children.label: II
children.definition: the fourth part of a κοτύλη, about 1/8 of a pint, μέλιτος Alex. 172.11, cf. Thphr. HP 9.11.7, al., Nic. Th. 598, Dsc. 3.27. (The form ὀξόβαφον BGU 781 iii 5 (i A.D.), PMed.Strassb. p.7 K., is condemned by Phryn. PS p.97 B.)

sharp-pointed, ἆλτο δʼ ὀϊστὸς ὀξυβελής Il. 4.126 ; ὀ. χαῖται, of the porcupineʼs bristles, Emp. 83.2 ; ἥλιος Id. 40 ; νῶτα καράβου Opp. H. 2.346 : metaph., πόθος ὀ. ib. 4.41 : in Prose, of a lancet, τὸ -ές Gal. 12.413.

children.label: II
children.definition: shooting sharp-pointed, and therefore swift, missiles, ὀ. [ὄργανα], opp. λιθοβολικά, Ph. Bel. 54.49 ; ὀξυβελής, ὁ, with and without καταπέλτης, an engine for throwing sharp-pointed bolts, opp. πετροβόλος, D.S. 20.85, 86 ; so ὀξυβελικόν (sc. ὄργανον), τό, ib. 75, etc.
oxyblatta, bright purple, Cod.Just. 4.40.1.
to be sharp-sighted, Arr. Epict. 2.11.22.
one who is sharp-sighted, Hsch. s.v. ἀτρέστοις, Gloss.
sharpness of sight, Hsch. s.v. ὀξυωπίαν.
shrill-screaming, of birds, A. Ag. 57 ; of men, Luc. JTr. 31 ; sharp-buzzing, of mosquitoes, AP 5.150 ( Mel.).
quickness of counsel, Sch.B Il. 10.204 (better ὀξυλαβία, as Sch.T).
steep in vinegar, Stud.Pal. 20.27.2 (ii/iii A.D.).
sour milk, whey, πίνουσι . . ὀ. τῶν προβάτων Ctes. Fr. 57.22, cf. Str. 7.4.6, Plu. Art. 3, Gal. 6.689.
made of sour milk, τυρός Gal. 6.697, 12.272, cf. 6.518.
sauce of vinegar and γάρον, Arr. Epict. 2.20.30, Gal. 6.534, Ath. 2.67e, 9.366c:—also ὀξόγαρον, Gloss., condemned by Phryn. PS p.97 B.
= Lat. axungia, lard, Dsc. 3.90, al., Orib. Fr. 97, Gloss.
with pointed chin, Poll. 4.145.
point of the chin, Poll. 2.97.
bufo et cufo, Gloss.
drink of acidulated honey, Hp. Fract. 11 (in dat. -εῖ), 36 (in acc. -υ), etc. :—so ὀξυ-γλῠκές, τό, Gal. 18(2).466 ; ὀξύ-γλῠκον, τό, Lat. dulcacidum, Gloss.
sour-sweet, ῥόα A. Fr. 363 ; ὁ τῆς ὀξυγλύκεος ῥοιᾶς χυλός (prob. a special variety) Orib. Fr. 53.
Dsc. 4.63,64 ( -τονον codd., cf. Apul. Herb. 53, Gloss.).
shrill-wailing, λιταί A. Th. 320 (lyr.).
writing fast, LXX Ps. 44 ( 45). 2, Ph. 2.363, etc.
acute-angled, Arist. Top. 107a17, Cael. 307a2, Euc. 1 Def. 21, Onos. 10.16 : neut. as Subst., acute-angled body, Epicur. Ep. 2p.50U. (pl.).
a being acute-angled, Apollod. Poliorc. 159.7.

definition: ὀξυδερκέω, prob. f.l. for ὀξυδορκέω, Ph. 1.409, 2.480, Hsch. s.v. ἐκ δυοῖν τρία βλέπεις ( -δορκ- Suid.).

children.definition: sharp-sighted, quick-sighted, Luc. Tim. 25, al. : Comp. -έστερος Id. Vit.Auct. 26, Hegesand. 9 ; ὄψις Alex.Aphr. in Top. 262.10 : Sup. -έστατος Hdt. 2.68, Arist. Mir. 834b28. Adv. -κῶς Ph. 1.590 : Comp. -έστερον ib. 229.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., promoting quickness of sight, ὕδωρ Diocl. Fr. 128, cf. Dsc. 5.5, Gal. 12.263, al.
sharp-sightedness, αἰσθήσεων Epicur. Nat. 28 Fr. 6, cf. Apollod. 3.10.3, Gal. 14.241, Alex.Aphr. in Top. 258.17, etc.: Ion. ὀξυ-δερκείη Democr. 119.
making the sight sharp, as L. Dind. for ὀξυδερκιῶν in Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.23.29 ( ὀξυδορκικῶν Dar.) ; -δερκικοῖς (and -δορκικοῖς) v.l. for -δερκέσι in Dsc. 2.163.

definition: ὀξυδερκώ, οῦς, ἡ, epith. of Athena, Paus. 2.24.2.

children.definition: to be quick of sight, Arist. Rh.Al. 1421a22, Com.Adesp. 359, Str. 6.2.1, etc.; v. -δερκέω.
Andronic.Rhod. p. 572 M., Hippod. ap. Stob. 4.39.26, Plot. 5.9.1, etc.
Plu. Adul. 2.69a, Gal. 11.778.
sharp-sounding, κύμβαλα AP 6.94 ( Phil.).
swift-running, Sch. Pi. O. 13.51.
with sharp points, nom. pl. -έθειρες, ἐχῖνοι Marc.Sid. 35 ; acc. pl. -έθειρας, ἀκάνθας Nonn. D. 14.368 ; gen.sg. -έθειρος, ἀκάνθης ib. 22.25.
mixture of oil and vinegar, Gal. 13.397.
acid ferments, Ps.-Democr. ap. Zos.Alch. p.160 B.
with a sharp sauce, Apic. 6.9.241.
a sharp, quick ear, Hippod. ap. Stob. 4.39.26, Metop. ib. 3.1.115, Plu. Aud.poet. 2.34c, Alex.Aphr. in Top. 327.14, interpol. in Poll. 2.82.

quick of hearing : of quick perception, keen, αἴσθησις Pl. Ti. 75b ; ἰχθύες Arist. HA 534a6, cf. A.D. Synt. 295.23.—In codd. sts. wrongly ὀξύκοος, ὀξυκοΐα : Comp. ὀξυηκοώτερος Luc. Pr.Im. 20, Porph. Abst. 3.8 : Sup. ὀξυηκοώτατος prob. l. in S.E. M. 9.65, for ὀξυηκούστατος.
sharp-sounding, of high notes, Philostr. VS 1.8.1 :
early death, Heliod.Astr. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).238.
dying quickly, shortlived, Eun. Hist. p.269 D., Heliod.Astr. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 4.154.

data.ref: Eun. Hist. p.269 D., Heliod.Astr. in

children.label: II
children.definition: killing quickly, Str. 17.2.4 ( Comp.).

definition: ὀξυθηγής, ές, = sq.: metaph., καιροί v.l. in Gal. 19.183.

children.definition: sharp-edged, sharp-pointed, φάσγανον, βέλος, E. Andr. 1150, El. 1159 (lyr.): gloss on ταναηκής, Sch. Il. Oxy. 1087.63.

children.label: II
children.definition: goaded to passion, infuriated, S. Ant. 1301 (s.v.l.).
light-haired or bristly-haired, Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.198.
to be quick to anger, E. Andr. 689.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be provoked, ὀξυθυμηθεῖσά μοι Ar. V. 501, cf. Th. 466 ; to be irritable, Gal. 15.598.
passionateness, v.l. in Artem. 4.69.
vivacity or instability of temper, Hp. Epid. 2.4.4, E. Andr. 728, Ruf. ap. Orib. inc. 6.5 ; excitability, ἐς γέλωτα Aret. SD 1.5, cf. Poll. 2.231 (v.l.).

refuse deposited at cross-roads near the statues of Hecate, ὃν χρῆν ἔν τε ταῖς τριόδοις κἀν τοῖς ὀξυθυμίοις προστρόπαιον τῆς πόλεως κάεσθαι τετριγότα should have been burned among the refuse, Eup. 120 ; περὶ οὗ πολλῷ ἂν δικαιότερον ἐν τοῖς ὀ. ἡ στήλη σταθείη ἢ ἐν τοῖς ἡμετέροις ἱεροῖς Hyp. Fr. 79 ; τῶν ὀ. ἀτιμότερος Poll. 5.163, cf. 2.231 ; = Ἑκαταῖα II, Did. ap. Harp., cf. Phot., Suid. ; or perh. gallows (so Aristarch.), τίς γὰρ ἂν ἀντὶ ῥαφανῖδος ὀξυθύμιʼ εἰσορῶν ἔλθοι πρὸς ἡμᾶς; prob. in Com.Adesp. 400 ; cf. ἑκάτη.

data.quote: περὶ οὗ πολλῷ ἂν δικαιότερον ἐν τοῖς ὀ. ἡ στήλη σταθείη ἢ ἐν τοῖς ἡμετέροις ἱεροῖς

children.definition: one who is quick to anger, Poll. 2.231, 6.124.
a kind of thyme, PLille 58 ii 21. iii 10 (iii B.C.).

quick to anger, choleric, Epich. 281. E. Med. 319, Ar. V. 406, 455, 1105, Arist. Rh. 1368b20, LXX Pr. 14.17, al. ; sharp to punish, of the Areopagus, A. Eu. 705 ; τὸ ὀξύθυμον, by crasis τοὐξύθυμον, = ὀξυθυμία, E. Ba. 671, Men. Georg.Fr. 3.
of beech-wood, Theopomp.Coloph. ap. Ath. 4.183b ( οἰσύινον Kaibel), Thphr. HP 5.7.2, Inscr.Délos 290.226 (iii B.C.):—later ὀξέϊνος, Apollod. Poliorc. 176.5, Gp. 15.2.7, Gloss.
sharply curved, of hooks, Antyll. ap. Orib. 45.18.13.
prickly cedar, Juniperus Oxycedrus, Thphr. HP 3.12.3.
quick-travelling, δρόμος Nonn. D. 5.233 codd. ( λοξοκέλευθον Koch, Ludw.).
= sq., Sch.rec. A. Pr. 424, Hsch. s.v. ὀξύπρῳροι.
with pointed horns, Opp. C. 2.445.
with pointed head, Poll. 2.43, Philum. Ven. 31.1, Sch. Ar. Av. 1295.
quickness of motion, Ptol. Tetr. 19, Porph. ap. Eus. PE 3.12, Eun. VS p.473 B., Lyd. Mens. 2.9.
quickly moving, Luc. Abd. 28, Dips. 5 ; διάνοια Ph. 1.605 ; of tumours, etc., Cass. Pr. 1.
oxycomina, olives served in brine or vinegar, Petron. 66.7 (cf. cominia, pl. = a kind of olive, Pallad. Agric. 3.18, oximinum = aceto mixto cum cumino, Gloss.).
gum, in the form ὀξωκόμῃ (dat. sg. fem.), PMag.Osl. 1.74.
with pointed hair, of the porcupine, Opp. C. 2.599 ; of a stag, ib. 194 ; of a pine, App.Anth. 5.46 ; with pointed spines, of a fish, Marc.Sid. 21.

data.ref: Opp. C. 2.599 ; of a stag, ib.

children.definition: with a sharp hook, σμιλίον Paul.Aeg. 6.87.
posca, Gloss.
poscarius, Gloss.
sour wine mixed with water, Dsc. 2.105, Aret. CA 1.1, Antyll. ap. Orib. 45.18.31, 4.11.14, Erot. s.v. μᾶζα, Gal. 11.439, al., Aët. 15.1.
fabae acetatae (acetosae), Gloss.
wailed with shrill cries, πάθος S. Ant. 1316.
quickness in seizing an opportunity, Eust. 123.46 ; cf. ὀξυλαβία.
seize quickly : seize an opportunity, X. HG 7.4.27, Men. Epit. 528, Gal. Parv.Pil. 3.
tongs, Suid. s.v. Ἥφαιστος :

definition: ὀξύλαβος, ὁ, Sch. Il. 18.477, Gloss. :— Dim. ὀξῠ-λᾰβίδιον, τό, Hermes 38.282.

children.definition: quick at seizing, of the eagle, Arist. HA 619b29.
quickness in seizing an opportunity, Sch.T Il. 10.204, Sch. A. Th. 97 ; cf. ὀξυλάβεια.

children.label: II
children.definition: ὀξυλάβη.
glib of tongue, Ar. Ra. 815 (lyr.).
curled dock, Rumex crispus, Dsc. 2.114, Gal. 6.635, al., Aret. CA 2.2, etc.: also ὀξῠ-λάπαθος, ὁ, Gp. 2.5.4.
composed of vinegar and oil, τρίμμα Timocl. 3.2 ; χυμίον Sotad.Com. 1.19.
dressed with vinegar and fat, Gal. 10.575.
have sharp ears, hear sharply, Suid.
quickness at learning, Str. 2.3.5, with v.l. ὀξυμαθία.
learning quickly, Phryn. PS p.97 B., Suid. s.v. θυμόσοφος.

definition: ὀξύμαλον Περσικόν, τό, Lacon. for κοκκύμηλον Περσικόν,

children.definition: peach, Prunus persica, Ar.Byz. ap. Ath. 3.83a, Hsch.
clear-singing, f.l. in Ar. Av. 1095 (lyr.).
mixture of vinegar and honey, oxymel, Hp. Loc.Hom. 17:—also ὀξύμελι, ῐτος, τό, Id. Acut. 19, 59, Lys. Fr. 42, Arist. Pr. 922a6, cf. Dsc. 5.14, Gal. 15.677.
keenly laboured or studied, παλαίσματα Ar. Ra. 877 (lyr.).
bringing down quick anger (i. e. of the Erinyes), φόνου ( -ους codd.) ὀξυμηνίτου A. Eu. 472.
clear-singing, A. Th. 1028.
butcherʼs broom, Ruscus aculeatus, Dsc. 4.144, cf. 1.11, Androm. ap. Gal. 13.842, Gal. 6.643 ; also called χαμαιμυρσίνη, Plin. HN 15.27, 23.165.

pointedly foolish : τὸ ὀξύμωρον a witty saying, the more pointed from being paradoxical or seemingly absurd, such as insaniens sapientia, strenua inertia, splendide mendax, Serv.ad Verg. A. 7.295, etc.
mixture of vinegar and soda, Paul.Aeg. 5.4.
acute illness, Cat.Cod.Astr. 1.119 (pl.).
sharp-witted, Sch.rec. A. Pers. 93.
one must pronounce with the acute accent, Sch. Il. 15.445.
sharpener, δονακήων, i.e. a penknife, AP 6.64 ( Paul.Sil.), cf. Aq. Jb. 41.22.
payment for sharpening tools, σιδήρου IG 2(2).1672.121 ; τῶν Βακχίου σιδηρίων Παρμένοντι ὄξυντρα ib. 11(2).203 A 58 ( Delos, iii B. C.), cf. Supp.Epigr. 4.447.42,453.49,59 ( Didyma, ii B. C.).

definition: ὀξύνω [ῡ], fut. ὀξῠνῶ LXX Wi. 5.20, ( παρ-) D. 2.11, 54.25 : aor. ὤξῡνα S. Tr. 1176 : pf. ὤξυγκα ( παρ-) Plb. 31.1.3, J. AJ 11.6.7 :— Pass., fut. ὀξυνθήσομαι ( παρ-) Hp. Acut.(Sp.) 17: aor. ὠξύνθην Hdt. (v. infr.), etc.: pf. ὤξυμμαι ( παρ-) Lys. 4.8, D. 14.16, ( ἀπ-) Plb. 18.18.13, etc.; later ὤξυσμαι ( ἀπ-, συν-) Id. 1.22.7, 6.22.4 :—

children.definition: sharpen, point, ἔγχος ὀ. σιδήρῳ Epigr.Gr. 790.5 ( Dyme) ; ἄκρη ἐς μυχὸν ὀξυνθεῖσα D.P. 177 ; of the nose, ῥῖνα ὠξυμμένην Gal. 17(1).998.

children.label: II
children.definition: goad to anger, provoke, τοὐμὸν ὀξῦναι στόμα S. l.c.:— Pass., ὀξυνθείς Hdt. 8.138, cf. LXX Ez. 21.9(14).
become acute, of pain, Aret. SD 2.11.

children.label: III
children.definition: A.D. Pron. 28.5 ( Pass.), 43.10, al.

children.label: IV
children.definition: make acid, Gal. 6.691 :— Pass., to be or become so, of wine, Arist. GA 753a23, Luc. Sat. 26 :—so, intr. in Act., Thphr. HP 4.3.4.

senses.definition: with sharp teeth; in Nonn. D. 40.484, with a neut. Subst.
with beechen shaft, beechen, ἔγχεα ὀξυόεντα Il. 5.568, cf. 50, etc.; δουρὶ μετάλμενος ὀξυόεντι 14.443, cf. Eust. 1951.2, Hsch.: the deriv. from ὀξύς is less probable.

children.definition: with a sharp shell, Luc. Lex. 13.
sharp-pointed, στάλικες AP 6.109 (Antip.) ; ὄνυξ Nonn. D. 14.385 ; prickly, κάραβος Opp. H. 1.261.
oxypaederotinus, bright pink, Hist.Aug.Aurelian. 46.
wildly screaming, Tim. Pers. 76.
concoct too fast, χυμόν Gal. 19.649.

ravenously hungry, ravenous, greedy, of the eagle, Arist. HA 619b29 ; of persons, Antiph. 276, Eub. 10.4 : metaph., πρὸς τοὺς λόγους ὀ. Plu. Garr. 2.512f, cf. Cic. Att. 2.12.2 :—later ὀξῠ-πείνης, ου, ὁ, of one who eats between meals, Anon. in EN 182.9 ; τένθης λέγεται ὁ ὀ. καὶ προτένθης Procl.ad Hes. Op. 522.
mixture of vinegar and pepper, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.84.
flying speedily, Sch. Od. 3.372.
with sharp stones, γῆς ποιὸν εἶδος οἱ γεωργικοί φασιν, Hsch.
sharp-pointed, ξίφος A. Ch. 640 (lyr.).
keen, smarting, Hsch. s.v. ὀξυπευκές; = acidus, Gloss.
struck by a sharp blow, cj. in S. Ant. 1301.
accompanying fierce blows, γόους S. Fr. 523.
quicken oneʼs pace, Gloss.
one who quickens his pace, Gloss.
quickening of oneʼs pace, Gloss.
quickness of eating and digesting, Gloss. (prob.).
a carminative medicine, Ps.- Gal. 19.717, Aët. 5.68 ; [τροφή] Philum. ap. eund. 9.23 :—also ὀξῠ-πορος, ον, Gal. 14.751, Orib. Fr. 46, etc.
piercing sharply, ἄγγος Opp. H. 2.406.
quick-passing, active, of medicines, Dsc. 3.51.

definition: ὀξύπους, ὁ, ἡ, πουν, τό, swift-footed, E. Or. 1550 (troch.). -->

children.definition: sharp-prowed: sharp-pointed, αἰχμαί A. Pr. 423 (lyr.) ; ῥάχις Opp. H. 3.333 : to be written with iota, Achae. ap. Lex.Mess. p.408.
hawk, Gloss.

sharp- or swift-winged: as Subst. ὀ., ὁ, = ὀξύσχοινος, Ps.- Dsc. 4.52 ; but, hawk, Clem.Al. Strom. 5.8.52.1 (in citation of De. 14.13) :—also ὀξῠ-πτερον, τό, = falco, Gloss.; τὰ ὀξύπτερα swift wings, Aesop. 8.
sharp-rumped, Hippiatr. 14.
with pointed bottom, of shell-fish, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.85 ( Comp.; -μενοί τε codd.).
in the higher region of the πυκνόν (q. v.), φθόγγος Cleonid. Harm. 4, 9, Bacch. Harm. 27, cf. Aristid.Quint. 1.6.
with a pointed beard, Heph.Astr. 2.2.
the sour fumes caused by indigestion, heartburn, Hp. Aph. 6.1, Aret. SA 2.3, Gal. 6.344, Aët. 9.43, etc.
the peevishness or fretfulness caused thereby, Ar. Fr. 473 ; cf. κρομμυοξυρεγμία, ὀξωρεγμία.
to be troubled with heartburn, Dsc. 3.30, 4.1, Antyll. ap. Orib. 6.8.3.
troubled with heartburn, Hp. Aph. 6.33, Acut. 28 ; causing heartburn, φῦσαι Aret. SD 2.8 ; ἀπεψία Gal. 10.579.
quick-turning art. Pi. O. 9.91 ; ὀξυρρεπής in Hsch.

definition: ὀξύρριν ( PPetr. 3p.25 (iii B. C.)) or ὀξῠ-ρρῑς, ῑνος, ὁ, ἡ, (ῥίς)

children.definition: with sharp or fine nose, Hp. Epid. 2.5.1 :—also ὀξύρρινος, ον, interpol. in Zonar. s.v. Γρυπόν.
rose-oil mixed with vinegar, Ath. 2.67f, Gal. 11.559, Gloss.
quick change, τῆς ὥρας Vett.Val. 299.35.

turning quickly, prop. of a delicate balance : metaph., ὀ. πρὸς τὰς ὀργάς sudden and quick to anger, Pl. Tht. 144a ; εἰς ὀργήν Jul. Or. 2.65d ; νοῦς ὀ. πρὸς τὰς μιαιφονίας Memn. 2 ; also ὀ. θυμός unstable temper, Pl. R. 411b ; τὸ ὀ. τῆς πεύσεως rapidity or vehemence, Longin. 18.1 ; cf. ὀξυρεπής. Adv. -πως D.C. Fr. 50.3.

definition: ὀξυρρυγχιτικόν (sc. μέτρον), τό, a measure of capacity in Egypt, PLond. 3.1170v. 79 (iii A. D.), PGiss. 34.12 (iii A. D.).

children.definition: sharp-snouted: metaph., sharp-pointed, ῥαφίδες Epich. 51 ; ὁ ὀ. χαρακτήρ, name of a style of handwriting, Phlp. in APr. 5.9 ; ὁ ὀ. τύπος Id. in APo. 1.13, in de An. 227.15.
Subst., ὀ., ὁ, a sharp-snouted Egyptian fish, [ Hes.] ap. Ath. 3.116b, Str. 17.2.4, Ael. NA 10.46, Ath. 7.312b.
wood sorrel, Oxalis Acetosella, Plin. HN 27.112.
great sea-rush, Juncus acutus, ib. 21.113.
sorrel, Rumex acetosa, Gal. 11.667.

definition: ὀξύς, εῖα, ύ, Ion. fem. ὀξέα Hdt. 9.23, al., v.l. in Hp. Mul. 1.64, al. (in codd. freq. ὀξέη, and so Babr. 73.1 metri gr.) : ὀξεῖα, poet. for neut. pl. ὀξέα, Hes. Sc. 348 :—

children.definition: sharp, keen, whether of a point or an edge, in Hom. and Hes. mostly of weapons or anything made of metal, ἄκων Il. 10.335, al.; ἄορ 21.173, Hes. Sc. 457 ; βέλος Il. 4.185, etc.; also of non-metallic substances, λᾶας 16.739 ; μοχλός Od. 9.382 ; σκόλοπες Il. 12.56, 64 ; ὀξεῖα κορυφή, of a mountain-peak, Od. 12.74 ; so πάγοι ὀξέες 5.411 ; λίθος ὀξὺς πεποιημένος sharpened so as to serve as a knife, Hdt. 7.69, cf. 3.8 ; κυρβασίας ἐς ὀξὺ ἀπηγμένας brought to a point, Id. 7.64 ; ὄρεα ἐς ὀ. τὰς κορυφὰς ἀ. Id. 2.28 ; τὸ ὀ. the apex of a triangle, ib. 16 ; of the heart, Arist. Resp. 478b5 ; τὸ ὀ. τοῦ ᾠοῦ Id. GA 752b8 ; ὀ. γωνία an acute angle, Id. Top. 107a16, al., Euc. 1 Def. 12, Archim. Spir. 16 ; Χρόνος ὀξὺς ὀδόντας Simon. 176 ; ἡ ὀξεῖα, name of a surgical instrument, Hermes 38.282, Heliod. ap. Orib. 44.23.59 ; but also, a pointed splinter of bone, ib. 46.20.5.

data.quote: ὄρεα ἐς ὀ. τὰς κορυφὰς ἀ.

children.definition: sharp, keen, ὀδύναι Il. 11.268 ; ὀ. ἠέλιος the piercing sun, h.Ap. 374 ; ὀξειᾶν ἀκτίνων πατήρ, i.e. the Sun, Pi. O. 7.70 ; Σείριος ὀξὺς ἐλλάμπων Archil. 61 ; πῦρ ὀ. Anaxipp. 1.12 ; so χιὼν ὀξεῖα Pi. P. 1.20 ; so also of grief and the like, ἄχος Il. 19.125 ; μελεδῶναι Od. 19.517 : and generally, sharp, severe, μάχη ὀξέα . . γίνεται keenly contested, Hdt. 9.23 ; ὀ. πυρετός Hp. VM 16 ( Sup.); [ἡ νόσος] ὀξεῖα φοιτᾷ καὶ ταχεῖʼ ἀπέρχεται S. Ph. 808 ; νόσοι, μανίαι, Pi. O. 8.85, N. 11.48 ( Comp.), cf. Hp. Acut. tit., Archig. ap. Gal. 9.887 ; πάθαι Pi. P. 3.97 ; ἐπιμομφά Id. O. 10(11).9, etc.

data.quote: [ἡ νόσος] ὀξεῖα φοιτᾷ καὶ ταχεῖʼ ἀπέρχεται

children.definition: ὀξύτατον ὄμμα Id. N. 10.62 ; ὄψις . . ὀξυτάτη τῶν διὰ τοῦ σώματος . . αἰσθήσεων Pl. Phdr. 250d : freq. in neut. as Adv., ὀξύτατον δέρκεσθαι to be keenest of sight, Il. 17.675 ; ὀξύτατα καθορᾶν Pl. R. 516c ; so ὀξὺ νοεῖν notice a thing sharply, Il. 3.374 ; ὀξὺ προϊδεῖν Od. 5.393 ; ὀξύτερον βλέπει Ar. Pl. 1048, Lys. 1202 (lyr.) : prov., ὀξύτερον τοῦ Λυγκέως βλέπειν Id. Pl. 210, cf. Macar. Prov. 6.41 ; also ὀξὺ ἄκουσεν heard with sharp ear, Il. 17.256, cf. Pl. Lg. 927b ; ὀξεῖαν ἀκοὴν . . λόγοις διδούς keen attention, S. El. 30.

data.quote: ὄψις . . ὀξυτάτη τῶν διὰ τοῦ σώματος . . αἰσθήσεων

children.label: b
children.definition: dazzling, bright, αὐγὴ Ἠελίου Il. 17.372 ; [Ἠελίου] ὀξύτατον πέλεται φάος εἰσοράασθαι 14.345 : hence of colours, Ar. Pax 1173 (v. φοινικίς 2) ; αἱ ὀξεῖαι χροιαί Arist. Phgn. 806b4 ; πορφύρα Plu. Cat.Mi. 6, PHolm. 20.36 ; [ἐσθὴς] ὀξυτέρα καὶ τηλαυγεστέρα Ael. NA 4.46.

shrill, piercing, ἀϋτή Il. 15.313 ; ὀξὺ βοήσας 17.89 ; ὀξὺ δὲ κωκύσασα 18.71 ; ὀξὺ λεληκώς 22.141 ; ὀξέα κεκληγώς 17.88, etc.; of whinnying horses, ὀξεῖα χρέμισαν Hes. Sc. 348 ; of young pigs, ὀξὺ κεκράγατε Ar. Ach. 804 ; of the scream of birds of prey, ὀξέα κλάζων S. Ant. 112 (anap.) ; of metals, ἰάχεσκε σάκος ὀξέα καὶ λιγέως Hes. Sc. 233 ; also of the wail of the nightingale (cf. ὀξύφωνος), ὄρνιθος ὀ. φθόγγον S. Ant. 424 ; so ἐπηλάλαξαν τὸν ὀ. νόμον shrieked their shrill song, A. Th. 952 (lyr.) ; ὀξὺ μέλος, of the grasshopper, Ar. Av. 1095 (lyr.).

children.label: b
children.definition: high-pitched, opp. βαρύς, φθόγγοι Pl. Ti. 80a, X. Cyn. 6.20 ; ὀξυτάτη χορδή Pl. Phdr. 268d ; φωνὴ ὀξεῖα, βαρεῖα, μέση Arist. Rh. 1403b29 ; τῷ ὀξεῖ ἐν φωνῇ μὲν ἐναντίον τὸ βαρύ, ἐν ὄγκῳ δὲ τὸ ἀμβλύ Id. Top. 106a13.

data.quote: τῷ ὀξεῖ ἐν φωνῇ μὲν ἐναντίον τὸ βαρύ, ἐν ὄγκῳ δὲ τὸ ἀμβλύ

children.label: c
children.definition: διʼ ὀξειῶν ( Dor. -ᾶν) interval of a fifth, Philol. 6, Arist. Pr. 920a24.

children.label: d
children.definition: ἡ ὀξεῖα (sc. προσῳδία) the acute accent, D.T. 630.1, A.D. Pron. 35.10, al.; τὸν τόνον φυλάσσειν ὀ. ib. 60.1 ; ὀ. συλλαβή Pl. Cra. 399b ; ὀ. στοιχεῖον S.E. M. 1.113.
sharp, pungent, acid, φακῆ X. Cyr. 6.2.31 ; ὄξος Diph. 18.1 ; οἶνος Alex. 141.12 ; ἐξ ὀξέος καὶ ἁλμυροῦ ξυνθεὶς ζύμωμα Pl. Ti. 74c.

data.quote: ἐξ ὀξέος καὶ ἁλμυροῦ ξυνθεὶς ζύμωμα

children.definition: Arist. de An. 421a30 ; ὀξύτατον ὄζειν τινός Ar. Ach. 193.

children.label: III
children.definition: sharp, keen, hasty, esp. quick to anger, passionate, epith. of Ares, Il. 2.440, al. ; μένος ὀξύ h.Hom. 8.14 ; καρδίη ὀξυτέρη Thgn. 366 ; θυμὸς ὀ. S. OC 1193 ; νέος καὶ ὀ. Pl. Grg. 463e ; οἱ ἀκρόχολοι ὀξεῖς Arist. EN 1126a18 : so in ὀξύ-θυμος, -κάρδιος, -χολος.

sharp, quick, δεινοὶ καὶ ὀξεῖς Pl. Ap. 39b : c. inf., ἐπινοῆσαι ὀ. Th. 1.70 ; γνῶναι . . ὀξύτατοι τὰ ῥηθέντα D. 3.15 ; also εἰς πάντα τὰ μαθήματα ὀξεῖς Pl. R. 526b ; τὰς ἐνθυμήσεις ὀξύς Luc. Salt. 81.

children.label: IV
children.definition: quick, swift, post- Hom., ὀξυτάτους ἵππους Hdt. 5.9 (v.l. ὠκυτάτους) ; ἱερακίσκος Ar. Av. 1112 ; ὀξυτέρῳ χαλινῷ S. Ant. 108 (lyr.) ; of a report, ὀξεῖα βάξις διῆλθʼ Ἀχαιούς Id. Aj. 998 ; ὀξεῖαν ἐκβάλλει ῥοήν, of a dying man, Id. Ant. 1238, cf. A. Ag. 1389 ; of a flame, fierce, Thphr. HP 5.9.3 ; ᾄξας ὀξὺς νότος ὥς S. Aj. 258 (anap.) ; τὸ εὔψυχον . . ὀξεῖς ἐνδείκνυνται are quick in displaying, Th. 4.126 ; opp. βραδύς, Id. 8.96 ; opp. ῥάθυμος, Arist. EE 1240a2 ; opp. ἡσύχιος, Id. EN 1116a9 ; ὀ. παράγγελμα Onos. 10.2 ; ὀ. καιρός an urgent crisis, Id. 6.1, al.; ὁ ὀ. δρόμος the express post, POxy. 900.7 (iv A. D.), 2115.6 (iv A. D.) ; ὀξεῖς οἱ πόδες αὐτῶν ἐκχέαι αἷμα Ep.Rom. 3.15 : esp. in Adv. (v. infr.).

data.quote: ὀξεῖς οἱ πόδες αὐτῶν ἐκχέαι αἷμα

children.label: V
children.definition: Adv. ὀξέως quickly, soon, βοηθεῖν, μεταχειρίσαι, Th. 6.10, 12, etc.; sharply, ὁρᾶν, αἰσθάνεσθαι, Pl. R. 567b, Phdr. 263c ; poet. ὀξείως Epigr.Gr. 986.3 ( Philae) : Comp. ὀξυτέρως Hp. Epid. 3.17.βʹ ; ὀξυτέρως ἀποθνῄσκειν ib. 1.2 ; but,
ὀξύ and pl. ὀξέα as Adv., v. supr. II.2, 3 : Comp. ὀξύτερον Th. 2.8, Pl. Tht. 190a : Sup. ὀξύτατον Il. 17.675, Pl. Lg. 741d ; or ὀξύτατα Id. R. 401e, al. (Cf. ὀξίνα, ὄκρις.)
a disorder in which the food turns acid on the stomach, like ὀξυρεγμία, Aristid. Or. 47(23).9.
sharpening of tools, IG ΙΙ(2).158 A 83, al. ( Delos, iii B. C.) ; cf. ὄξυντρα.
sharp-breasted, of animals as compared with man, Gal. 18(1).536.
sharp-beaked, of gryphons, A. Pr. 803 ; of Ioʼs gadfly, ib. 674 ; of a gnat, Ar. Av. 244 (lyr.).

data.ref: A. Pr. 803 ; of Ioʼs gadfly, ib.

children.definition: sharp-edged, E. Supp. 1206 ; of a cupping instrument, sharp-rimmed, Antyll. ap. Orib. 7.16.15.

data.ref: E. Supp. 1206 ; of a cupping instrument,

children.definition: great sea-rush, Juncus acutus, Batr. 164, Dsc. 4.52, Gal. 12.136.
with sharp ends, diamond shaped, διόπτραι, of open spaces in lattice-work, dub.l. in Lyd. Mag. 3.37 (fort. ὀξυτενής, ές, eodem sensu, cf. Suid.).
sharpness, pointedness, of acute angles, Pl. Ti. 61e, cf. 56d.
sharpness, opp. βαρύτης, Id. Phlb. 17c, Tht. 163c.
pungency, acidity, in pl., Hp. VM 19, Acut. 61, cf. Gal. 11.656.
Arist. HA 492a4.

children.label: III
children.definition: sharpness, cleverness, τῆς ψυχῆς Phld. Rh. 2.31 S. ; σκέψεως ibid.; διαφέροντα τῇ τέχνῃ τῇ τʼ ὀξύτητι Philosteph. Com.I; ὀ. ἐς τὰ πολιτικά Luc. Im. 17.

children.label: IV
children.definition: quickness, of motion, action, or occurrence, Critias 37 D., Pl. Chrm. 160b, Plt. 306c, al.; ταῖς ὀξύτησι . . ἀκολουθεῖν D. 24.95 ; ἡ ὀ. τοῦ καιροῦ the pressing occasion, Plu. Pyrrh. 2, D.S. 15.43.

children.label: V
children.definition: = ὀξεῖα, ἡ, v. ὀξύς II.3d, A.D. Adv. 138.16, cf. Arist. Po. 1456b33 : pl., Pl. Cra. 399a.
sharp-cutting, keen, Pi. P. 4.263.
pronounce with an acute accent, i. e. on the last syllable, τὴν λέξιν Ath. 9.400b, cf. Ph. 1.243, Cleonid. Harm. 12, A.D. Synt. 264.4 :— Pass., Id. Pron. 29.3, al., Gal. 18(2).518.
make high-pitched, τοὺς φθόγγους Nicom. Harm. 10.
a pronouncing with an acute accent, Eust. 60.13.
one must pronounce oxytone, AB 457.
sharp-sounding, piercing. of sound, ὀ. γόοι S. El. 243 (lyr.) ; ὀξυτόνους ᾠδὰς θρηνήσει Id. Aj. 631 (lyr.) ; ὀξυτόνου διὰ πνεύματος Id. Ph. 1093 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: sung to a high note, D.H. Comp. 11 ; having the acute accent, Hermog. Id. 1.12, A.D. Pron. 33.24, al. Adv. -νως ib. 29.2, S.E. M. 1.222, Eust. 41.4.

children.label: III
children.definition: Subst. -τονον, τό, v. ὀξύγονον.
piercing, pointed, πίτυς ὀ. the pine with its sharp spines, AP 4.1.16 ( Mel.).
Scrib.Larg. 163, Plin. HN 21.54, Gloss.
bright Tyrian purple, Edict.Diocl. 24.4, al.

definition: ὀξύφαγρος, ὁ, a kind of φάγρος, a sea-fish, v.l. in Opp. H. 1.140.

children.definition: keen-sighted, Nonn. D. 7.214, 28.303 (with v.l. ὀξυφανής).
bright-beaming, epith. of ῥόδα, Chaerem. 8.
violent inflammation, Hp. Virg. 1.
Ruf. Fr. 80.
acute, sagacious, E. Med. 641 (lyr.) ; crafty, Ptol. Tetr. 165.
with pointed leaves, θρίδαξ Dsc. 4.23.

children.label: II
children.definition: ὀξῠ-φυλλον, τό, = τρίφυλλον, Id. 3.109, Gal. 12.144.
to have a shrill voice, Gal. 16.607, Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus. 58.71.
pronounce with an acute accent, Eust. 23.4 ( Pass.).
high pitch of voice, Hp. Coac. 252, Arist. EN 1125a15 ; opp. βαρύτης, Id. GA 788a3.

shrill-voiced, piercing (cf. ὀξύς II.3), Telest. 5 ; of the nightingale, S. Tr. 963 (lyr.), Babr. 12.3 ; with high-pitched voice, γυναῖκες Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.97 : Comp. -ότερος Arist. HA 538b13, GA 787b9.
quick with the hands, quick to strike, quarrelsome, Lys. 4.8, Men. 1048, Theoc. Ep. 22.2 ; ὀ. κοὐκ ἐγκρατής Nicom.Com. 1.33.
ὀξύχειρι σὺν κτύπῳ with quick beating of the hands in lamentation, A. Ch. 23 (lyr.).
quickness of hand, Alex. 323 ; of conjurers, S.E. M. 2.39 ; ἀπνευστὶ καὶ -χειρίᾳ δρᾶν τι Ph. 2.87.
quick to anger, Sol. 13.26, S. Ant. 955 (v.l. for ὀξυχόλως), AP 9.127 ; τὸ ὀ. Luc. Fug. 19.
to be sharp-sighted, Thphr. Sens. 8, Ph. 1.392, Alex.Aphr. in Top. 327.13 ; ὀ. πρὸς τὴν κατάληψιν Anachars. ap. S.E. M. 7.55.

sharp-sighted, ὀφθαλμοὶ -έστατοι Arist. HA 492a9 ; ὁ ἁλιάετος -έστατος ib. 620a2, cf. Luc. Icar. 14 : Comp. -έστερος Ph. 1.531, 2.546. Adv., -έστερον βλέπεις Suid. s.v. Λυγκέως; -έστατα ὁρᾶν Ph. 1.338 ; βλέπειν Herm. ap. Stob. 1.49.45.
θίξις -εστέρα Marcellin. Puls. 19.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., sharpening the sight, Dsc. 3.45.
sharp-sightedness, Arist. PA 691a25, Pr. 876b25, Dsc. 2.56, S.E. M. 5.81 ; λογισμοῦ Ph. 2.314.
one who sees sharply, Poll. 2.51.
Arist. HA 618b8, PA 657b26.
with sharp angles, of dressed stone, IG 7.3073.133 ( Lebad., ii B. C. ; cf. εὐθύωρος).
like vinegar, acid, Gal. 8.34, al., S.E. P. 1.110, Alex.Aphr. in Sens. 83.19, al.
Phryn. PS p.97 B.

definition: ὀξωτός, ή, όν, (as if from ὀξόω)

children.definition: pickled, Ar. Fr. 130.
the fruit of the service-tree, v. ὄα (A). ὅου, Ep. gen. for οὗ, of whom, v. ὅς.

definition: ὀπάζω, impf. ὤπαζον Il. 8.341 ; Ep. ὄπ- 16.730 : Ep. fut. ὀπάσσω Od. 8.430, 21.214 : aor. ὤπασα Il. 13.416, Hes. Th. 974, Pi. N. 1.16, and Trag. (v. infr.); Ep. and Lyr. also ὄπασσα, Od. 10.204, Pi. I. 7(6).38 :— Med., aor. ὠπασάμην, Ep. 3 sg. ὀπάσσατο Il. 19.238 ; 2 sg. subj. ὀπάσσεαι 10.238 :— Pass., only in pres. (v. fin.) :—

children.definition: ἕπομαι, make to follow, send with one, give as a companion or follower, ἐπεί ῥά οἱ ὤπασα πομπόν Il. 13.416 ; σοὶ γάρ με πατὴρ ἅμα πομπὸν ὄπασσεν 24.461, cf. Od. 9.90 ; ἅμʼ ἡγεμόνʼ ἐσθλὸν ὄπασσον 15.310 ; ἀρχὸν δὲ μετʼ ἀμφοτέροισιν ὄπασσα 10.204 ; πολὺν δέ μοι ὤπασε λαόν, i. e. made me leader over many, Il. 9.483, cf. Pi. N. 1.16 ; ὦ Ζεῦ, γυναικῶν οἷον ὤπασας γένος A. Th. 256 :— Med., bid another follow one, take with one, take as a companion, σὺ δὲ χείρονʼ ὀπάσσεαι Il. 10.238 ; Νέστορος υἷας ὀπάσσατο 19.238 ; κήρυκά τʼ ὀπασσάμενος καὶ ἑταῖρον Od. 10.59 :— Nic. uses the Med. in act. sense, σκολόπενδρα . . ὀπάζεται ἀνδράσι κῆρα Th. 813 : Hes. never has it in this sense.

data.quote: σοὶ γάρ με πατὴρ ἅμα πομπὸν ὄπασσεν
ὦ Ζεῦ, γυναικῶν οἷον ὤπασας γένος

children.label: II
children.definition: make or give to be with a person, then simply, give, grant, τούτῳ . . Ζεὺς κῦδος ὀπάζει gives him glory to be with him, Il. 8.141, cf. 17.566 ; κτήματα, ἀρετήν, κάλλος, ἀοιδήν, φῆμιν, ὀϊζύν, etc., freq. in Hom., Od. 21.214, 13.45, Il. 6.156, Od. 8.498, 24.201, 23.210, al. ; πολλὰ γὰρ ὤπασε παιδί gave her as a portion, Il. 22.51 ; τέλος ἐσθλὸν ὀ. grant a happy end, Hes. Op. 474 ; ὄλβον, ἄγρην, Id. Th. 420, 442 ; εὐδίαν ἐκ χειμῶνος ὀ. Pi. I. 7(6).38, al.; Ὕβρις . . πλοῦτον . . ἀλλότριον ὤπασεν B. 14.60 ; πῦρ ἐγώ σφιν ὤπασα A. Pr. 254, cf. 8, 30, Pers. 762, Eu. 530 (lyr.) ; a few times in E., e. g. Med. 517, twice in Ar., Eq. 200 (mock heroic), Th. 973 (lyr.): with pleon. inf., Πατρόκλῳ . . κόμην ὀπάσαιμι φέρεσθαι, like δίδωμι ἔχειν, Il. 23.151, cf. Pi. O. 9.66 :— Med., καλάμινθον ὀπάζεο take to yourself . . , Nic. Th. 60, cf. 520.

give besides something else, add, ἔργῳ δʼ ἔργον ὄπαζε h.Merc. 120 ; χάριν ἅμʼ ὄπασσον ἀοιδῇ h.Hom. 24.5 ; μελέταν ἔργοις ὀ. devote, Pi. I. 6(5).67 ; ἔργον ὤπασεν πρὸς ἀσπίδι put the work of art on the shield, A. Th. 492.

children.label: III
children.definition: press hard, chase, Ἕκτωρ ὤπαζε κάρη κομόωντας Ἀχαιούς Il. 8.341 ; χαλεπὸν δέ σε γῆρας ὀπάζει ib. 103 ; πολὺν καθʼ ὅμιλον ὀπάζων (sc. αὐτήν) 5.334, cf. 17.462 ; φόνια δʼ ὤπασας λέχεʼ ἀπὸ γᾶς didst chase them away, E. El. 1192 (lyr.) :— Pass., ποταμὸς . . ὀπαζόμενος Διὸς ὄμβρῳ a torrent forced on by rain, Il. 11.493.

children.label: IV
children.definition: ὀπασθείς· ἐκ τῶν ὀπίσω δεθείς, καὶ ἐξαγκωνισθείς, Hsch. (but cf. ὀσταθείς Id.). (The relation to ἕπομαι, ὀπαδός, ὀπάων is uncertain.)

with a hole or opening, διὰ τῆς ὀπαίας κεραμίδος, = διὰ τῆς καπνοδόκης, through the tile with a hole in it (for the smoke to escape), Diph. 84, cf. Moer. p.292P . . Poll. 2.54 :—also ὀπαῖον, τό, IG 1(2).374.127-139 (pl.), Plu. Per. 13 ; cf. ὀπή.—On the reading ἀνʼ ὀπαῖα Od. 1.320, v. ἀνοπαῖα.
opal, Orph. L. 282 ; opalus, Plin. 37.80.
τὸ ἐφόδιον, Πέρσαι, Hsch. (Perh. OPers. upastā ‘help’, ‘aid’.)
by the same father, κασίγνητος καὶ ὄπατρος Il. 11.257, 12.371:—also ὀπάτριος, ον, Lyc. 452.

definition: ὀπάων [ᾱ], ονος, ὁ, as in Hom. and Trag.; later Ion. ὀπέων, ωνος, Hdt. 9.50, 51, restored by Dind. in 5.111 : (v. ὀπάζω fin.) :—

children.definition: comrade in war, esquire, denoting the slight subordination in which one hero stood to another, as Meriones to Idomeneus, Il. 8.263, 10.58, etc. ; Phoenix to Peleus, 23.360 ; so, = ὑπασπιστής, Hdt. 5.111.
follower, attendant, B. 17.35, Hdt. 9.50, 51, A. Ch. 769, Supp. 492, 954, S. Ant. 1108 ; ὀ. μήλων a shepherd, Pi. P. 9.64 ; of a female, h.Cer. 440. —Cf. ὀπηδός.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., following, ὀπάονι ῥιπῇ Opp. H. 5.489 ; ὀ. Νύμφην IG 14.1389i52.

awl, Poll. 10.141 (v.l. ὄπεαρ) ; dat. written ὑπέατι in Hdt. 4.70, cf. Hsch. s.v. ὔπεα, and ῥάπτει ὑπητίῳ rupiat, Gloss. :— Dim. ὀπήτιον, τό, Nicoch. 9 (dub., ὄπεαρ Kock), Hp. Epid. 5.45, LXX Ex. 21.6, De. 15.17, Peripl.M.Rubr. 17 ; ὀπητίδιον, Poll. 7.83. (Prob. from same root as ὀπή.)
Schwyzer 664.16 (Orchom. Arc., iv B. C.).
Schwyzer 511.5 ( Lebad., ii B. C.).

definition: ὀπεύει περισκοπεῖ, βλέπει, Hsch. (but cf. ὀπιπεύει Id.). ὀπέων, v. ὀπάων.

children.definition: opening, hole, ὀπὰς γὰρ εἶχεν οὐκ ὀλίγας [τὸ τριβώνιον] Ar. Pl. 715 ; a mouseʼs hole, Sannyr. 8 ; of holes in the earth, Arist. HA 559a4, al. ; in a door, Luc. Asin. 52 ; in a rock, LXX Ex. 33.22 ; of an orifice in the body, Poll. 5.73 ; ἡ ὀπὴ τῶν ὤτων Id. 2.84 (cod. B).

data.quote: ὀπὰς γὰρ εἶχεν οὐκ ὀλίγας [τὸ τριβώνιον]

data.ref: Arist. HA 559a4, al. ; in a door,
LXX Ex. 33.22 ; of an orifice in the body,

children.definition: hole in the roof, serving as a chimney, = κάπνη, καπνοδόκη, Ar. V. 317 (lyr.), 350 ; καὶ διʼ ὀπῆς κἀπὶ τέγους Id. Fr. 11, cf. Xenarch. 4.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: holes in the frieze left to receive the beam-ends, Vitr. 4.2.4 ; later, of windows, lights in doors, αἱ ὀ. τῶν τοίχων Ptol. ap. Simp. in Cael. 710.21 ; σιδήρια ἐξ ὀπῆς IG 4.39 ( Aegina, v B. C.).

children.label: III
children.definition: ὄψομαι, ὄπωπα) sight, τοὶ μήτʼ ἀκουὰν μήτʼ ὀπὰν πεπαμένοι Cerc. 4.23.

data.quote: τοὶ μήτʼ ἀκουὰν μήτʼ ὀπὰν πεπαμένοι

definition: ὅπη, Ep. ὅππη, both in Hom., v. infr. (better written ὅπῃ A.D. Adv. 209.27, Eust. 174.1) ; Dor. ὅπᾳ Leg.Gort. 2.35, etc. ( ὅππᾳ Com.Adesp. p.126 D.), also ὅπη Leg.Gort. 1.42, Berl.Sitzb. 1927.158 ( Cyrene), etc., and ὅπει IG 12(3).248.11 ( Anaphe), etc. ; Aeol. ὄππα ib. 12(2).645a47. Theoc. 28.4 ; but ὄππᾳ prob. in Alc. Supp. 1A.4 ; Ion. ὅκη (better ὅκῃ) Hdt. (v. infr.) :— Adv., relat. and indirect interrog.:

children.label: I
children.definition: by which or what way, in which or what direction or part: sts. nearly = ὅπου, where, Il. 22.321, Od. 9.457 ; εἰρωτᾶν ὅκῃ εἴη v.l. in Hdt. 5.87; ὅππῃ τʼ ἰθύσῃ, τῇ τʼ εἴκουσι στίχες ἀνδρῶν to whatever point . . , at that point . . , Il. 12.48 ; ὅκῃ ἰθύσειε στρατεύεσθαι Hdt. 1.204, cf. 2.146 ; ἀμηχανῶ . . ὅπᾳ τράπωμαι A. Ag. 1532 (lyr.); ἐμβαλοῦ μʼ ὅπῃ θέλεις S. Ph. 481 codd.

children.label: II
children.definition: in what way, how, as, ὅπῃ νόος ἐστὶν ἑκάστου Il. 20.25, cf. Od. 1.347 : more freq. in Trag. and Att., as A. Pr. 586, 906 (both lyr.), Ag. 67 (anap.), al., Th. 1.129, Lys. 14.4, etc. : joined with ὅπως, ὅπῃ ἔχει καὶ ὅπως Pl. R. 612a, cf. Lg. 899a, 899b, etc. ; ὅπῃ ἔτυχεν Arist. GA 743a21 (v.l. ὅπου) ; ὅπῃ ἄν, with subj., ὅπῃ ἂν δοκῇ ἀμφοτέροις Foed. ap. Th. 5.18 ; ὅπᾳ κα δικαιότατα Dor. Foed. ap. eund. 5.79, cf. 8.56 ; ἔστιν ὅπῃ in a way, Pl. Prt. 331d ; ἔσθʼ ὅπῃ . . ; Id. R. 486b ; οὐκ ἔστιν ὅπῃ Aeschin. 3.209 (as v.l.).

data.ref: Od. 1.347 : more freq. in Trag. and

children.label: III
children.definition: ὅπῃ δή Il. 22.185, etc. ; ὅπῃ ποτέ in what possible direction or manner, Pl. Sph. 231c, R. 372e ; ὅπῃ δή ποτε Id. Ep. 338a : c. gen., τοὺς ὅπῃ ποτὲ κατοικοῦντας Εὐρώπης Plu. Per. 17 ; ὅπῃ οὖν or ὁπῃοῦν, in any direction or way whatever, Pl. Prt. 353d, Lg. 950a ; ὁπῃγοῦν Id. Tht. 187d (fort. ὁπῃτιοῦν, cf. Ap. 35b); ὅπῃπερ, ὅπῃπερ ἄν, S. OT 1458 (as v.l.), Pl. Sph. 251a, Ti. 45c, etc.; cf. ὁπωστιοῦν.

definition: ὀπηδέω, Dor. ὀπᾱδέω (v. ὀπηδός), used by Hom. only in 3 sg. pres. ὀπηδεῖ, and impf. ὀπήδει (without augm.): inf. ὀπηδεῖν h.Ap. 530 :—

children.definition: follow, accompany, attend, τινι Il. 2.184, 24.368, Pi. P. 4.287 ; also ἅμα τινί Od. 7.165, Hes. Th. 80, h.Ap. l.c. ; μετά τινι, v. infr. II.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἕπομαι II), ἀνεμώλια γάρ μοι ὀπηδεῖ [τόξα] useless do they go with me, Il. 5.216 ; ἀρετὴν σὴν . . , ἥ τοι ὀπηδεῖ Od. 8.237 ; ἐκ δὲ Διὸς τιμὴ καὶ κῦδος ὀπηδεῖ Il. 17.251, cf. Hes. Op. 142, 313, Thgn. 933, etc. ; μετʼ ἀνδράσι λιμὸς ὀπηδεῖ Hes. Op. 230 ; μετʼ ἴχνια Κύρνος ὀ. Call. Del. 19.— Ep. Verb, rare in Trag., as ὀπαδεῖ A. Fr. 475 ; ὀπαδοῦσʼ prob. in Id. Ag. 426 (lyr.), and once in a late Pap., Sammelb. 4324.11 (Tab. Defix.) : ὀπαδός however is used by Trag.

data.quote: ἐκ δὲ Διὸς τιμὴ καὶ κῦδος ὀπηδεῖ

data.ref: Id. Ag. 426 (lyr.), and once in a late Pap.,

definition: ὀπήδησις, εως, Dor. ὀπάδησις [ᾱ], ιος, ἡ,

children.definition: a following after, attending, pursuit, Crito ap. Stob. 2.8.24.

definition: ὀπηδός, ὁ, ἡ, Dor. ὀπᾱδός, which is also the usual form in Trag. and Prose (v. infr.) (neither form occurs in Hom., though ὀπηδός may be inferred from ὀπηδέω),

children.definition: attendant (cf. the Homeric ὀπάων), S. Tr. 1264 (anap.), E. Alc. 136 ; of body-guards, A. Supp. 985 : c. gen., Πάν, Ματρὸς μεγάλας ὀπαδέ Pi. Fr. 95 ; ἀοιδὰ στεφάνων ἀρετᾶν τε . . ὀ. Id. N. 3.8 ; τέκνων ὀ., of a παιδαγωγός, E. Med. 53 ; πυκνοστίκτων ὀ. ἐλάφων pursuing them, of Artemis, S. OC 1093 (lyr.) ; ἀστέρες . . νυκτὸς ὀ. Theoc. 2.166 ; τὴν Ἑκάτην ὀπαδὸν Ἀρτέμιδος εἶναι Phld. Piet. 91, cf. 33.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., c. dat., following, accompanying, attending, ἐγὼ Μούσῃσιν ὀπηδός h.Merc. 450 ; πτεροῖς ὀπαδοῖς ὕπνου κελεύθοις following the ways of sleep ( ὀπαδοῦσʼ following on wing the ways of sleep, cj. Dobree), A. Ag. 426 (lyr.); σταγόνα σπονδῖτιν, θυέεσσιν ὀπηδόν AP 6.190 ( Gaet.).—Poet. word, used by Pl. Phdr. 252c, Phlb. 63e, and in late Prose, Phld. (v. supr.), Plu. Alc. 23, Jul. Or. 4.157a ( ὀπηδός Ant.Lib. 7.7).
with a hole, δίφρος ὀ., i. e. an obstetric chair, Hp. Mul. 2.114.

definition: ὁπηλίκος, η, ον, relat. and indirect interrog.,

children.definition: however big (or small), how big, Pl. Lg. 737c, Epicur. Ep. 1p.16U. ; exclamatory, how big! Diocl. Fr. 145 ; indef. ὁπηλικοσοῦν, Arist. Cael. 274a14, al., Epicur. Ep. 1p.16U.; ὁπηλικοσδηποτοῦν, Hp. Superf. 27.

definition: ὁπηνίκα, Dor. ὁπᾱνίκα, Adv., relat. and indirect interrog.,

children.definition: at what point of time, at what hour, on what day, more precise than ὁπότε, S. OC 434, Th. 4.125, Theoc. 23.33 ; though sts. it cannot be distd. from ὁπότε, Pl. Alc. 1.105d, Jul. Or. 7.204a, al. ; ὁπότε καὶ ὁ. Pl. Lg. 772d ; ὁ. ἄν at whatever hour or time, S. Ph. 464 ; whenever, PGiss. 53.3 (iv A. D.); simply, when, LXX 4 Ma. 2.16.

data.ref: Theoc. 23.33 ; though sts. it cannot be distd. from

children.definition: πηνίκʼ ἐστὶν ἄρα τῆς ἡμέρας ;— ὁπηνίκα; what time of day is it ?— what time, do you say ? Ar. Av. 1499.
οὐδεὶς οἶδʼ ὁ. ἐστὶ τοὐνιαυτοῦ what time of year, Id. Fr. 569.7.

children.label: II
children.definition: ὁ. ἐφαίνετο ταῦτα πεποιηκώς when once it was seen that . . , D. 18.14, cf. 21.42.
ὅπης, ητος, ὁ, v. ἕρπης II. ὀπητίδιον, ὀπήτιον, v. ὄπεας.
cheese made from milk curdled with fig-juice ( ὀπός), Ar. V. 353 (with a pun on ὀπή) ; in full, τυρὸς ὀπίας E. Cyc. 136, cf. Ath. 14.658c ; v. ὀπίζω.
dreaded, awful, A.R. 2.292 ( Sup.).

definition: ὀπιέλαιος, ὁ, name of a plant, dub. in Inscr.Délos 366 B 19 (iii B. C.).
ὀπίζομαι, Lacon. ὀπίδδομαι IG 5(1).919, Hom. only pres. and impf. 2 and 3 sg. : later also part. (v. infr.), and aor. ὠπίσατο Q.S. 2.618: ( ὄπις):—

children.definition: regard with awe and dread, Διὸς δʼ ὠπίζετο μῆνιν Od. 14.283 ; τῶν ὅ γʼ ὀπίζετο μῆνιν Hes. Sc. 21 ; σὸν θυμὸν ὀπίζομαι Od. 13.148 ; μητρὸς . . ὠπίζετʼ ἐφετμήν Il. 18.216 ; ἐμὲ δʼ οὐδὲν ὀπίζεο νόσφιν ἐόντα 22.332, cf. h.Merc. 382 : abs. in part., feel awe or reverence, Pi. P. 4.86, I. 3.5 ; χάρις ὀπιζομένα filled with reverence, Id. P. 2.17.

data.quote: ἐμὲ δʼ οὐδὲν ὀπίζεο νόσφιν ἐόντα

children.definition: Hom., care for, c. gen. pers., Thgn. 734, 1148, A.R. 2.181, Man. 6.218 :—so later in Act., σώματος . . ὀπίζων App.Anth. 3.143.— Ep. and Lyr. Verb, never in Trag.
extract juice from, θριδακίνην Thphr. HP 7.6.2 ; τὸν καυλὸν καὶ τὰς ῥίζας ib. 9.1.3:— Pass., to be extracted, Gal. 14.62 ; ooze out, D.S. 5.41.

children.label: II
children.definition: ὀ. [γάλα] curdle milk with fig-juice ( ὀπός), Arist. Mete. 384a22 ; cf. ὀπίας.

definition: ὄπιθε and ὄπῐθεν, poet. and late Gr. for ὄπισθε, ὄπισθεν.

children.definition: following a mortal, ὀ. αὔχημα the glory that lives after men, Pi. P. 1.92.
the Opici or Osci (Opsci, Fest. p.218 L.), an ancient people of Southern Italy, Arist. Pol. 1329b19, Str. 5.4.3:—also Ὄπικες, v.l. in Th. 6.2 ; Ὀπικία, ἡ, their country, ib. 4 : hence,

children.label: II
children.definition: Ὀπικός, ή, όν, barbarous, AP 5.131 ( Phld.), cf. Juv. 3.207 : hence ὀπικίζω, = βαρβαρίζω, Lyd. Mens. 1.13, as v.l. for ὀππικίζω ; also ὀφφικίζω ibid. : ὀππικιστής, opicus, Gloss.

data.ref: Lyd. Mens. 1.13, as v.l. for ὀππικίζω ; also

children.definition: made of opium, PTeb. 273.42 (ii/iii A. D.).
Dim. of ὀπός, poppy-juice, opium, Diocl. Fr. 94, Dsc. 3.152, POxy. 1088.6, al. (i A. D.), Plin. HN 20.199, Gal. 13.269, Alex.Trall. 2.1.
peg, pin, Arist. Pr. 915a11 codd. (leg. ἐπίουρος).

definition: ὀπιπᾶ ἐξαπατᾶ, ἀπαταιῶν, Hsch. ; i. e. ὀπιπᾷ· ἐξαπατᾷ, and ὀπῖπα· ἀπατεών (cf. γυναικοπίπης, παρθενοπίπης, παιδοπίπης, πυρροπίπης).

children.definition: starer, gaper, Nonn. D. 37.270, etc. ; also, = παρθενοπίπης, ib. 7.193, Man. 6.584.

data.ref: Nonn. D. 37.270, etc. ; also, = παρθενοπίπης, ib.

children.definition: stare at, with collat. notion of spying, watch, ὀπιπεύσεις δὲ γυναῖκας Od. 19.67 ; or of fear, τί δʼ ὀπιπεύεις πολέμοιο γεφύρας ; Il. 4.371, cf. Hes. Op. 29.

children.label: II
children.definition: watch, spy, οὐ γάρ σʼ ἐθέλω βαλέειν . . λάθρῃ ὀπιπεύσας, ἀλλʼ ἀμφαδόν Il. 7.243 ; εὖ μάλʼ ὀπιπεύοντα . . βάλλειν Hes. Op. 806, cf. Musae. 101, Orph. A. 249 :— Med., to be on the alert, Onos. 10.26.

data.quote: οὐ γάρ σʼ ἐθέλω βαλέειν . . λάθρῃ ὀπιπεύσας, ἀλλʼ ἀμφαδόν

children.label: III
children.definition: seduce, Man. 3.196 :— Pass., δολεροῖσιν -ευθεῖσαι ἔπεσσιν Id. 6.182. (Redupl. from ὀπ-, cf. ὄπ-ωπα.)

definition: ὄπις, ῐδος, ἡ, acc. ὄπιν Il.and Hes. (v. infr.), but in Od. and other Poets also ὄπῐδα ; poet. dat. ὄπῑ, v. II.1 ; acc. ὄπιν by mistake for ὄπα, Maiist. 58 :

children.definition: Hom., ὄπις θεῶν the vengeance or visitation of the gods for transgressing divine laws, θεῶν ὄπιν οὐκ ἀλέγοντες Il. 16.388, Hes. Op. 251 ; οὐδʼ ὄπιδα τρομέουσι θεῶν Od. 20.215 ; οὐδὲ θεῶν ὄπιν αἰδέσατʼ οὐδὲ τράπεζαν 21.28 ; θ. ὄπιν εἰδότες Hes. Op. 187 ; ὄπιν ἀθανάτων πεφυλαγμένος εἶναι ib. 706, cf. Theoc. 25.4: also without θεῶν, divine vengeance, οὐκ ὄπιδα φρονέοντες ἐνὶ φρεσέν Od. 14.82 ; τοῖς ὄπιδος . . δέος ἐν φρεσὶ πίπτει ib. 88 ; of the avenging goddesses, κακὴν ὄπιν ἀποδοῦναι Hes. Th. 222.

data.quote: οὐδὲ θεῶν ὄπιν αἰδέσατʼ οὐδὲ τράπεζαν

children.definition: the care or favour of the gods, θεῶν ὄπιν αἰτεῖν Pi. P. 8.71.

the awful regard which men pay to the gods, religious awe, veneration, obedience, οὔτε δαιμόνων οὔτε θεῶν ὄπιν ἔχοντας paying no regard to . . (cf. ὀπίζομαι), Hdt. 9.76, cf. 8.143 ; so also ὄπι (v.l. ὄπιν) δίκαιον ξένων strict in his reverence towards strangers, i. e. in the duties of hospitality (al. ξένον), Pi. O. 2.6 ; αἰδεσθεὶς ὄπιδα . . πολιοῖο γενείου maintaining due reverence for the hoary beard, Mosch. 4.117.
pious care or zeal, Pi. I. 5(4).58. (Hence ὀπίζομαι, ὀπιδνός.)
a going backwards, S. Fr. 406: metaph. in Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.202, cf. Ael.Dion. Fr. 415.

definition: ὄπισθα, Aeol. and Dor. for ὄπισθε, A.D. Adv. 153.18.

children.definition: with the arms behind the back, PMag.Par. 1.301 ( -αγγωνα Pap.), Tz.ad Lyc. 704, Gloss.
Hsch.

definition: ὄπισθεν, in Ion. ( Hdt. 4.72, al., SIG 46.65 ( Halic., v B. C.), etc.) and late Att. ( Luc. Am. 16, etc.) ὄπισθε before a conson., as also in Poets, E. Cyc. 545, IT 1333 : poet. also ὄπῐθεν Il. 6.181, al., Pi. O. 10(11).35, A. Pers. 1001 (lyr.) :— Adv. :

children.label: I
children.definition: behind, at the back, opp. πρόσθε, Il. 5.595 ; πρόσθε λέων ὄπιθεν δὲ δράκων μέσση δὲ χίμαιρα 6.181 ; ὄπισθεν καταλιπεῖν Od. 10.209 ; μένειν Il. 9.332, etc. ; πέμψει οὖρον ὄ. Od. 15.34 ; ὄπιθεν κομόωντες with long back-hair, Il. 2.542 ; ὄπιθεν κομόωσαι ἔθειραι IG 12(9).1179.9 ( Euboea) ; ὄ. ἕπεσθαι, ἀκολουθεῖν, A. l.c., etc. ; οἱ ὄπιθεν those who are left behind, e.g. at home, Od. 11.66 ; but also, those who are in the rear, X. Cyr. 2.2.8 ; εἰ τοὺς ὄ. ἐς τὸ πρόσθεν ἄξομεν shall bring the rear ranks to the front (metaph.), S. Aj. 1249 ; αἱ ὄ. ἁψῖδες the hinder fellies, Hdt. 4.72 ; τὰ ὄ. the hinder parts, rear, back, Il. 11.613 ; οἱ ὄ. ἁρμοί IG 1(2).372.117 ; εἰς τοὔπισθεν back, backwards, E. Ph. 1410, Pl. Sph. 261b, etc. ; εἰς τ. τοξεύειν, i.e. ‘versis sagittis’, like the Parthians, X. An. 3.3.10 : opp. ἐκ τοὔπισθεν Ar. Ec. 482, cf. Th. 7.79, X. An. 4.1.6 ; ἐν τῷ ὄ. Pl. R. 614c, X. Cyn. 9.8, etc. ; ὄ. ποιήσασθαι τὸν ποταμόν place the river in his rear, Id. An. 1.10.9.

data.quote: πρόσθε λέων ὄπιθεν δὲ δράκων μέσση δὲ χίμαιρα

children.definition: behind, στῆ δʼ ὄπιθεν δίφροιο Il. 17.468 ; ὄπισθε μάχης 13.536 ; ὄπισθε τῆς θύρης Hdt. 1.9 ; ἔμπροσθέ τε Θερμοπυλέων καὶ ὄ. Id. 7.176 ; ὄ. ἐμοῦ . . εἰσῄει Pl. Smp. 175a, etc. : sts. after its case, δίφρου ὄπισθεν Il. 24.15 ; ἴμεν φάμας ὄπισθεν follow the voice, Pi. O. 6.63 ; γνώμης πατρῴας πάντʼ ὄ. ἑστάναι S. Ant. 640 ; also τούτοισι δʼ ὄ. ἴτω Cratin. 30 ; πνοιαῖς ὄπιθεν Βορέα Pi. O. 3.31 (s. v.l.).

children.label: II
children.definition: after, in future, hereafter, Il. 4.362, Od. 2.270, 18.168, etc. ; either of a thing absolutely future, or of one which follows something else, opp. αὐτίκα, Il. 9.519 ; ὄπιθεν οὐ πολλόν Pi. O. 10(11).35 ; πολλοῖς μησὶν ὄ. Theoc. Ep. 22.8 ; cf. ὀπίσω II.1.

data.ref: 18.168, etc. ; either of a thing absolutely future, or of one which follows something else, opp.

children.definition: ἐν τοῖσι ὄ. λόγοισι in the books yet to come, in the following books, Hdt. 5.22, 7.213 ; cf. ὀπίσω II.2 : but, in Gramm., of what has gone before, Sch. Od. 3.366, Hsch. s.v. Ἴωνες, Sch. Ar. Ra. 1488 ; ὁ ὄπιθεν χρόνος the earlier time, PMasp. 158.22 (vi A. D.) :—for Comp. ὀπίστερος, Sup. ὀπίστατος, v. sub vocc. (Prob. from *ὄπις ‘back’, contained in ἀνόπιν, κατόπιν, μετόπιν, ὀπίσω.)

data.ref: 7.213 ; cf. ὀπίσω II.2 : but, in Gramm., of what has gone before, Sch.

postilena, Gloss.

definition: ὀπισθίδιος, α, ον, = sq., Sophr. 50, Call. Dian. 151, AP 9.482 ( Agath.).

children.definition: hinder, belonging to the hinder part, IG 1(2).369.12 ; τὰ ὀ. σκέλεα the hind-legs. Hdt. 3.103, X. Eq. 11.2 : sg., Arist. HA 500b30 ; πόδες Semon. 28, Philem. 145 ; τένων ὁ ὀ. the tendo Achillis, Hp. Fract. 11 ; so ὀπίσθια (sc. μόρια) Arist. GA 722b29 ; τὸ ὀ. the hinder part, opp. τὸ πρόσθιον, Id. IA 706b1 ; also of the cheek of animals, Id. HA 492b23 : Subst. fem. ὀπισθία, hinder part, Epich. 90 ; of stars, following in the daily movement, Cleom. 1.1. Adv. -ίως LXX 1 Ki. 4.18.
walking backwards, AP 6.196 ( Stat. Flacc.).

Aët. 7.115 : as Adj., ἄδηκτον μὲν ὀ. δέ ib. 109.
mounting, sens. obsc., AP 12.33 ( Mel.).

shoe, Poll. 7.91, Hsch.
backward curvature of the spine, Gal. 18(1).493.

definition: ὀπισθόπους, ὁ, ἡ, πουν, τό, gen. ποδος,
