children.label: I
children.definition: backwards, opp. to πρόσω, Il. 12.272 ; to προπρηνές, 3.218 ; ἀνεχάζετο τυτθὸν ὀπίσσω 5.443 ; ἀ. πολλὸν ὀ. 16.710 ; πάλιν εἶσιν ὀπίσσω Od. 11.149 : in Prose also, τὸ ὀπίσω, contr. τοὐπίσω, τὸ ὀ. φεύγειν Hdt. 1.207, cf. 8.108 ; ἄναγε εἰς τοὐπίσω Pl. R. 528a, cf. Th. 4.4, Arist. Fr. 106, etc.; [γνάμ]φθη δʼ ὀπίσσω [φάσγα]νον B. 12.53 ; τὰ ὀ. the hinder parts, LXX Jl. 2.20 ; τοῦ προπύλου τὸ ὀ. μέρος SIG 756.17 ( Athens, i B. C.); τὴν ὀ. τοῦ προπύλου στέγην ib. 12 ; ἐκ τοῦ ὀ. on the back (of the papyrus), BGU 1002.16 (i B. C.); τἀπίλοιπα ὀ. PTeb. 58.37 (ii B. C.).

back, back again, of movement, ἀπήνυσαν οἴκαδʼ ὀπίσσω Od. 7.326 ; ὀπίσω πάλιν οἴκαδε Pi. N. 3.62 ; ἂψ ὀ. Theoc. 25.74; ἀπίκοντο ὀ. Hdt. 1.62 ; ὀ. πορευόμενοι ib. 75 ; ὀ. ἀναπλῶσαι ib. 78 ; ἐν τῇ ὀ. κομιδῇ on his way back, Id. 8.120, cf. 1.111, etc.
back again, again, of action that reverses an action or occurrence, ἀνακτᾶσθαι ὀ. τὴν τυραννίδα ib. 61, cf. 68, 2.14 ; ἀποδόντες ὀ. Id. 5.92.γʹ; σφραγίζεις λύεις τʼ ὀπίσω E. IA 38 (anap.).
δεῦτε ὀ. μου come after me, follow me, Ev.Matt. 4.19.

children.label: II
children.definition: hereafter, since the future is unseen and was therefore regarded as behind us, whereas the past is known and therefore before our eyes, ἡμῖν τεκέεσσί τʼ ὀπίσσω πῆμα λίποιτο Il. 3.160 ; Τρῳαὶ δέ μʼ ὀπίσσω πᾶσαι μωμήσονται ib. 411, cf. Hes. Op. 741, Th. 488 ; ἔς περ ὀπίσσω Od. 20.199 ( εἰσοπίσω S. Ph. 1104 (lyr.)) ; opp. to νῦν, τούτῳ δʼ οὔτʼ ἂρ νῦν φρένες ἔμπεδοι [εἰσίν], οὔτʼ ἄρʼ ὀπίσσω ἔσσονται Il. 6.352 ; to προπάροιθε, σεῖο δʼ, Ἀχιλλεῦ, οὔ τις ἀνὴρ προπάροιθε [ἦν] μακάρτατος, οὔτʼ ἄρʼ ὀπίσσω [ἔσσεται] Od. 11.483 ; where ὀπίσσω and πρόσσω are opposed, πρόσσω must be the past and ὀπίσσω the future, οἶδε νοῆσαι ἅμα πρόσσω καὶ ὀπίσσω Il. 1.343 ; ἅμα πρόσσω καὶ ὀ. λεύσσει 3.109 ; ὅρα πρόσσω καὶ ὀ. 18.250, Od. 24.452 ; so ὅσα τʼ ἦν ὅσα τʼ ἔσθʼ ὅσα τʼ ἔσται ὀπίσσω Emp. 21.9 (ap. Arist. Metaph. 1000a30); οὔτʼ ἐνθάδʼ ὁρῶν οὔτʼ ὀπίσω neither present nor future, S. OT 488 (lyr.) ; τοὐπίσω σκοπεῖν E. Fr. 49 ; θνητὸς πεφυκὼς τοὐπίσω πειρῶ βλέπειν Isid.Trag. 2 ; cf. ὄπισθεν II.1.

data.quote: ἡμῖν τεκέεσσί τʼ ὀπίσσω πῆμα λίποιτο
νῦν, τούτῳ δʼ οὔτʼ ἂρ νῦν φρένες ἔμπεδοι [εἰσίν], οὔτʼ ἄρʼ ὀπίσσω ἔσσονται
προπάροιθε, σεῖο δʼ, Ἀχιλλεῦ, οὔ τις ἀνὴρ προπάροιθε [ἦν] μακάρτατος, οὔτʼ ἄρʼ ὀπίσσω [ἔσσεται]
οἶδε νοῆσαι ἅμα πρόσσω καὶ ὀπίσσω
ὅσα τʼ ἦν ὅσα τʼ ἔσθʼ ὅσα τʼ ἔσται ὀπίσσω

children.definition: ἐν τοῖσι ὀ. λόγοις in the books yet to come, in the following books, Hdt. 1.75 ; cf. ὄπισθεν II.2.

definition: ὀπισώτατος, η, ον, Sup. Adj. from ὀπίσω,

children.definition: hindmost, Sammelb. 4308.5 (iii B. C.).
tuberous root of Bunium ferulaceum, earth-nut, Thphr. HP 7.13.9.

definition: ὁπλάριον [ᾰ], τό, Dim. of ὅπλον, IG ΙΙ(2).190 A 23 ( Delos, iii B. C.), Supp.Epigr. 4.447.44 ( Didyma, ii B. C.), Plu. Flam. 17, IGRom. 4.1318 (Tamasus, Lydia).

children.definition: make ready, ἄμαξαν ὥπλεον Od. 6.73.

hoof, in Hom. always the solid hoof of the horse, Il. 11.536, 20.501, cf. Ar. Eq. 605, Porph. Abst. 3.9 : after Hom., like χηλή, the cloven hoof of horned cattle, h.Merc. 77, Hes. Op. 489, Pi. P. 4.226, Hdt. 2.71, Pl. R. 586b, Arist. HA 575b8 ; τοῦ βοὸς ὁπλά SIG 1026.19 ( Cos, iv/iii B. C.) ; of swine, Semon. 28, Ar. Ach. 740 ; of sheep, Arist. Fr. 253 :—distd. from χηλή, Gal. UP 3.4.
hooved, Poeta ap. D.Chr. 32.85.
Hdt. 5.66, E. Ion 1580, CIG 3665 ii 32 ( Cyzicus); Ὁπλήθων (gen. pl.) SIG 57.2 ( Milet., v B. C.); φυλὴ Ὁπλείτων Dacia1.273 ( Tomi); cf. Αἰγικορεῖς.

definition: ὀπλίας Λοκροὶ τοὺς τόπους ἐν οἷς συνελαύνοντες ἀριθμοῦσι τὰ πρόβατα καὶ τὰ βοσκήματα, Hsch.

ὁπλίζω, aor. ὥπλισα, Ep. ὥπλισσα (v. infr.): pf. ὥπλικα ( παρ-) D.S. 4.10 : plpf. ὡπλίκει D.C. 78.6:— Med., fut. -ίσομαι ( ἐφ-) AP 9.39 ( Music.), -ιοῦμαι Sch. Il. 13.20 : aor. ὡπλισάμην, Ep. ὁπλίσσατο (v.l. ὡπλ-) Od. 2.20:— Pass., aor. ὡπλίσθην Hdt. 2.152, etc., Ep. 3 pl. ὅπλισθεν Od. 23.143: pf. ὥπλισμαι E. Ba. 733, etc.— Hom. usu.uses the augm., but codd. have ὁπλισάμεσθα Od. 4.429, ὅπλισθεν 23.143 (v.l. ὥ-): ( ὅπλον, cf. ὁπλέω, ὅπλομαι):—

children.definition: make or get ready, in Hom. of meats and drink, ἐπεί ῥʼ ὥπλισσε κυκειῶ Il. 11.641 ; ὅπλισσόν τʼ ἤϊα Od. 2.289 ; δαῖθʼ ὁ. E. Ion 852:—Med, δόρπον or δεῖπνον ὁπλίζεσθαι make oneself a meal ready, Od. 2.20, 16.453, Il. 11.86 ; ὡπλίσσατο λύχνον Emp. 84.1 ; ὁ. θυσίαν θεοῖς cause it to be prepared, E. Ion 1124.

get ready, harness, equip, αὐτὰρ ὅ γʼ υἷας ἄμαξαν . . ὁπλίσαι ἠνώγει Il. 24.190 (so in Med., prepare or get ready for oneself, ἐΰτριχας ὡπλίσαθʼ ἵππους 23.301) ; ὥπλιζον ἵππους προμετωτιδίοις X. Cyr. 6.4.1 :— Pass., of ships, νῆες . . ὁπλίζονται Od. 17.288 ; of any implements, λαμπὰς διὰ χερῶν ὡπλισμένη ready for use, A. Th. 433 ; θώρακα . . περιβόλοις ὡπλισμένον furnished with, E. Ion 993.

data.quote: αὐτὰρ ὅ γʼ υἷας ἄμαξαν . . ὁπλίσαι ἠνώγει

children.definition: equip, arm, Hdt. 1.127, E. Ion 980, etc.; also, train, exercise soldiers, Hdt. 6.12 : in Att. Prose, arm or equip as ὁπλῖται, ὁπλίζειν τὸν δῆμον πρότερον ψιλὸν ὄντα Th. 3.27, cf. 6.100 ( Pass.), Lys. 31.15, etc.:— Med. and Pass., make oneself ready, prepare or equip oneself, get ready, ἀλλʼ ὅ γʼ ἄρʼ ἔξω ἰὼν ὡπλίζετο Od. 14.526 ; ὅπλισθεν (for ὡπλίσθησαν) δὲ γυναῖκες the women got ready [for dancing], 23.143 ; Τρῶες . . ἀνὰ πτόλιν ὡπλίζοντο were arming, Il. 8.55 ; ἀλλʼ ὁπλιζώμεθα θᾶσσον Od. 24.495 ; χαλκῷ ὁπλισθέντας Hdt. 2.152 ; κατάπερ Κόλχοι ὡπλισμένοι Id. 7.79 ; χρωμένους τῷ πλήθει ὡπλισμένῳ Pl. R. 551e ; ὁπλίζου, καρδία E. Med. 1242 : c. inf., τοὶ δʼ ὡπλίζοντο . . νέκυάς τʼ ἀγέμεν, ἕτεροι δὲ μεθʼ ὕλην Il. 7.417 ; βουσφαγεῖν ὡπλίζετο E. El. 627:—in Med., also c. acc., ὁπλίζεσθαι χέρα arm oneʼs hand, Id. Or. 926 (in Act., Id. Alc. 35 (anap.)); ὁπλίζεσθαι θράσος arm oneself with boldness, S. El. 996, cf. AP 5.92, 1 Ep.Pet. 4.1: freq. c. dat. instrum., ὁπλιζώμεσθα φασγάνῳ χέρας E. Or. 1223, cf. Ph. 267 ; θύρσοις διὰ χερῶν ὡπλισμέναι Id. Ba. 733.

data.quote: ὁπλῖται, ὁπλίζειν τὸν δῆμον πρότερον ψιλὸν ὄντα
ἀλλʼ ὅ γʼ ἄρʼ ἔξω ἰὼν ὡπλίζετο
τοὶ δʼ ὡπλίζοντο . . νέκυάς τʼ ἀγέμεν, ἕτεροι δὲ μεθʼ ὕλην

children.definition: pertaining to arms, Vett.Val. 17.3.
armoury, cj. Lobeck for ὀπτασία in AP 6.210 ( Philet.; fort. ὁπλασία, cf. ἐξοπλασία).
preparing for war, equipment, accoutrement, arming, ὁπλίσεις ἀνδρῶν Ar. Ra. 1036 ; εὐσταλεῖς τῇ ὁ. Th. 3.22 ; περὶ ὅπλισιν [τοῦ δήμου] Arist. Pol. 1297a16.
armour, τῆς ὁ. σχέσις Pl. Ti. 24b, cf. Ephor. 54J.
army, armament, E. IA 253 (lyr., pl.).

children.label: II
children.definition: weapon, ὅ . . . δεινῆς κορύνης Id. Supp. 714 : in pl., Pl. Plt. 279d.

children.label: III
children.definition: tackle in ships, Hsch.
one must arm, X. Eq.Mag. 1.6.
warrior-dress, AP 7.230 ( Eryc.): as Subst., ὁπλιστής warrior, Vett.Val. 3.8 ; armator, Gloss.
carrying the heavy-armed, νῆες ὁ. troop-ships, transports, Th. 6.25, 31, 8.30.
the service of the heavy-armed, warfare, Pl. Lg. 706c.
serve as a man-at-arms, Th. 6.91, 8.73, Lys. 20.25, X. An. 5.8.5 ; οἱ ὁπλιτεύοντες men now serving, opp. οἱ ὡπλιτευκότες, Arist. Pol. 1297b13, cf. 1265b28.

heavy-armed, armed, ὁ. δρόμοι races of men in armour, opp. the naked race (v. στάδιον II), Pi. I. 1.23 ; called ὁ ὁ. or simply ὁπλίτης ( Dor., Arc. -τας) in IG 5(1).1120 ( Geronthrae, v B. C.), 5(2).550.26 ( Lycaeum, iv B. C.), etc. (= τοῦ ὅπλου δρόμος, Paus. 6.13.1), cf. ὁπλιτοδρομέω; ἀνὴρ ὁ. A. Th. 717, E. Supp. 585, etc.; ὁ. στρατός an armed host, Id. Heracl. 800 ; ὁ. κόσμος warrior-dress, armour, ib. 699.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., ὁπλίτης, ὁ, heavy-armed foot-soldier, man-at-arms, who carried a pike (δόρυ) and a large shield (ὅπλον), Ἀθηναίων οἱ στρατηγοὶ καὶ . . οἱ ὁ. IG 1(2).116.25 ; ὁπλῖται, opp. ψιλοί, Hdt. 9.30, Th. 1.106 ; opp. γυμνῆτες, Hdt. 9.63 ; opp. ἱππεῖς, Pl. R. 552a ; opp. τοξόται, Id. Criti. 119b ; to be a ὁπλίτης implied the possession of full civic rights, hence οἱ ὁ., opp. οἱ βάναυσοι, Arist. Pol. 1326a23 ; and, in oligarchical states, opp. ὁ δῆμος, ib. 1305b33.

data.quote: Ἀθηναίων οἱ στρατηγοὶ καὶ . . οἱ ὁ.

data.ref: Arist. Pol. 1326a23 ; and, in oligarchical states, opp.

children.definition: of or for a man-at-arms, μάχη Pl. R. 374d ; αἱ ὁ. τάξεις X. HG 3.4.16 ; ὅπλα ib. 4.2.7.
ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) the art of using heavy arms, the soldier’s art, Pl. R. 333d ; so τὸ -κόν Id. La. 182d ; also τὰ -κὰ ἐπιτηδεύειν profess the art of arms, ib. 183c.

children.label: II
children.definition: heavy-armed, τὸ -κόν the soldiery, = οἱ ὁπλῖται, opp. τὸ ἄνοπλον, Arist. Pol. 1289b32, cf. Th. 5.6, X. An. 7.6.26 ; ἡ ὁ. δύναμις Arist. Pol. 1321a18.
ὁπλίτης, χεῖρες Poll. 3.150.
run a race in armour, Paus. 1.23.11.
running a race in armour, IG 1(2).531 (dub.), CIG 2758iv2, al. ( Aphrodisias), Poll. 3.151, Sch. Pi. P. 10.22, Sch. Ar. Ach. 213.
heavy-armed warrior, A. Fr.Eleg. 5.
one who teaches the use of arms, Vett.Val. 74.13, Gloss.
arm, ἄνδρας LXX 1 Ma. 14.32.
armidator, Gloss.
rattling with armour, Orph. H. 65.3, as Piers.for δολόδουπος.
armoury, SIG 253 T 9 ( Delph., iv B. C.), LXX 2 Ch. 32.27, D.S. 17.79, Str. 4.1.5, J. BJ 2.4.1 (pl.), Plu. Symp. 2.159e (pl.), Sull. 14, Ael. VH 6.12.
shield-case. OGI 339.80 ( Sestos, ii B. C., pl.).
armilustrium, Gloss.

definition: ὁπλοκαθαρσία, ἡ, and ὁπλό-ιον (sc. ἱερόν), τό, = foreg. [ὁπλοκαθαρμός], Gloss.

children.definition: hoof-resounding, restored by Seidler in A. Th. 83 (lyr.).
collect arms from, τινας LXX 2 Ma. 8.27:— Pass., to be disarmed, ὑπό τινος Ph. 2.530.
prepare, δεῖπνον ἄνωχθι ὅπλεσθαι Il. 19.172, 23.159 ; cf. ὁπλίζω I, ὁπλέω. ( ὁπλεῖσθαι shd. perh. be restored.)
to be mad on war, AP 9.320 ( Leon.); περί τινος show war-madness in fighting for . . , Posidon. 48 J.
serve as a man-at-arms: practise the use of arms, Isoc. 15.252, Arist. Ath. 42.3, Plu. Cam. 37, Gal. 6.42, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: to be a drill-sergeant ( ὁπλομάχοςII), Abh.Berl.Akad. 1925(5).7 ( Cyrene), IG 2(2).957.47 (ii B. C.), 3.1085 (i A. D.).
Pl. Euthd. 299c.
of or for the use of arms: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) the art of using arms, S.E. M. 11.197.

fighting with heavy arms, the art of using them, Pl. Lg. 813e, 833e, X. An. 2.1.7, Ephor. 54J.; as a form of athletic exercise, SIG 1061.11 (ii B. C.), OGI 339.81 ( Sestos, ii B. C.), Antyll. ap. Orib. 6.36.

data.ref: Ephor. 54J.; as a form of athletic exercise,

children.definition: of or for ὁπλομαχία, ἀγῶνες D.C. 59.14 ; κινήσεις Gal. 6.153 ; -κός, ὁ, ibid. ; -κόν, τό, title of work by Democr., Fr. 280.
fighting in heavy arms, X. Lac. 11.8, Plb. 2.65.11, LXX Is. 13.5 ; -χοι ἄνδρες Alciphr. 1.11.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. ὁ., ὁ, one who teaches the use of arms, drill-sergeant, opp. a mere fencing-master, Thphr. Char. 5.10, Teles p.50 H., PCair.Zen. 298 (iii B. C.), SIG 697 E 11 ( Delph., ii B. C.).
armatura, Lyd. Mag. 1.46.
tool, implement, mostly in pl., like ἔντεα, τεύχεα: (prob. from ἕπω A):

children.label: I
children.definition: tackle, tackling, Hom. (only in Od.), 2.390, al., Hes. Op. 627 ; esp. ropes, halyards, etc., δησάμενοι δʼ ἄρα ὅπλα Od. 2.430, etc.; in which sense Hom. twice uses the sg., rope, 14.346, 21.390: generally, any ropes, Hdt. 7.25, 9.115, Hp. Art. 78.

children.label: II
children.definition: tools, strictly so called, in Hom. esp. of smiths’ tools, Il. 18.409, 412 ; in full, ὅπλα χαλκήϊα Od. 3.433 : in sg., ὅπλον ἀρούρης sickle, AP 6.95 ( Antiphil.) ; ὅπλον γεροντικόν staff, Call. Epigr. 1.7 ; δείπνων ὅπλον ἑτοιμότατον, of the wine-flask, AP 6.248 ( Marc. Arg.).

children.label: III
children.definition: implements of war, arms and armour, Hom. (only in Il.), αὐτὰρ ἐπεὶ πάνθʼ ὅπλα κάμε, of the arms of Achilles, 18.614, cf. 19.21 ; ὅπλοισιν ἔνι δεινοῖσιν ἐδύτην 10.254, 272 ; so in Pi. N. 8.27, IG 1(2).1.9, E. Hec. 14, etc.: rarely in sg., weapon, οὐδέ τι ἀρήϊον ὅπλον ἐκτέαται Hdt. 4.23, cf. 174, E. HF 161, 570, 942, Pl. R. 474a, X. Cyr. 7.4.15 ; ποτὶ πονηρὸν οὐκ ἄχρηστον ὅπλον ἁ πονηρία [ Epich.] 275 ; piece of armour, D.S. 3.49.

data.ref: E. Hec. 14, etc.: rarely in sg.,

children.definition: the large shield, from which the men-at-arms took their name of ὁπλῖται ( εἰκόνα γραπτὴν ἐν ὅπλῳ IG 2(2).1012.18 (ii B. C.), cf. IGRom. 4.1302.35 ( Cyme, i B. C. /i A. D.), Th. 7.75, D.S. 15.44, 17.18); ὅπλον στύππινον IG ΙΙ(2).203 B 99 ( Delos, iii B. C.) : metaph., τῆς πενίας ὅπλον ἡ παρρησία Nicostr.Com. 29; ὅ. μέγιστον . . ἁρετὴ βροτοῖς Men. Mon. 433, cf. 619.
heavy arms, Hdt. 9.53 ; ὅπλων ἐπιστάτης, = ὁπλίτης, opp. κώπης ἄναξ, A. Pers. 379 ; ὁ πόλεμος οὐχ ὅπλων τὸ πλέον ἀλλὰ δαπάνης Th. 1.83 ; ὅπλα παραδοῦναι Id. 4.69 ; ὅπλα ἀποβάλλειν Ar. V. 27, etc.

data.quote: ὁ πόλεμος οὐχ ὅπλων τὸ πλέον ἀλλὰ δαπάνης

children.definition: ὅπλα, = ὁπλῖται, men-at-arms, πολλῶν μεθʼ ὅπλων S. Ant. 115 (lyr.): and freq. in Prose, ἐξέτασιν ὅπλων ποιεῖσθαι to have a muster of the men-at-arms, Th. 4.74, etc.; ὁ ἐπὶ τῶν ὅπλων στρατηγός, opp. ὁ ἐπὶ τῆς διοικήσεως, Decr. ap. D. 18.38, Decr.ib. 115 ; χειροτονηθεὶς ἐπὶ τὰ ὅ. πρῶτος . . στρατηγός IG 2(2).682.44 (iii B. C.); στρατηγεῖν ἐπὶ τὰ ὅ. SIG 697 E ( Delph., ii B. C.), etc.

data.quote: χειροτονηθεὶς ἐπὶ τὰ ὅ. πρῶτος . . στρατηγός

children.definition: τὰ ὅ. the place of arms, camp, ἦλθεν εἰς τὰ ὅ. Lys. 13.12, cf. X. Cyr. 7.2.5, etc.; ἐκ τῶν ὅ. προϊέναι Th. 1.111, cf. 3.1.

ἐνέδυνον (v.l. ἐνέδυντο) τὰ ὅ. Hdt. 7.218, etc.; ἐν ὅπλοισι εἶναι or γενέσθαι to be in arms, under arms, Id. 1.13, cf. E. Ba. 303, Th. 6.56 ; ἐν ὄπλοισι [ἰππομ]άχεντας Sapph. Supp. 5.19 ; ἐν ὅπλοις μάχεσθαι Pl. Grg. 456d ; ἡ ἐν τοῖς ὅπλοις μάχη Id. Lg. 833e ; ποιῆσαι ἐξέτασιν ἐν ὅπλοις Decr. ap. Arist. Ath. 31.2 ; εἰς τὰ ὅ. παραγγέλλειν X. An. 1.5.13 ; ἐφʼ ὅπλοις or παρʼ ὅπλοις ἧσθαι, E. Supp. 674, 357 ; μένειν ἐπὶ τοῖς ὅπλοις X. Cyr. 7.2.8 ; for ὅπλα ῥίπτειν, ἀφιέναι, κατατίθεσθαι, v. sub vocc. ; for ὅπλα τίθεσθαι, v. τίθημι.

children.label: IV
children.definition: the arms possessed by animals for self-defence, [τὸν ἄνθρωπον] οὐκ ἔχοντα ὅπλον πρὸς τὴν ἀλκήν Arist. PA 687a25, cf. b4, al.

data.quote: [τὸν ἄνθρωπον] οὐκ ἔχοντα ὅπλον πρὸς τὴν ἀλκήν

children.label: V
children.definition: membrum virile, Nic. Fr. 74.30, APl. 16.242 ( Eryc.), Hsch.

children.label: VI
children.definition: a gymnastic exercise, the last which came on in the games, Artem. 1.63.
juggler with weapons, Vett.Val. 74.13 ; = armilusor, ventilator, Gloss. (written -πεκτής and -πετής).
insigniarius, armiger, Gloss.
make or use as a weapon, LXX Wi. 5.17.

children.label: II
children.definition: make weapons, Str. 15.3.18.
Phlp. in APr. 8.2.
making of arms, D.S. 14.43, Poll. 7.154 ; name of the eighteenth book of the Iliad, Str. 1.1.7.

data.ref: Poll. 7.154 ; name of the eighteenth book of the Iliad,

children.definition: the art of forging arms, Pl. Plt. 280d, Poll. 7.209 ; in both places with v.l. -ποιητική.

data.ref: Poll. 7.209 ; in both places with v.l. -ποιητική.

children.definition: armourer, D.S. 14.43, J. AJ 6.3.5, Poll. 7.154, prob. in JRS 14.35 ( Iconium).
armed dancer, Ptol. Tetr. 180.
inspection of arms : review, Ph. 2.130.
Arist. PA 673a19, IG 5 (2).344.18 (Orchom. Arc., iii B. C.); Ὁπλοσμία, ἡ, of Hera in Peloponnesus, Lyc. 614 ; prob. armed, in armour: Ὁπλοδμία, name of a phyle at Mantinea, IG 5(2).271.10 (iv B. C.).

definition: ὁπλότερος, α, ον, Comp. without any Posit. in use, Ep. for νεώτερος,

children.definition: the younger, always of persons, Il. 4.325, Od. 21.370, B. 10.71 ; ὁπλότερος γενεῇ younger by birth, Il. 2.707, Od. 19.184 : fem. gen. pl. ὁπλοτεράων Il. 14.267, 275: Sup., youngest, ὁπλότατος γενεῆφιν 9.58 ; ὁ. θυγάτηρ Od. 7.58, cf. 11.283, Hes. Th. 946, Pi. I. 6(5).6, al. : Ar. Pax 1270- 1 uses the Comp. in mock heroic lines.—The orig. sense was perh. capable of bearing arms; and so ὁπλότεροι would be the serviceable men, hence, the young men, opp. the old men and children, Il. 3.108, Hom. Epigr. 4.5 ; then simply, younger or youngest, hence of women, Νέστορος ὁπλοτάτη θυγάτηρ Od. 3.465, etc. ; then, as the youngest are the last born, ἄνδρες ὁπλότεροι also means the latter generations, men of later days, Theoc. 16.46 ; ὁπλοτέρου τʼ Ἀχιλῆος ἀκούομεν Εὐρυλόχοιο Euph. 80.
Ptol. Tetr. 180.
nibbling at arms or shields, μύες Eust. 34.44.
bear arms, be armed, X. Cyr. 4.3.18, AP 9.320 ( Leon.), BCH 32.429 ( Delos, ii B. C.), Jahresh. 26 Beibl. 61 ( Ephesus, iv/vii A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be guarded, c. dat., μυριάσι πεζῶν Plu. Aem. 27.
bearing arms: armed man, warrior, soldier, E. Ph. 789, IA 190 (both lyr.), X. Cyr. 5.4.27, LXX 2 Ch. 14.8(7).

children.label: II
children.definition: X. Hier. 2.8, J. AJ 6.6.2, al.
IG 12(8).178 ( Samothrace).

children.label: III
children.definition: Ἀρχ.Ἐφ. 1911.126 (Thessaly ; of Ares, Rev.Bibl. 32.118 ( Palestine).
armoury, arsenal, Str. 15.1.52.
one who has the charge of arms, Ath. 12.538b ; = custos armorum, IGRom. 4.733,736 ( Eumenia) ; a name of Heracles at Smyrna, CIG 3162, BMus.Cat.Coins Ionia pp. 259, 260.
delighting in arms, Orph. H. 32.6.
hard-shelled tortoise, Tz. H. 11.609.
purchase arms, SIG 363.11 ( Ephesus, iii B. C.).
of the balsam-tree, ξύλα κυπαρίσσινα ἢ ὀ. PMag.Leid.W. 9.21.

the juice of the balsam-tree, balsam of Mecca, Thphr. HP 4.4.14, CP 6.18.2, J. AJ 14.4.1, Gal. 12.554, Edict.Diocl. in BCH 22.403 (written ὀποπ-, as also in PMed.Strassb. p.4 K., Gloss.); the tree itself, Balsamodendron Opobalsamum, J. AJ 8.6.6, al.

definition: ὁποδαπός, ή, όν, correlative to ποδαπός in indirect questions,

children.definition: of what country, what countryman, Hdt. 5.13, 9.16 (v.l.), Pl. Phdr. 275c ; of things, δέκʼ ὀβολῶν, οὐχὶ προσθεὶς ὁποδαπῶν Diph. 66.10.

like ὀπός I.1, milky, Hp. Epid. 7.25 ; ὀπώδης, full of ὀπός I.1, σῦκα Id. Vict. 2.55 ( Sup.), cf. Arist. PA 676a15 ; milky, Thphr. HP 1.12.2 ; acid, Alex.Trall. 2 ; δένδρα, of spice-bearing trees, Philostr. VA 2.2.
juicy, ἐρινοί Nic. Al. 319.

children.label: II
children.definition: Opus, Il. 2.531, IG 9(1).334.33 (v B. C.), etc. ; Ὀπούντιοι, οἱ, name of a section of the Locrians, Th. 1.108, etc. ; Locr. Ὁπούντιοι SIG 597 B 2 ; also Ὁπόντιοι IG 9(1).334.39, and un contr. Ὁποέντιος ib. 7.393.2 ( Oropus).

definition: ὁπόθεν, Ep. ὁππόθεν, Ion. ὁκόθεν (never -θε, for ὁππόθʼ Od. 3.89 is for ὁππόθι):—

children.definition: Adv. correl. to πόθεν :
ὅποι (q.v.), whence, from what place, εἴρεαι ὁππόθεν εἰμέν Od. 3.80 ; ἐρέσθαι, ὁππόθεν οὗτος ἀνήρ 1.406, cf. Pi. P. 9.43, Hdt. 2.54 ; σήμαινʼ ὅτου τʼ εἶ χὠπόθεν S. Fr. 104.

ἀπαίροντες . . ὁπόθεν τύχοιεν Th. 4.26 ; ὁπόθεν . . ῥᾴδιον ἦν λαβεῖν, οὐκ ἦγον to the place from which, X. An. 5.2.2 ; ὁ αὐτός τι κερδανεῖ Id. Mem. 2.6.4 ; so ὁ. ἂν τύχῃ from whencesoever . . , Pl. Tht. 180c ; γαμεῖν ὁ. ἂν βούληται Id. R. 362b, cf. IG 1(2).58.12 ; ἡδέως ζῆν . . ἐὰν ἔχῃ τις ὁ. Philetaer. 7.3 ; ὁ. ἔσοιτο μᾶζα Pl.Com. 33 ; ὁ. ἔτυχεν ἄρχεσθαι at haphazard, Arist. Po. 1450b32 : also with other Particles, ὁ. ποτέ Pl. Smp. 173d ; ὁ. δήποτε D.Chr. 31.54 (corr. Emperius for ὁ. δήποθεν) ; ὁποθενοῦν Pl. Grg. 512a, Arist. Cael. 271a24 ; ὁκοθενοῦν Hp. Ulc. 7 ; ὁποθενδηποτοῦν J. AJ 8.4.3.

data.quote: ὁπόθεν . . ῥᾴδιον ἦν λαβεῖν, οὐκ ἦγον
ἡδέως ζῆν . . ἐὰν ἔχῃ τις ὁ.

data.ref: Arist. Po. 1450b32 : also with other Particles,

definition: ὁπόθι, Ep. ὁππόθι as always in Hom.,

children.definition: Adv., correl. to πόθι, ὁππόθι πιότατον πεδίον . . ,ἔνθα . . τέμενος ἑλέσθαι Il. 9.577 ; ὁπόθι θάνατος ἀπῇ (or ἐπῇ) A. Supp. 124 (lyr.), as corrected.

data.quote: πόθι, ὁππόθι πιότατον πεδίον . . ,ἔνθα . . τέμενος ἑλέσθαι

children.definition: ὅπου, σάφα εἰπέμεν ὁππόθʼ ὄλωλεν Od. 3.89 ; v. ὅθι.

definition: ὅποι, Ion. ὅκοι, Dor. ὅπυι, ὅπυς (qq.v.), Adv. correl. to ποῖ ; on its difference from ὅπῃ, v. sub voce :

children.definition: to which place, whither, ἐκεῖσʼ ὅ. πορευτέον S. Aj. 690 ; ἴθʼ ὅ. χρῄζεις Ar. Nu. 891 ; ὅ. thither where, E. IT 119 ; πέμψον . . ὅ. προσωτάτω as far as possible, Id. Andr. 922, cf. X. An. 6.6.1, etc. ; ὅ. ἄν, with subj., whithersoever, ἀπιέναι ὅ. ἂν βούλωνται Foed. ap. Th. 5.18, cf. Pl. Ap. 37d, IG 1(2).76.31, etc. ; ὅ. ἂν ἄλλοσε βούλῃ whithersoever else, Pl. Phdr. 230e ; also ὅποιπερ S. Aj. 810, OT 1458 (v.l. ὅπηπερ) ; ὅποι ποτέ Id. Ph. 780, etc.

to what place, whither, ἀμηχανεῖν ὅποι τράποιντο A. Pers. 459 ; ἂν σκοπῇ . . ὅποι φέρονται Antiph. 40.7 ; ἴστε ὅθεν ἥλιος ἀνίσχει καὶ ὅποι ( ὅπου codd. meliores) δύεται X. An. 5.7.6 ; μέχρι ὅ. up to what point, Pl. Grg. 487c : in repeating a question, ποῖ; Answ. ὅποι μʼ ἐρωτᾷς; Crobyl. 5.

data.ref: Pl. Grg. 487c : in repeating a question,

children.label: b
children.definition: διδάξαι . . μʼ ὅποι καθέσταμεν (i.e. ὅποι ἐλθόντες) S. OC 23 ; τοὺς δὲ σοὺς ὅποι θεοὶ πόνους κατοικτιοῦσιν, οὐκ ἔχω μαθεῖν at what point the gods will take pity on (i.e. will end) thy sorrows, ib. 383 (v.l. ὅπῃ).

children.label: c
children.definition: ὅποι γῆς whither in the world, ὅποι γῆς . . πεπλάνημαι A. Pr. 564 (anap.) ; ὅποι τέτραπται γῆς Ar. Ach. 209 ; οὐκ οἶσθʼ ὅποι γῆς οὐδʼ ὅποι γνώμης φέρῃ S. El. 922.

data.quote: οὐκ οἶσθʼ ὅποι γῆς οὐδʼ ὅποι γνώμης φέρῃ

definition: ὁποῖος, α, ον, Ep. ὁπποῖος, η, ον, Hom., but twice ὁποῖος, Od. 17.421, 19.77 ; Ion. ὁκοῖος, η, ον, Archil. 70, Hdt. 2.82, al., GDI iv p.883 ( Erythrae, iv B. C.); Cret. ὀτεῖος (q. v.): correlat. to ποῖος: replaced by οἷος in Att. Inscrr. after 300 B.C. :

children.definition: of what sort or quality, ὁπποῖόν κʼ εἴπῃσθα ἔπος, τοῖόν κʼ ἐπακούσαις as [is] the word thou hast spoken, such shalt thou hear again, Il. 20.250 ; τοίῳ ὁποῖος ἔοι such as he might be, Od. 17.421 ; οὔθʼ οἷʼ ἔπασχεν οὔθʼ ὁποῖʼ ἔδρα κακά S. OT 1272.

data.quote: οὔθʼ οἷʼ ἔπασχεν οὔθʼ ὁποῖʼ ἔδρα κακά

children.definition: Od. 1.171, etc. ; εὑρεῖν ὁποίοις φαρμάκοις ἰάσιμος A. Pr. 475 : in direct questions only as f.l. in E. Ph. 878, Ba. 663 : sts. folld. by ποῖος in the same clause, οὐ γὰρ αἰσθάνομαί σου ὁποῖον νόμιμον ἢ ποῖον δίκαιον λέγεις X. Mem. 4.4.13 ; οὐκ οἶδα ὁποίᾳ τόλμῃ ἢ ποίοις λόγοις χρώμενος ἐρῶ Pl. R. 414d.

data.quote: οὐ γὰρ αἰσθάνομαί σου ὁποῖον νόμιμον ἢ ποῖον δίκαιον λέγεις
οὐκ οἶδα ὁποίᾳ τόλμῃ ἢ ποίοις λόγοις χρώμενος ἐρῶ

children.label: II
children.definition: ὁποῖός τις Th. 7.38, X. An. 2.2.2 ; ὁκοῖόν τι Hdt. 1.158 ; γιγνομένων ὁποῖοί τινες ἔτυχον Arist. Pol. 1286b24 ; so in Hom., ὁπποῖʼ ἄσσα of what sort, for ὁποῖά τινα, Od. 19.218 ; ὁποῖʼ ἄττα Pl. Grg. 465a ; ὁποιοσοῦν of what kind soever, Id. Tht. 152d, al. ; ὁποῖος δή, δήποτε, δηποτοῦν, and οὖν δή, as ὁποία δὴ φλέψ X. HG 5.4.58 ; τοὺς ὁποιουσδήποτε . . ἐξεπέμπετε στρατηγούς D. 18.146 : gen., ὁποίου τινὸς οὖν X. Cyr. 2.4.10: acc. fem., ὁποιαντινοῦν Lys. 13.11 ; ὁποῖόσπερ A. Ch. 669 ; ὁποιοσποτοῦν Arist. Ph. 253b23 ; ὁποιοσδητισοῦν Iamb. ap. Simp. in Ph. 639.30 ; πόλιν . . οὐδʼ ὁποίας ἥττω inferior to none, Plb. 4.65.3 ; οὔτʼ ἄλλους οὐδʼ ὁποίους Theopomp.Hist. 217 ( c) ; μηδὲ καθʼ ὁποῖον τρόπον SIG 672.14 ( Delph., ii B. C.) ; μηδʼ ὁτίη or μηδοτίη, v. μηδοτίη.

children.label: III
children.definition: Adv., like as, S. OT 915, 1076, E. Hec. 398.

children.label: IV
children.definition: Adv. ὁποίως, qualiter, Gloss.
smell of ὀποκάλπασον, Gal. 14.68.
Hotai, an acrid kind of myrrh, Balsamodendron Playfairii, Gal. 14.56.
Dsc. Alex.Praef.; opocarpatum, Plin. HN 28.158, 32.98.
the juice of the κιννάμωμον, prob. f.l. in Thphr. HP 4.4.14.

definition: ὀποπανάκη, ἡ, and ὀπο-πανάκιον, τό, = seq., Gloss.

children.definition: gum of Opopanax hispidus, Hercules’ woundwort, Heraclid.Tar. ap. Gal. 14.186, Dsc. 3.48, Gal. 12.94, PGrenf. 1.52.11 (iii A. D.).

juice, distd. from χυλός, χυμός, in that ὀπός is prop. vegetable juice, the milky juice which is drawn from a plant by tapping it, ὀπὸν . . στάζοντα τομῆς . . κάδοις δέχεται S. Fr. 534 (anap.), cf. Thphr. HP 9.8.1, etc. ; esp. the acid juice of the fig-tree, used as rennet ( τάμισος) for curdling milk, Il. 5.902, Emp. 33, Hp. Morb. 4.52, Menestor ap. Thphr. HP 1.2.3, Arist. Mete. 384a21, 389b10, GA 737a14 ; generally, acid juice, Pl. Ti. 60b ; βλέπειν ὀπόν Ar. Pax 1184 : in pl., Antiph. 88.4, cj. in Anaxandr. 41.59 (anap.); cf. ὀπίας, ὀποειδής,
ὀπὸς ἥβης the juicy freshness of youth, opp. ῥυτίς, AP 5.257 ( Paul.Sil.).

children.label: II
children.definition: ὀποῦ καρπός, = σιλφίου σπέρμα, Hp. ap. Gal. 19.126 ; and so prob. in Ar. Ec. 404, Pl. 719 ; but ὀπὸς σιλφίου silphium juice, Hp. Acut. 23, cf. 37, Acut. (Sp.) 18 [? was 48], Thphr. HP 6.3.2 ; so ὀπός alone, Gal. 12.90.

children.label: III
children.definition: gravy, Ath. 9.402c. (Perh. cf. Lith. sakaĩ (pl.) ‘resin’, Slav. sokǔ ‘sap’.)
polygon of any number of sides, Papp. 314.19.

definition: ὁποσάκις [ᾰ], Aeol. ὁποσσάκιν (leg. ὁππόσσακιν) Theoc. 30.27:— Adv., ( ὁπόσος)

children.definition: as many times as . . , X. Cyr. 2.3.23 ; ὁποσάκις ἄν so often as ever, Pl. Tht. 197d ; ὁποσακισοῦν as many times as you please, Arist. Cael. 273a32.
how many months old, Hp. Epid. 4.6.
how many-fold soever, Arist. Ph. 204b17, Simp. in Ph. 949.9.

definition: ὁποσάπους, ὁ, ἡ, πουν, τό, gen. ποδος, in indirect questions,

children.definition: how many feet long . . , Luc. Gall. 9.
in as many ways as . . , X. Cyn. 6.20.
in as many places as . . , Aristid. Rh. 2p.542S.
in as many ways as . . , Aristid. Rh. 1p.506S.

definition: ὁπόσε, Ep. ὁππόσε, poet. for ὅποι, Od. 14.139, but f.l. in h.Ap. 209.

ὁπόσος, Ep. ὁππόσος Od. 14.47, ὁπόσσος 22.220, Il. 23.238 (also ὁπόσος 24.7), ὁπόσσος also Berl.Sitzb. 1927.160 ( Cyrene), IG 42(1).121.109 ( Epid., iv B. C.); Ion. ὁκόσος; Cret. and Boeot. ὁπόττος Leg.Gort. 4.40, al., IG 7.522.19 (iii B. C.), etc.: correlat. to πόσος: freq. in IG 12, but replaced by ὅσος in Att. Inscrr. after 300 B.C. :

children.label: I
children.definition: as many, as many as . . , ὁπόσα τολύπευσε σὺν αὐτῷ Il. 24.7 ; πᾶσι θεοῖς . . , ὁπόσοι τὴν Διὸς αὐλὴν εἰσοιχνεῦσιν A. Pr. 121 (anap.), cf. 411, Th. 927 (both lyr.); τοσαῦτα ὁπόσα σοι φίλον Pl. Lg. 642d ; ὁπόσους πλείστους ἐδυνάμην X. Cyr. 4.5.29, etc. : in Prose freq. ὁ. ἄν with subj., ὁπόσοις ἂν δοκῇ Foed. ap. Th. 4.118, cf. Pl. Sph. 245d, etc.

data.quote: πᾶσι θεοῖς . . , ὁπόσοι τὴν Διὸς αὐλὴν εἰσοιχνεῦσιν

children.definition: as much as, of Size or Space, as great as, ὁπόσσον ἐπέσχε as far as it spread, Il. 23.238 ; χθόνα . . , ὁπόσαν καὶ φθιμένοισιν κατέχειν as much as is allowed the dead to occupy, A. Th. 732 (lyr.); ὁπόσην τῆς χώρας X. Oec. 4.8 : Adverbial in dat., ὁπόσῳ πλέον . . , τοσούτῳ πλειόνων κτλ. Pl. Lg. 649b.

ὁποσοσοῦν how great or much soever, Th. 4.37, 6.56, Pl. Sph. 245d : Ion. dat. pl., ὁκόσῃσι ὦν Hdt. 5.20 ; so ὁπόσῳ δήποτε D. 21.39 ; ὁποσοιδηποτοῦν Euc. 9.12, al. ; ὁπόσοσπερ Pl. Lg. 753b, X. Oec. 4.5 ; ὁποσουτινοσοῦν for however large a price, Lys. 22.15.

children.label: II
children.definition: ὄφρα . . εἴπῃς ὁππόσα κήδεʼ ἀνέτλης Od. 14.47 ; ὁπόσαι ψάμαθοι κλονέονται, καθορᾷς Pi. P. 9.46 ; εἰπὲ . . ὁκόσοι τοιοῦτοι [εἰσί] Hdt. 7.234 ; διαλογισώμεθα . . ὁπόσα . . πέφανται how many things he has been found to be, Pl. Sph. 231d ; ἠρώτων τὸ στράτευμα, ὁπόσον εἴη X. An. 4.4.17, cf. Pl. Sis. 388e ; ἤρετο ὁπόσου asked for how much, at what price, Timocl. 11.9.
of what day in serial order, εἴρει ὁποσταίη μηνὸς περιτέλλεται ἠώς Arat. 739.
what fraction, Eudem. ap. Simp. in Ph. 973.24.

in what or which place in numerical order, ὁπόστον μέρος Archyt. 1 ; ὁ. εἰλήχει what number he had drawn, Pl. R. 617e ; ὁ. ἐγένετο ἀφʼ Ἡρακλέους how many generations from . . , X. Ages. 1.2 ; οὕτως ὁπόστος τὸν ἀριθμόν, κτλ., in a sense determined by the number of which he is one, Arist. Pol. 1262a3 ; οὐ πρῶτος, οὐ δεύτερος . . , οὐχ ὁποστοσοῦν D. 18.310.

data.quote: οὐ πρῶτος, οὐ δεύτερος . . , οὐχ ὁποστοσοῦν

definition: ὁπόταν, i. e. ὁπότʼ ἄν, as it is freq. written in codd. (the distn. did not exist for the Greeks) : Adv., related to ὅταν as ὁπότε to ὅτε (v. ὁπότε),

children.definition: whensoever, used only with subj., Il. 15.209, etc. ( Hom. uses ὁππότε κεν in the same way, Il. 4.40, 229, al.): rarely after past tenses, πολλὰς . . ᾔσθου πλαγάς, ὁπόταν . . νὺξ ὑπολείφθῃ (for ὁπότε νὺξ ὑπολειφθείη) S. El. 91 (anap.): never with ind. in early writers, for φθέγξομαι ( Il. 21.340), ἱμείρεται ( Od. 1.41) are Ep. aor. subj. forms, and in Od. 16.282 θῇσιν is the right reading : never with opt. save in late writers (unless the Mss. can be trusted in Pl. Alc. 2.146a), for in Il. 7.415 ὁππότʼ ἄρʼ is the reading of the best codd. ; in X. Cyr. 1.3.11 ὁπότε ἥκοι is the right reading.

data.ref: S. El. 91 (anap.): never with ind. in early writers, for

children.label: II
children.definition: as soon as, ὁπότʼ ἂν τὸ πρῶτον ἴδῃ φάος h.Ap. 71.

data.quote: ὁπότʼ ἂν τὸ πρῶτον ἴδῃ φάος

definition: ὁπότε, Ep. ὁππότε, both in Hom. ; Ion. ὁκότε; Cyrenaic ὁπόκᾰ Berl.Sitzb. 1927.164 ; in Dor. Poets ὁππόκᾰ Theoc. 5.98 :

children.definition: Adv. of Time, correlat. to πότε, used much like ὅτε, exc. that the sense is less definite (cf. X. Cyr. 1.6.3), though the two were freq. used without distinction :

data.ref: X. Cyr. 1.6.3), though the two were freq. used without distinction :

children.label: I
children.definition: when, Il. 1.399, 3.173, etc. ; the ind. ἦστε is omitted, 8.230 : in Class. Att. Prose only ὅτε is so used, when referring to a particular time, but later ὁπότε returns, as ὁπότε περιῆν when she was alive, POxy. 243.10 (i A. D.): with the pres. in a simile, ὡς δʼ ὁπότε . . ποταμὸς πεδίονδε κάτεισι Il. 11.492 : with subj., like ὁπόταν, with reference to an indef. number of occasions in the pres. or to the future, ὁππότʼ Ἀχαιοὶ Τρώων ἐκπέρσωσʼ εὖ ναιόμενον πτολίεθρον 1.163, cf. 13.817, 21.112, Od. 14.170, Hes. Th. 782 : sts. in similes, ὡς ὁπότε νέφεα Ζέφυρος στυφελίξῃ Il. 11.305, cf. Od. 4.335 ; but ὁπότʼ ἄν, Ep. ὁπότε or ὁππότε κεν, is more common with subj., and in Att. Prose ἄν must be used, v. ὁπόταν: Cyrenaic ὁπόκα κα δήληται Berl.Sitzb. l.c.

data.quote: ὡς δʼ ὁπότε . . ποταμὸς πεδίονδε κάτεισι
ὁππότʼ Ἀχαιοὶ Τρώων ἐκπέρσωσʼ εὖ ναιόμενον πτολίεθρον

children.label: b
children.definition: ἷζε . . δέγμενος ὁππότε ναῦφιν ἀφορμηθεῖεν Il. 2.794, cf. 4.334, 7.415, 9.191, 18.524.

children.label: c
children.definition: S. Tr. 824 (lyr.), X. An. 4.6.20 ; in implied orat. obliq., Od. 24.344 (of a past promise) ; ἀποδοτέον . . ὁ. μανεὶς ἀπαιτοῖ we were not [as you remember] to . . , Pl. R. 332a.

data.ref: X. An. 4.6.20 ; in implied orat. obliq.,

children.label: d
children.definition: μηδʼ ἀντιάσειας ἐκείνῳ ὁππότε νοστήσειε Od. 18.148, cf. Pl. R. 396c, X. Cyr. 1.6.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἦ ῥά τι ἴδμεν . . ὁππότε Τηλέμαχος νεῖται; when he is to return, Od. 4.633 ; εἰς ὁ. by what time, Aeschin. 3.99 : rarely after a past tense, προσεδέρκετο, δέγμενος αἰεί, ὁππότε δὴ . . ἐφήσει (for ἐφείη, v. supr. I.2 b) Od. 20.386 ; εἰς σὲ βλέψαι καὶ τὸν ταμίαν ὁπότʼ ἄριστον παραθήσει Ar. V. 613.

data.quote: εἰς σὲ βλέψαι καὶ τὸν ταμίαν ὁπότʼ ἄριστον παραθήσει

children.label: III
children.definition: ὁποτεοῦν at any time whatever, Arist. Metaph. 1049a1.

children.label: B
children.definition: because, since, with ind., Thgn. 749 (s. v.l.), Hdt. 2.125, Pl. Lg. 895c, etc. ; also ὁπότε γε S. OC 1699 (lyr.), X. Cyr. 8.3.7.

definition: ὁπότερος, α, ον, Ep. ὁππότερος, as always in Hom. ; Ion. ὁκότερος Hdt. 5.119 :—correlat. to πότερος, used in sg. of individuals, in pl. of groups, e.g. of two armies, Il. 3.299, 5.33 :

children.definition: which of two, ἡμέων δʼ ὁπποτέρῳ θάνατος . . τέτυκται, τεθναίη Il. 3.101 : with ἄν, Ep. κε, whichsoever, ὁππότερος δέ κε νικήσῃ ib. 71 ; ὁπότερʼ ἂν κτίσῃς A. Supp. 434 (lyr.) ; ὁπότεροι ἂν κρατῶσιν X. Cyr. 4.2.37.

data.quote: ἡμέων δʼ ὁπποτέρῳ θάνατος . . τέτυκται, τεθναίη

children.definition: Ζεὺς οἶδε . . , ὁπποτέρῳ θανάτοιο τέλος πεπρωμένον ἐστίν Il. 3.309, cf. 22.130, 23.487 ; περὶ τοῦ ὁκότερος ἡμέων πλέω ἀγαθὰ . . ἐργάσεται about the question, which of us two . . , Hdt. 8.79 ; ὥστε μὴ γνῶναι ὁπότερος . . Lys. Fr. 78.3, cf. Antipho 3.2.6 ; ἀσαφῶς ὁποτέρων ἀρξάντων, for ἀσαφὲς ὂν ὁπότεροι ἦρξαν, Th. 4.20 : rarely in direct questions, for πότερος, prob. f.l. in Pl. Euthd. 271a and Ly. 212c.

data.quote: Ζεὺς οἶδε . . , ὁπποτέρῳ θανάτοιο τέλος πεπρωμένον ἐστίν

data.ref: Th. 4.20 : rarely in direct questions, for

children.definition: either of two, ἐὰν . . ὁπότερος αὐτοῖν . . πράξῃ Id. Lg. 868a, cf. R. 509a, X. Cyr. 3.2.22, And. 3.26, D. 16.27 ; so ὁποτεροσοῦν Pl. Men. 98d, Phlb. 14c, al.; ἐξεῖναι δʼ ὁποτεροισοῦν Th. 5.41, cf. Arist. Pol. 1319b9, al. : with οὐδέ, οὐδʼ ὁπότερος (or οὐδοπ-) neither, Hero Dioptr. 37.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adv. ὁποτέρως, in which of two ways, as Relat. and indirect interrog., ὁ. ἔσται, ἐν ἀδήλῳ κινδυνεύεται Th. 1.78, cf. Lys. 26.5, Isoc. 12.76, Pl. R. 348b, etc. ; so ὁποτερωσοῦν Arist. APr. 60a16, al.

ὁπότερον or -ερα as Adv., mostly in indirect questions, whether, folld. by ἢ . . ἤ . . , as ἐβουλεύοντο ὁκότερα ἢ παραδόντες . . ἢ ἐκλιπόντες . . , ἄμεινον πρήξουσι Hdt. 5.119 ; by one ἤ, Ar. Nu. 157 : folld. by πότερον . . ἤ . . , Pl. Erx. 405c, etc.; also ὁπότερον εἴτε . . , εἴτε . . Isoc. 12.76, cf. X. HG 3.5.19.

data.quote: ἐβουλεύοντο ὁκότερα ἢ παραδόντες . . ἢ ἐκλιπόντες . . , ἄμεινον πρήξουσι

children.definition: from which of the two sides or directions, Il. 14.59 ; ὁ. ἂν ᾖ ἡ πληγή Arist. PA 691b10 ; ὁποτερωθενοῦν on either of the two sides, Id. APr. 61a38.
in whichever of the two places, Hp. Superf. 10, X. Eq.Mag. 4.15.
in which of two directions, to which of two places, Th. 1.63, 5.65 ; ἐπορεύετο ὁ. βουληθείη Pl. Smp. 190a.
οὐδʼ ὁποτέρωσε (or οὐδοπ-) in neither of two directions, Dosith. p.410 K.

definition: ὅπου, Ion. ὅκου, Relat., indirect interrog., and indef. Adv. of Place, correlat. to ποῦ:

children.label: I
children.definition: τῆς πόλεως ὅπου κάλλιστον στρατοπεδεύσασθαι Pl. R. 415d, cf. Hdt. 2.172 ; ὅπου βούλοιτο τοῦ δρόμου X. HG 2.4.27 ; ἔσθʼ ὅπου in some places, A. Eu. 517 (lyr.), Fr. 302 : standing for the Relat. Adj., μέλη, ὅπου (i. e. ἐν οἷς) χελιδὼν ἦν τις ἐμπεποιημένη Ar. Av. 1301 : with other Particles, ὅκου δή somewhere or other, Hdt. 3.129 ; ὅπου ἄν wherever, with subj., IG 1(2).76.11, etc.; in Trag. the ἄν may be omitted, as ὅπου δʼ Ἀπόλλων σκαιὸς ᾖ, τίνες σοφοί; E. El. 972, etc. (never in Att. Prose): c. gen., ὅπου ἂν τύχῃ τῶν λεγομένων Pl. Prt. 342e ; ὁπουοῦν anywheresoever, Id. Cra. 403c ; ὅπουπερ c. opt., wherever, X. Cyr. 3.3.5 ; ὅπου ποτέ S. OC 12 ; ὁπουδάν, = ὅπου δὲ ἄν, anywhere, D.C. Fr. 109.21 ; ὁπουδήποτε, = ubicumque, Dosith.p.410 K. ; ὁπουδηποτοῦν anywheresoever, J. Ap. 2.15.

ὄφρα πύθηαι πατρός, ὅπου κύθε γαῖα Od. 3.16, cf. 16.306, S. OT 924, etc.: with Verbs of motion in pregnant sense, ὅκου ἐτράπετο, οὐκέτι εἶχον εἰπεῖν Hdt. 2.119 ; κεῖνος δʼ ὅπου βέβηκεν, οὐδεὶς οἶδε S. Tr. 40, v.l. in X. Cyr. 3.1.37, etc.: in many passages editors have in this sense restd. ὅποι, mostly from codd. ; in repeating a question, ἡ Λακεδαίμων ποῦ ʼστιν; Answ. ὅπου ʼστίν; (do you ask) where it is? Ar. Nu. 214 : c. gen., εἰδότες ὅκου γῆς εἴη Hdt. 4.150, cf. Pl. R. 403e.

data.quote: ὄφρα πύθηαι πατρός, ὅπου κύθε γαῖα

data.ref: S. OT 924, etc.: with Verbs of motion in pregnant sense,

data.quote: κεῖνος δʼ ὅπου βέβηκεν, οὐδεὶς οἶδε

data.ref: X. Cyr. 3.1.37, etc.: in many passages editors have in this sense restd.

children.definition: ὅ. τινʼ ἴδῃ Thgn. 922, cf. 999, X. HG 3.3.6 ; σιγᾶν θʼ ὅ. δεῖ καὶ λέγειν τὰ καίρια A. Ch. 582, cf. Eu. 277 ; οὐκ ἔσθʼ ὅ. there is no case in which, i.e. in no case. S. OT 448, Aj. 1069, E. HF 186, D. 3.35 ; so ἔστιν ὅ.; as a question, Id. 18.22.

data.quote: σιγᾶν θʼ ὅ. δεῖ καὶ λέγειν τὰ καίρια

children.definition: whereas, Hdt. 1.68, 4.195, Antipho 1.7; ὅ. γὰρ ἐγὼ . . ὁμολογῶ D. 21.205 ; ὅκου γε, Lat. quandoquidem or quippe, Hdt. 7.118 ; ὅπου γε X. Cyr. 2.3.11, etc.

children.label: B
children.definition: Adv., only in the phrase ὅ. μέν . . , ὅ. δέ . . here . . , there . . , Plu. Def.orac. 2.427c, S.E. P. 1.53, etc.
the seed of the σίλφιον, Dsc. Eup. 1.20,66, prob. in Dsc. 3.80.

definition: ὀππάτεσσι, Aeol. for ὄμμασι, Sapph. 2.11. ὅππη, Ep. for ὅπη.
ὁππῆμος, Adv., Ep. for ὁπῆμος (= ὁπότε),

children.definition: when, Arat. 568.

definition: ὁππόθεν, ὁππόθῐ, ὁπποῖος, Ep. for ὁπόθεν, ὁπόθι, ὁποῖος.
ὁππόσε, ὁππόσος, Ep. for ὁπόσε, ὁπόσος.
ὁππόταν, ὁππότε, ὁππότερος, ὁπποτέρωθεν, Ep. for ὁποτ-.

children.definition: to be seen, LXX Nu. 14.14 :—so ὀπτάνομαι, ib. 3 Ki. 8.8, UPZ 62.32 (ii B. C.), PTeb. 24.5 (ii B. C.), Act.Ap. 1.3, [ Ar.Byz.] Arg. Ar. Pl. 4, PMag.Par. 1.3033, Corp.Herm. 3.2 :—an Act. ὀπταίνω in Eust. 069.33.
roasted, broiled, κρειῶν πίνακας παρέθηκε . . ὀπταλέων Od. 16.50 ; ὀπταλέα κρέα ἔδμεναι Il. 4.345 ; κρέα . . ὀπταλέα τε καὶ ὠμά Od. 12.396 ; opp. ἑφθός (boiled), Ath. 9.380c.
assator, coctarius, Gloss.
one who roasts, PBerol. ap.Wilcken Ostr. i p. 693 (iii B. C.), PTeb. 277 (iii A. D.); assator, Gloss.
Suid.
for roasting, PRyl. 227.24 (iii A. D.).

place for roasting, kitchen, Ar. Eq. 1033, Pax 891, Alex. 173.13, Philem. 61, etc.; oven, PHolm. 11.18: these and other passages from Com. Poets, together with IG 2(2).1672.189, SIG 1097.28 (both iv B. C.), show that ὀπτάνιον is a real form, but ὀπτανεῖον, which is found in codd. of Plu. Crass. 8, Luc. Asin. 27, etc., can be defended by the older ὀπτανήϊον (v. Hdn.Gr. 2.417) and would be a normal derivative from ὀπτανεύς :—mock-heroic gen. pl. ὀπτανιάων for ὀπτανίων, Matro Conv. 12.

data.ref: Luc. Asin. 27, etc., can be defended by the older
Hdn.Gr. 2.417) and would be a normal derivative from

children.label: II
children.definition: firewood for roasting, Man. ap. J. Ap. 1.26.
roasted, opp. ἑψανός, ἀπʼ ὀβελίσκων ὀπτανά Sotad.Com. 1.10, cf. Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.151 ; τὰ ὀ. meat for roasting, Arist. Pr. 923a21.
vision, AP 6.210 codd. ( Philet.; v. ὁπλισία), LXX Es. 4.17, Ev.Luc. 1.22 ; simply, appearance, LXX Ma. 3.2, Si. 43.2.

definition: ὀπτασία (B), ἡ, prob. scribal error for ὀπτάνιον, PHolm. 9.39.

ὀπτάω, pf. ὤπτηκα Euphro 1.5 : irreg. part. Pass. ὀπτεύμενος Theoc. 7.55: Dor. pres. part. ὀπτᾶντες Epich. 164: fut. Med. ὀπτήσομαι (in pass. sense) Luc. Asin. 31 : aor. Pass., ὀπτηθῆναι Od. 20.27 : pf. Pass. ὤπτημαι Ar. Fr. 627: ( ὀπτός (A), q. v.) :—

children.definition: roast, broil, κρέα ὤπτων Od. 3.33, etc. ; σπλάγχνα δʼ ἄρʼ ὀπτήσαντες ἐνώμων 20.252 ; ὤπτησάν τε περιφραδέως Il. 1.466, 2.429 : also c. gen. partit., ὀπτῆσαί τε κρεῶν roast some meat, Od. 15.98 ; then in Hdt. 9.120, Ar. Av. 1690, X. Cyr. 8.2.6, etc. ; broil or fry fish, Ar. Fr. l.c., Crates Com. 17, al.; fry an egg, PLit.Lond. 170 (i A. D.); toast cheese, Eub. 150.2.—Hence it appears that ὀπτᾶν was used of all kinds of cooking by means of fire or dry heat, opp. ἕψω (boil in water), which never appears in Hom., whose heroes ate only roast meat, κρέα δὲ μόνον ὤπτων, ἐπεὶ ἕψοντά γʼ οὐ πεποίηκεν αὐτῶν οὐδένα Eub. 120.

data.quote: κρέα δὲ μόνον ὤπτων, ἐπεὶ ἕψοντά γʼ οὐ πεποίηκεν αὐτῶν οὐδένα

children.definition: bake bread, Hdt. 2.47 ; ὅκως ὀπτῷτο (v.l. ὀπτῴη) ὁ ἄρτος Id. 8.137, cf. X. An. 5.4.29; ὀπτᾶν πλακοῦντας Ar. Ra. 507 ; also of bricks or pottery, bake, burn, Hdt. 1.179 ; καλῶς ὠπτημένη [χύτρα] Pl. Hp.Ma. 288d; ὁ ὀπτώμενος κέραμος Arist. Mete. 383a21.
bake, scorch, of the sun, ἐπεὶ τόκα μʼ ἅλιος ὀπτῇ Bion Fr. 15.12 ; ἡ γῆ ὀπτᾶται ὑπὸ τοῦ ἡλίου X. Oec. 16.14.

data.quote: ἡ γῆ ὀπτᾶται ὑπὸ τοῦ ἡλίου

children.definition: ‘roast’ a man, τοῦτον ὀπτᾶν καὶ στρέφειν Ar. Lys. 839, cf. Sopat. 6.9 ( Pass.):— Pass., of the fire of love, ὀπτεύμενον ἐξ Ἀφροδίτας Theoc. 7.55, cf. 23.34, AP 12.92.7 ( Mel.): so, prob., in Act., Sapph. 115.
one must see, Hld. 7.17, Plot. 6.7.28.
forger, σιδήρου, of Hephaestus, Coluth. 54.
see, Ar. Av. 1061 (lyr.), A.D. Synt. 290.18, Max.Tyr. 8.7 ; but ὀπτευσάμενοι (μόχθους) in Eust.ad D.P. 195 is prob. f.l. for ὀττευσάμενοι.

data.ref: D.P. 195 is prob. f.l. for ὀττευσάμενοι.

children.definition: one who looks or spies, spy, scout, Od. 14.261, A. Supp. 185, S. Aj. 29.

children.label: II
children.definition: one who has seen, Id. Ichn. 77 ; eye-witness, Antipho 5.27, X. Cyr. 4.5.17.
presents made by the bridegroom on seeing the bride without the veil, = ἀνακαλυπτήρια, θεώρητρα, Poll. 2.59, 3.36, Hsch.
presents upon seeing or for the sight of a person, παιδὸς ὀ. E. Ion 1127, cf. Call. Dian. 74 ; προσβάλλων ἀκοαῖς ὀ. θυμοῦ Aspasia ap. Ath. 5.219d.
for roasting, Eub. 4.
roasting, frying, σπλάγχνων, opp. κρεῶν ἕψησις, SIG 57.34 (Milet. v B. C.), cf. Hp. Aff. 49, Arist. Mete. 381a23.
baking, of bread, J. AJ 3.10.7, Ath. 3.109c (pl.); of pottery, BGU 1143.17 (i B. C.), Luc. Prom.Es 2.
overheating of humours, Gal. 13.335, 19.580.
one who roasts, κάμινος Call. Fr. 475.
one must roast, Dsc. 5.88.
Hsch. (dub. sens.).
roasted, Eust. 135.17.
f.l. in Archyt. ap. Iamb. Protr. 4.
= Lat. auspicia, Arr. Epict. 3.24.117.

of or for sight: τὰ ὀπτικά the theory of the laws of sight, optics, Arist. Metaph. 1077a5, etc.; so ἡ ὀπτική (sc. θεωρία) ib. 997b20 ; -καὶ ἀποδείξεις Id. APo. 76a24 ; -κοὶ λόγοι Gal. 17(2).214 ; -κὴ δύναμις Id. 8.20. Adv. -κῶς Id. 18(1).309.

definition: ὀπτιλίασις ὀφθαλμίασις, Hsch. ( ὀπτοιαλίασις cod.): ὀπτιλίας is prob. cj. for ὁ ἐπὶ τηλείας in Id. s.v. λαμόπτης.
Ὀπτιλῖτις or Ὀπτιλλέτις, ιδος, ἡ, a name of Athena, Plu. Lyc. 11.

ὀπτίλος [ῐ], ὁ, Dor. for ὀφθαλμός, Metop. ap. Stob. 3.1.115, Plu. Lyc. 11 ; ὀπτίλλος in IG 42(1).121.40 ( Epid., iv B. C.), al., Hdn.Gr. 1.159, 2.560 (whence the spelling with one λ should prob. be corrected).

children.definition: optio, assistant; esp. in military sense, adjutant or aide-de-camp, Plu. Galb. 24, where ὀπίων is f.l., cf. IGRom. 4.825 ( Hierapolis), 3.1131 ( Syria), Sammelb. 6963 ( Nubia). ( Plu. wrongly derives it from the Greek ὄψομαι, fut. of ὁράω.)
baked tile, PFlor. 378.17 ( v A. D., pl.), etc.

roasted, broiled, σῖτός τε κρέα τʼ ὀπτά Od. 22.21, cf. 16.443 ; νῶτα βοὸς . . ὄπτʼ ἐν χερσὶν ἑλών 4.66 ; σάρκες A. Ag. 1097 ; ἑφθὰ καὶ ὀπτά boiled meats and roast, E. Cyc. 358 (lyr.), cf. Hdt. 2.77, Pl. R. 404c.

data.quote: νῶτα βοὸς . . ὄπτʼ ἐν χερσὶν ἑλών

children.definition: baked, βοῦν καὶ ἵππον . . ὀπτοὺς ἐν καμίνοισι Hdt. 1.133 ; of bread, Id. 2.92 ; of fish, PCair.Zen. 66.8 (iii B. C.) ; also of bricks and pottery, baked, burned, Hdt. 1.180, 186, X. An. 2.4.12, PAmh. 2.99 (a) 9 (ii A. D.), etc.; of soil, parched, X. Oec. 16.13: Sup. ὀπτότατος best dressed or done, Cratin. 143.

data.quote: βοῦν καὶ ἵππον . . ὀπτοὺς ἐν καμίνοισι

children.definition: forged, tempered, S. Ant. 475.
scorched, τὰ ὑπέρθυρʼ ὀπτά Herod. 2.65.
visible, Luc. Lex. 9, Ath. 8.338c.
see, A.D. Adv. 198.7.
get married, in irreg. aor. Pass. subj. 1 pl. ὀπυασθώμεθα Lyr.Alex.Adesp. 1.52 (dub. l.).

definition: ὅπυι, Dor. for ὅποι, SIG 56.39 ( Argos, v B. C.), Leg.Gort. 4.15 ; οὐδʼ ὅπυι κα ἔνθῃ no matter

children.definition: where he may go, Berl.Sitzb. 1927.158 ( Cyrene).
husband, Herod. 4.84.

definition: ὀπυίω, Att. ὀπύω Arist. EN 1148b32, Moer. p.278P., also Cerc. 17.41 ( Hsch. gives ὀπυόλαι· γεγαμηκότες), used by Hom. only in pres., and in impf. with or without augm.: fut. ὀπύσω [ῡ] Ar. Ach. 255.— Ep. Verb, used also in Cret. (v. infr.) and later Att. Prose:

children.label: I
children.definition: Act., of the man, marry, take to wife (= τὸ κατὰ νόμον μίγνυσθαι, Hsch. s.v. βεινεῖν), τὴν Εὔμηλος ὄπυιε Od. 4.798, cf. 2.207, Il. 16.178 ; πρεσβυτάτην δʼ ὤπυιε 13.429, cf. 18.383 ; τοῦ γὰρ ὀπυίεις παῖδα Hes. Sc. 356 ; δῶκεν ὀπυίειν θυγατέρα ἥν Id. Th. 819, cf. Pi. I. 4(3).59, Ar. l.c.; αἰ δέ κα . . ὁ ἐπιβάλλων ἡβίονσαν λείονσαν ὀπυίεθθαι μὴ λῇ ὀπυίεν if . . the man whose right it is does not wish to marry her, though she is of marriageable age and willing to marry, Leg.Gort. 7.42 : abs., πέντε δέ τοι φίλοι υἷες . . , οἱ δύʼ ὀπυίοντες, τρεῖς δʼ ἠΐθεοι θαλέθοντες two wedded. etc., Od. 6.63.

Pass., of the woman, to be married, τόν ῥʼ ἐξ Αἰσύμηθεν ὀπυιομένη τέκε μήτηρ Il. 8.304, cf. Solon. ap. Plu. Sol. 20 ; αἰ κύσαιτο καὶ τέκοι ϝοικέα μὴ ὀπυιομένα Leg.Gort. 4.19 : c. dat., αἰ δὲ τῷ αὐτῷ αὖτιν ὀπυίοιτο πρὸ τῶ ἐνιαυτῶ ib. 4.

data.quote: τόν ῥʼ ἐξ Αἰσύμηθεν ὀπυιομένη τέκε μήτηρ
αἰ κύσαιτο καὶ τέκοι ϝοικέα μὴ ὀπυιομένα

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., merely to have connexion with a woman, Cerc. l.c., Luc. Eun. 12, Merc.Cond. 41, etc.:— Pass., of the woman, οὐκ ὀπύουσιν ἀλλʼ ὀπύονται [γυναῖκες] Arist. l.c., cf. AP 10.56.7 ( Pall.); ἔνθʼ ἂν εὕρῃ τὸν ἄρρενα ὑπὸ τῆς θηλείας ὀπυιόμενον D.H. 19.2. ( ὀπύ(σ)yω, cf. ὀπυσ-τύς and perh. Skt. pusyati ‘nourish’, ‘maintain’.)

data.quote: ἔνθʼ ἂν εὕρῃ τὸν ἄρρενα ὑπὸ τῆς θηλείας ὀπυιόμενον

children.definition: IG 42(1).74.14 (Epid.), SIG 1166 ( Dodona).
marriage, GDI 4971.7 ( Crete).
pf. 2 of ὁράω :—hence late pres. ὀπωπέω, Orph. A. 183, 1022 ; ὀπωπήσασθαι Euph. 107. (Cf. ὄψ.)
a sight or view, ὅπως ἤντησας ὀπωπῆς Od. 3.97.
outward appearance, μετεβάλλετʼ ὀπωπάν Erinn. in PSI 9.1090.53 + 13 (p. xii), cf. Nonn. D. 2.60, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: sight, power of seeing, ἁμαρτήσεσθαι ὀπωπῆς Od. 9.512.
h.Merc. 15, prob. in Epigr.Gr. 1032 (Augusta Trevirorum).
bones of the eyes, Hp. Oss. 1.

definition: ὀπώρα, Ion. ὀπώρ-η, ἡ : sts. ὁπώρα, cf. χεῖμα χὠπώραν, i.e. καὶ ὁπ-, Alcm. 76 ( χειμάχωι πάραν, etc. codd.) ; pr. nn. Ὁπωρίς IG 5(1).1497, Hopora CIL 6.21782 ; cf. μεθόπωρον, μεθοπωρινός:—

children.definition: the part of the year between the rising of Sirius and of Arcturus (i.e. the last days of July, all Aug., and part of Sept.), the latter part of summer; Hom. names θέρος and ὀπώρη together, θέρος τεθαλυῖά τʼ ὀπώρη Od. 11.192 ; Σείριος being the star of ὀπώρη, Il. 22.27 ; cf. ὀπωρινός.—In later times it became the name of a definite season, autumn (v. ὥρα I.1 c), but was still used sts. to denote summer (autumn being distd. as φθινόπωρον or μετόπωρον) , ἀρξάμενος ἀπὸ τοῦ ἠρινοῦ χρόνου πρὸ ὀπώρας X. HG 3.2.10, cf. Ar. Av. 709, Arist. Mete. 348a1 ; ἐπʼ ὀκτὼ μῆνας Κυρηναίους ὀπώρη ἐπέχει Hdt. 4.199 ; νέας δʼ ὀπώρας ἡνίκʼ ἂν ξανθῇ στάχυς A. Fr. 304.7.

data.quote: ἀρξάμενος ἀπὸ τοῦ ἠρινοῦ χρόνου πρὸ ὀπώρας
ἐπʼ ὀκτὼ μῆνας Κυρηναίους ὀπώρη ἐπέχει
νέας δʼ ὀπώρας ἡνίκʼ ἂν ξανθῇ στάχυς

children.label: II
children.definition: fruit, γλαυκῆς ὀπώρας . . ποτοῦ χυθέντος . . Βακχίας ἀπʼ ἀμπέλου S. Tr. 703 ; τέμνεται βλαστουμένη καλῶς ὀ. Id. Fr. 255.8 ; σικυούς, βότρυς, ὀπώραν Ar. Fr. 569.1 : so in Prose, X. HG 2.4.25, Pl. Lg. 844d, 845c, Arist. HA 606b2, 629a2 : in this sense also in pl., Is. 11.43 ; Alcm. ( 75) even calls honey κηρίνα ὀπώρα; ἐαρινὴ ὀπώρα Alciphr. Fr. 6.10.

data.quote: γλαυκῆς ὀπώρας . . ποτοῦ χυθέντος . . Βακχίας ἀπʼ ἀμπέλου

data.ref: 629a2 : in this sense also in pl.,

children.label: III
children.definition: summer, the time of youthful ripeness, Pi. I. 2.5 ; τέρειναν ματέρʼ οἰνάνθας ὀπώραν (v. οἰνάνθη) Id. N. 5.6 ; ripe virginity, A. Supp. 998, 1015 ; ὀ. Κύπριδος Chaerem. 12.
pomarium, Gloss.

definition: ὀπωρεύς, έως, ὁ, epith. of Zeus at Acraephiae, IG 7.2733.

children.definition: autumnal, τὰ ὀ., = ὀπώρα II, fruit, Thphr. Ign. 41.

gather fruit, ὀ. ὀπώραν Pl. Lg. 845a ; σῦκα ib. 844e; ἀπὸ συκῆς ὠπώριζε D.L. 6.61 ; eat fruits, Arist. HA 612a30 ; gather in the fruits, Plu. Per. 9 :—so in Med., gather in oneʼs fruits, Theopomp.Hist. 89 : metaph., τοῖς τὰν ὥραν αὐτῶν βολλομένοις ὀπωρίξασθαι Dius ap. Stob. 4.21.16.

data.quote: τοῖς τὰν ὥραν αὐτῶν βολλομένοις ὀπωρίξασθαι

children.label: II
children.definition: gather fruit off, ὀπωριεῦντες ( Ion. fut. for -ιοῦντες) τοὺς φοίνικας Hdt. 4.172, 182.
of fruit: in fem. -κή, ἡ, name of a remedy for dysentery, Plin. HN 24.129.
of fruit, εἴδη dub. l. in PLond. 3.974i3, ii 5 ( iv A. D., cf. Addenda p. vii).
Anon. ap. Suid.

of ὀπώρα or late summer, ἀστέρʼ ὀπωρινῷ ἐναλίγκιον, i. e. Sirius, the star whose rising marked the beginning of that season (v. ὀπώρα), Il. 5.5 ; ἦμαρ 16.385 ; βορέης 21.346, Od. 5.328; ὄμβρος Hes. Op. 674, 677 ; ὄρχατοι E. Fr. 896 ; δέλφαξ Ar. Fr. 506.4 ; πυλαία SIG 239 C 31, al. ( Delph., iv B. C.). [In Hom. the last syll. is always long (by position in Il. 21.346), and the penult. is long also, metri gr.: when the ult. is short, the penult. also is short, as in Hes. Op. 674 ; in Att. ῐ always ; cf. μετοπωρινός.]
