children.definition: vintage, Aq. De. 7.13.
queen of fruits, a fine kind of fig, Anon. ap. Ath. 3.75d.
fruit-room, Varro RR 1.59.
fruiterer, Alciphr. 3.60.
plucking fruit, Opp. C. 1.125.
fruiterer, POxy. 980 (iii A. D.), 1133.7 (iv A. D.), Hsch. s.v. ὡραιοπώλης; gen. -πώλη MAMA 3.359 ( Corycus); but ὀπωρώνης was the Att. word acc. to Phryn. 181.
pomifero, Gloss.
eating of fruit, Sch. Gal. ap. Corp.Med.Gr. 5.9(2).198, Steph. in Hp. 1.54 D.
bear fruit, AP 6.252 ( Antiphil.).
bearing fruit, AP 7.321 ; δένδρα Gp. 3.13.4 ; ὀξόβαφα BGU 781 iii 5 (i A. D.).
hut of a garden-watcher, LXX Is. 1.8, cf. Theognost. Can. 136 ; = pomarium, Gloss.
watcher of fruits, garden-watcher, Arist. Pr. 938a16, D.S. 4.6, PRyl. 244 Intr. (iii A. D.).
D. 18.262, Aristaenet. 2.1, PLond. 5.1794.6 (V A.D.).

definition: ὅπως, Ep. also and Aeol. ὅππως, Ion. ὅκως, Dor. ὁπῶς acc. to A.D. Adv. 173.11: correlat. to ὡς and πῶς.

children.label: A
children.definition: as, in such manner as, and with interrog. force how, in what manner, rarely indef., v. infr. A. V.

children.label: B
children.definition: in such a manner that, in order that.

children.label: A
children.definition: how, as:

children.label: I
children.definition: ὥς or οὕτως (like ὡς), in such manner as, as:

children.label: a
children.definition: ἦ τοι νόστον, ὅπως φρεσὶ σῇσι μενοινᾷς, ὥς τοι Ζεὺς τελέσειεν Od. 15.111 ; οὕτως ὅ . . . S. Tr. 330 ; ὧδʼ ὅ. Id. El. 1301 ; οὕτως ὅ. δύνανται Th. 7.67: sts. an analogous word replaces the antec. Adv., με τοῖον ἔθηκεν, ὅπως (for οἷον) ἐθέλει Od. 16.208 : freq. without any antec. expressed, ἔλθοι ὅ . . . ἐθέλω (sc. αὐτὸν ἐλθεῖν) 14.172 ; ἔρξον ὅ. ἐθέλεις Il. 4.37, Od. 13.145 ; χρῶ ὅ. βούλει X. Cyr. 8.3.46; ποίει ὅ. ἄριστόν σοι δοκεῖ εἶναι ib. 4.5.50 ; ὅ. ἔχω as I am, on the spot, S. Ph. 819.

data.quote: ἦ τοι νόστον, ὅπως φρεσὶ σῇσι μενοινᾷς, ὥς τοι Ζεὺς τελέσειεν

children.label: b
children.definition: fut. ind., esp. after Verbs of seeing, providing, taking care . . , in the manner in which, how, that, οἱ Περσικοὶ νόμοι ἐπιμέλονται ὅπως μὴ τοιοῦτοι ἔσονται οἱ πολῖται X. Cyr. 1.2.3; ποιέειν ὅκως μηκέτι κεῖνος ἐς Ἕλληνας ἀπίξεται Hdt. 5.23 ; ἐφρόντιζον ὅκως μὴ λείψομαι τῶν πρότερον γενομένων Id. 7.8.α, cf. Pl. Ap. 29e ; ἔπρασσον ὅπως τις βοήθεια ἥξει Th. 3.4 ; τοῦτο μηχανᾶσθαι ὅπως ἀποφεύξεται πᾶν ποιῶν θάνατον Pl. Ap. 39a ; τούτου στοχαζόμενοι, ὅπως . . ἔσονται Id. Grg. 502e (cf. infr. III.1 b, etc.): this fut. ind. may become opt. after a historical tense, ἐπεμελεῖτο ὅπως μήτε ἄσιτοι μήτε ἄποτοί ποτε ἔσοιντο X. Cyr. 8.1.43, cf. HG 7.5.3, Cyr. 8.1.10, Oec. 7.5, Ages. 2.8 ; and ὅπως is freq. used interchangeably with such forms as διʼ ὧν, ὅτῳ τρόπῳ, etc., εἰσηγοῦνται μὴ διʼ ὧν . . ἀσκήσουσιν, ἀλλʼ ὅπως . . δόξουσι Isoc. 1.4, cf. Th. 6.11: this sense easily passes into a final sense, so that, τοῦτο ἀπόβαλε οὕτω ὅκως μηκέτι ἥξει Hdt. 3.40 ; οὕτω δʼ (sc. ποίει) ὅπως μήτηρ σε μὴ ʼπιγνώσεται S. El. 1296, cf. Ar. Ra. 905, X. Cyr. 4.5.25, HG 2.4.17 ; v. infr. B.

data.quote: οἱ Περσικοὶ νόμοι ἐπιμέλονται ὅπως μὴ τοιοῦτοι ἔσονται οἱ πολῖται
ποιέειν ὅκως μηκέτι κεῖνος ἐς Ἕλληνας ἀπίξεται
ἐφρόντιζον ὅκως μὴ λείψομαι τῶν πρότερον γενομένων
τοῦτο μηχανᾶσθαι ὅπως ἀποφεύξεται πᾶν ποιῶν θάνατον
ἐπεμελεῖτο ὅπως μήτε ἄσιτοι μήτε ἄποτοί ποτε ἔσοιντο
εἰσηγοῦνται μὴ διʼ ὧν . . ἀσκήσουσιν, ἀλλʼ ὅπως . . δόξουσι

data.ref: Th. 6.11: this sense easily passes into a final sense,

data.quote: τοῦτο ἀπόβαλε οὕτω ὅκως μηκέτι ἥξει

children.definition: ἄν ( Ep. κε) and subj. in indefinite sentences, in whatever way, just as, however, ὅππως κεν ἐθέλῃσιν Il. 20.243 (but ὅπως ἐθέλῃσιν (without κε) Od. 1.349, 6.189) ; οὕτως ὅκως ἂν καὶ δυνώμεθα Hdt. 8.143 ; οὕτως ὅπως ἂν αὐτοὶ βούλωνται X. Cyr. 1.1.2, cf. IG 2(2).1.13 (v B. C.), Pl. Phd. 116a, Smp. 174b, etc.

children.label: b
children.definition: οὕτως ὅ. τύχοιεν Th. 8.95 ; ὅ. βούλοιντο X. HG 2.3.13 ; in a gnomic statement, εἰκῇ κράτιστον ζῆν ὅ. δύναιτό τις S. OT 979 : when ἄν appears with the opt., it belongs to the Verb and not to ὅπως, ὅ. ἄν τις ὀνομάσαι τοῦτο however one might think fit to call it, D. 13.4.

data.quote: εἰκῇ κράτιστον ζῆν ὅ. δύναιτό τις

children.definition: οὐκ ἔστιν ὅ. ( οὐκ ἔσθʼ ὅπως) there is no way in which . . , it cannot be that, οὐκ ἔστι ὅκως κοτὲ σοὺς δέξονται λόγους Hdt. 7.102, cf. Ar. Pl. 18, D. 18.208, al.; so οὐκ ἔστιν ὅ. οὐ, fieri non potest quin, οὐκ ἔσθʼ ὅ. οὐ πιστὸν ἐξ ὑμῶν πτερὸν ἐξήγαγʼ S. OC 97, cf. Ar. Ach. 116, Eq. 426, Th. 882, Pl. Ap. 27e ; οὐδαμῶς ὅ. οὐ, in answer, it must positively be so, Id. Tht. 160d ; so also οὐκ ἂν γένοιτο τοῦθʼ ὅ . . . οὐ φανῶ S. OT 1058 ; οὐ γὰρ γένοιτʼ ἄν, ταῦθʼ ὅ. οὐχ ὧδʼ ἔχειν (anacoluth. for ἔχει or ἕξει) Id. Aj. 378 : so in questions, ἔσθʼ ὅ . . . ἔλθωμεν; Ar. V. 471 (v.l. -οιμεν) ; ἔστιν οὖν ὅ. ὁ τοιοῦτος φιλοσοφήσει; Pl. R. 495a, cf. Phdr. 262b, Tht. 154c : so, besides ind. of all tenses, οὐκ ἔσθʼ ὅ. may be folld. by opt. with ἄν, οὐ γάρ ἐσθʼ ὅπως μίʼ ἡμέρα γένοιτʼ ἂν ἡμέραι δύο Ar. Nu. 1181, cf. V. 212, Isoc. 12.156, Pl. La. 184c: by ind. with ἄν, οὐκ ἔστιν ὅπως ἂν . . κατέστησαν Isoc. 15.206, cf. D. 33.28 : ἄν is omitted in οὐκ ἔσθʼ ὅπως λέξαιμι A. Ag. 620, cf. E. Alc. 52, Ar. V. 471 (v.l. ἔλθωμεν).

data.quote: οὐκ ἔστι ὅκως κοτὲ σοὺς δέξονται λόγους
οὐκ ἔσθʼ ὅ. οὐ πιστὸν ἐξ ὑμῶν πτερὸν ἐξήγαγʼ
οὐκ ἂν γένοιτο τοῦθʼ ὅ . . . οὐ φανῶ

data.ref: Tht. 154c : so, besides ind. of all tenses,

data.quote: ἄν, οὐ γάρ ἐσθʼ ὅπως μίʼ ἡμέρα γένοιτʼ ἂν ἡμέραι δύο
ἄν, οὐκ ἔστιν ὅπως ἂν . . κατέστησαν

children.definition: κῦμʼ ὅπως A. Pr. 1001 ; γῄτης ὅπως S. Tr. 32, cf. 442, 683 ; ὅπως δρῦν ὑλοτόμοι σχίζουσι κάρα Id. El. 98 (anap.) ; ὅπως ἁ πάνδυρτος ἀηδών ib. 1076 (lyr.), cf. Ph. 777, E. Andr. 1140 ; ὅκως τις καλλίης κάτω κύπτων Herod. 3.41 ; so in Locr. Prose, ὅπω(ς) ξένον IG 9(1).334.2 (V B.C.).
ὅτι, with Sup. of Advs., ὅ. ἄριστα A. Ag. 600, IG 1(2).44.8, etc.; ὅ. ἀνωτάτω as high up as possible, Ar. Pax 207 ; in full, οὕτως ὅ. ἥδιστα (sc. ἔχει) S. Tr. 330.
σοῦσθε ὅ. ποδῶν run as you are off for feet, i. e. as quick as you can, A. Supp. 837 (lyr., where however <ἔχετε> shd. prob. be added); v. infr. III.10, ἔχω (A) B. II.2b.

when, Τρῶες . . ὅπως ἴδον αἷμʼ Ὀδυσῆος . . , ἐπʼ αὐτῷ πάντες ἔβησαν Il. 11.459, cf. 12.208, Od. 3.373: freq. in Hdt. with opt., whenever, ὅκως μὲν εἴη ἐν τῇ γῇ καρπὸς ἁδρός 1.17, cf. 68, 100, 162, 186, 2.13, 174, al.: in Trag. and Com., A. Pers. 198, S. El. 749, Tr. 765, Ar. Nu. 60 : with Sup. of Advs., ὅ. πρῶτα as soon as, Hes. Th. 156 ; ὅ. ὤκιστα Thgn. 427 ; ὅ. τάχιστα A. Pr. 230.

data.quote: Τρῶες . . ὅπως ἴδον αἷμʼ Ὀδυσῆος . . , ἐπʼ αὐτῷ πάντες ἔβησαν
ὅκως μὲν εἴη ἐν τῇ γῇ καρπὸς ἁδρός

children.definition: where, dub. in Herod. 3.75.

children.label: II
children.definition: ὅπως is sts. used to introduce the substance of a statement, after Verbs of saying, thinking, or perceiving, that, how, λόγῳ ἀνάπεισον ὅκως . . Hdt. 1.37 ; οὐδὲ φήσω ὅκως . . Id. 2.49, cf. 3.115, 116 ; τοῦτʼ αὐτὸ μή μοι φράζʼ, ὅπως οὐκ εἶ κακός S. OT 548, cf. Ant. 223, Pl. Euthd. 296e ; after ἐλπίζειν, S. El. 963, E. Heracl. 1051 ; after Verbs of emotion, ἐμοὶ δʼ ἄχος . . , ὅπως δὴ δηρὸν ἀποίχεται grief is mine, when I think how . . ( i.e. that . . ), Od. 4.109, cf. S. Ph. 169 (lyr.); after θαυμάζω freq. in Att., θαυμάζω ὅ. ποτὲ ἐπείσθησαν Ἀθηναῖοι X. Mem. 1.1.20, cf. Pl. Cri. 43a.

data.quote: τοῦτʼ αὐτὸ μή μοι φράζʼ, ὅπως οὐκ εἶ κακός

data.ref: E. Heracl. 1051 ; after Verbs of emotion,

children.definition: οὐχ ὅ . . . ἀλλὰ or ἀλλὰ καὶ . . is not only not . . but . . , and is expld. by an ellipsis of λέγω or ἐρῶ (cf. ὅτι IV), οὐχ ὅ. κωλυταὶ . . γενήσεσθε, ἀλλὰ καὶ . . δύναμιν προσλαβεῖν περιόψεσθε not only will you not become . . , but you will also . . , Th. 1.35, cf. X. HG 5.4.34, D. 6.9 ; οὐχ ὅ. ὑμῖν τῶν αὑτοῦ τι ἐπέδωκεν, ἀλλὰ τῶν ὑμετέρων πολλὰ ὑφῄρηται Lys. 30.26 ; οὐχ ὅ. τούτων χάριν ἀπέδοσαν, ἀλλʼ ἀπολιπόντες ὑμᾶς εἰς τὴν Λακεδαιμονίων συμμαχίαν εἰσῆλθον Isoc. 14.27, cf. D. 18.131, 53.13 ; οὐ γὰρ ὅπως . . , ἀλλὰ καὶ . . Id. 21.11 ; οὔκουν ὅπως . . , ἀλλὰ . . X. Cyr. 8.2.12 ; also οὐχ ὅ . . . , ἀλλʼ οὐδέ . . , οὐχ ὅ. ἀδικοῦντες, ἀλλʼ οὐδʼ ἐπιδημοῦντες ἐφυγαδευόμεθα Id. HG 2.4.14 ; οὐχ ὅ. τῆς κοινῆς ἐλευθερίας μετέχομεν, ἀλλʼ οὐδὲ δουλείας μετρίας τυχεῖν ἠξιώθημεν Isoc. 14.5 ; διμοιρίαν λαμβάνων ἐν ταῖς θοίναις οὐχ ὅπως ἀμφοτέραις ἐχρῆτο, ἀλλὰ διαπέμπων οὐδετέραν αὑτῷ κατέλειπε X. Ages. 5.1 ; οὐχ ὅ. ζημιοῦν, ἀλλὰ μηδʼ ἀτιμάζειν . . Th. 3.42 : so sts. μὴ ὅ. (where an imper. must be supplied), μὴ ὅ. ὀρχεῖσθαι ἀλλʼ οὐδὲ ὀρθοῦσθαι ἐδύνασθε do not think that you could dance = so far from being able to dance, X. Cyr. 1.3.10.

data.quote: οὐχ ὅ. ὑμῖν τῶν αὑτοῦ τι ἐπέδωκεν, ἀλλὰ τῶν ὑμετέρων πολλὰ ὑφῄρηται
οὐχ ὅ. τούτων χάριν ἀπέδοσαν, ἀλλʼ ἀπολιπόντες ὑμᾶς εἰς τὴν Λακεδαιμονίων συμμαχίαν εἰσῆλθον
οὐχ ὅ . . . , ἀλλʼ οὐδέ . . , οὐχ ὅ. ἀδικοῦντες, ἀλλʼ οὐδʼ ἐπιδημοῦντες ἐφυγαδευόμεθα
οὐχ ὅ. τῆς κοινῆς ἐλευθερίας μετέχομεν, ἀλλʼ οὐδὲ δουλείας μετρίας τυχεῖν ἠξιώθημεν
διμοιρίαν λαμβάνων ἐν ταῖς θοίναις οὐχ ὅπως ἀμφοτέραις ἐχρῆτο, ἀλλὰ διαπέμπων οὐδετέραν αὑτῷ κατέλειπε
οὐχ ὅ. ζημιοῦν, ἀλλὰ μηδʼ ἀτιμάζειν . .

children.label: b
children.definition: οὐχ ὅ. rarely follows another clause, to say nothing of . . , let alone . . , πεπαύμεθʼ ἡμεῖς, οὐχ ὅ. σε παύσομεν S. El. 796 ; μηδʼ ἐμπίδα, οὐχ ὅπως ταῦρον ἔτι ἄρασθαι δυνάμενος . . let alone a bull, Luc. Cont. 8, cf. Prom. 8, Pr.Im. 7, Pisc. 31.

data.quote: πεπαύμεθʼ ἡμεῖς, οὐχ ὅ. σε παύσομεν

children.label: III
children.definition: how, in what way or manner:

children.label: a
children.definition: ἔσπετε νῦν μοι ὅππως δὴ . . πῦρ ἔμπεσε νηυσίν Il. 16.113 ; εἴπʼ ἄγε μʼ . . ὅππως τούσδʼ ἵππους λάβετον 10.545 ; εὖ μοι κατάλεξον ὅπως ἤντησας Od. 3.97 ; ὅπως ἠφανίσθη οὐδὲ λόγῳ εἰκότι δύνανται ἀποφαίνειν Antipho 5.26 ; Ἀλκιβιάδης ἀνήχθη . . ἐπὶ κατασκοπὴν . . τοῦ οἴκαδε κατάπλου ὅπως ἡ πόλις πρὸς αὐτὸν ἔχοι X. HG 1.4.11 ; οὐδέ τί πω σάφα ἴδμεν ὅπως ἔσται τάδε ἔργα Il. 2.252, etc.

data.quote: ἔσπετε νῦν μοι ὅππως δὴ . . πῦρ ἔμπεσε νηυσίν
εἴπʼ ἄγε μʼ . . ὅππως τούσδʼ ἵππους λάβετον
ὅπως ἠφανίσθη οὐδὲ λόγῳ εἰκότι δύνανται ἀποφαίνειν
Ἀλκιβιάδης ἀνήχθη . . ἐπὶ κατασκοπὴν . . τοῦ οἴκαδε κατάπλου ὅπως ἡ πόλις πρὸς αὐτὸν ἔχοι
οὐδέ τί πω σάφα ἴδμεν ὅπως ἔσται τάδε ἔργα

children.label: b
children.definition: fut. after Verbs of deliberation (like the subj., v. infr. 2), φραζώμεθʼ ὅπως ἔσται τάδε ἔργα 4.14 ; φράζευ ὅπως Δαναοῖσιν ἀλεξήσεις κακὸν ἦμαρ (v.l. ἀλεξήσῃς) 9.251, cf. Od. 13.376, 386, 19.557, 20.29, 39.

subj. after Verbs of deliberation, taking care, and the like, λεύσσει ὅπως ὄχʼ ἄριστα . . γένηται Il. 3.110 ; ἐνόησεν (gnomic aor.) ὅππως κέρδος ἔῃ 10.225 ; ἀλλʼ ἄγεθʼ ἡμεῖς οἵδε περιφραζώμεθα πάντες νόστον ὅπως ἔλθῃσι Od. 1.77, cf. 13.365 ; οὐκ οἶδʼ ὅπως . . φῶ S. OT 1367, cf. Aj. 428, Lys. 8.5, Pl. Men. 91d ; ἐπιμελητέον ὅπως τρέφωνται οἱ ἵπποι X. Eq.Mag. 1.3, cf. Oec. 7.36, 37, 9.14, 15.1, Pl. Grg. 515c.—Sts. the fut. and subj. are conjoined without difference of meaning, ἐπράττετο γὰρ . . , πρῶτον μὲν ὅπως μὴ περιμείνητε . . , δεύτερον δὲ ὅπως ψηφιεῖσθε . . , τρίτον δὲ ὅπως μὴ ἔσται Aeschin. 3.65, cf. X. Ages. 7.7, Mem. 2.2.10.—On ὅπως ἄν (κεν) , v. infr. 5.

data.quote: ἀλλʼ ἄγεθʼ ἡμεῖς οἵδε περιφραζώμεθα πάντες νόστον ὅπως ἔλθῃσι
ἐπράττετο γὰρ . . , πρῶτον μὲν ὅπως μὴ περιμείνητε . . , δεύτερον δὲ ὅπως ψηφιεῖσθε . . , τρίτον δὲ ὅπως μὴ ἔσται

children.definition: τῶν ἀδῄλων ὅπως ἀποβήσοιτο ib. 1.3.2, etc.: after Verbs of deliberation, being virtually orat. obliq., μερμήριξε . . Ἥρη ὅπως ἐξαπάφοιτο (orat. rect. πῶς ἐξαπάφωμαι;) Il. 14.160 ; μερμήριζεν ὅπως ἀπολοίατο πᾶσαι νῆες Od. 9.554, cf. 420 ; οὐ γὰρ εἴχομεν . . ὅπως δρῶντες καλῶς πράξαιμεν S. Ant. 271 ; ἐπεμελήθημεν ὅπως ἐξαλειφθείη αὐτῷ τὰ ἁμαρτήματα Lys. 6.39, cf. 13.32, X. Cyr. 6.2.11.

data.ref: 1.3.2, etc.: after Verbs of deliberation, being virtually orat. obliq.,

data.quote: οὐ γὰρ εἴχομεν . . ὅπως δρῶντες καλῶς πράξαιμεν
ἐπεμελήθημεν ὅπως ἐξαλειφθείη αὐτῷ τὰ ἁμαρτήματα

children.definition: ἄν freq. expressing a wish, which in orat. rect. would be expressed by πῶς ἄν, σκόπει ὅ. ἂν ἀποθάνοιμεν ἀνδρικώτατα Ar. Eq. 81 (v.l. ἀποθάνωμεν), cf. Nu. 760 ; βουλευόμενοι ὅ. ἂν τὴν ἡγεμονίαν λάβοιεν τῆς Ἑλλάδος X. HG 7.1.33, cf. Cyr. 2.1.4 ; τῶν ἄλλων ἐπιμελεῖται ὅ. ἂν θηρῷεν (v.l. -ῶσιν) ib. 1.2.10: the opt. with ἄν and subj. sts. appear in consecutive clauses, Id. HG 3.2.1.

data.quote: πῶς ἄν, σκόπει ὅ. ἂν ἀποθάνοιμεν ἀνδρικώτατα
βουλευόμενοι ὅ. ἂν τὴν ἡγεμονίαν λάβοιεν τῆς Ἑλλάδος

children.definition: ὅπως ἄν (κεν) with the subj. is used after imper. or inf. used as imper., πείρα ὅπως κεν δὴ σὴν πατρίδα γαῖαν ἵκηαι Od. 4.545; φράζεσθαι . . , ὅππως κε μνηστῆρας . . κτείνῃς 1.295; σκοπεῖτε . . , ὅ. ἂν ὑμῖν πρᾶγος εὖ νικᾷ τόδε A. Supp. 233, etc.; φύλασσε . . ἔπειθʼ ὅ. ἂν . . ἡ χάρις . . ἐξ ἁπλῆς διπλῆ φανῇ S. Tr. 618, cf. E. IA 539 : in Prose, ἐπιμεληθῆναι ὅ. ἂν . . X. Cyr. 8.3.6, cf. Pl. Prt. 326a; μηχανᾶσθαι Id. Phdr. 239b, Grg. 481a, cf. Ar. Eq. 917.

data.quote: πείρα ὅπως κεν δὴ σὴν πατρίδα γαῖαν ἵκηαι
σκοπεῖτε . . , ὅ. ἂν ὑμῖν πρᾶγος εὖ νικᾷ τόδε
φύλασσε . . ἔπειθʼ ὅ. ἂν . . ἡ χάρις . . ἐξ ἁπλῆς διπλῆ φανῇ

children.definition: inf., ἐπιμελήθητε προθύμως ὅπως διπλάσια . . σῖτα καὶ ποτὰ παρασκευασθῆναι X. Cyr. 4.2.37 (v.l. -εσκευασμένα ᾖ), cf. Oec. 7.29, HG 6.2.32; so later ὅπως παρακολουθῆμεν ( Dor. inf.) Supp.Epigr. 1.170.18 (cf. p.138, Delph., ii B. C.); ὅπως . . ἔχειν, ὅπως . . εἴργεσθαι, D.S. 20.4, 85; ὅπως πέμπιν PTeb. 315.30 (ii A. D.).

data.quote: ἐπιμελήθητε προθύμως ὅπως διπλάσια . . σῖτα καὶ ποτὰ παρασκευασθῆναι

children.definition: ὅπως and ὅπως μή are used with fut. ind. or aor. subj. :— the readings are freq. uncertain : the following (among others) are made certain either by the metre or the form,

children.label: a
children.definition: fut. ind., δέδοιχʼ ὅπως μὴ τεύξομαι Ar. Eq. 112 ; παντὶ λόγῳ ἀντιτείνετε εὐλαβούμενοι ὅπως μὴ . . οἰχήσομαι Pl. Phd. 91c ; φόβος . . ἔστιν . . ὅπως μὴ αὖθις διασχισθησόμεθα Id. Smp. 193a : sts. the preceding Verb is omitted, ὅπως μὴ οὐκ . . ἔσομαι Id. Men. 77a.

data.quote: παντὶ λόγῳ ἀντιτείνετε εὐλαβούμενοι ὅπως μὴ . . οἰχήσομαι
φόβος . . ἔστιν . . ὅπως μὴ αὖθις διασχισθησόμεθα

children.label: b
children.definition: aor. subj., τὴν θεὸν δʼ ὅ. λάθω δέδοικα E. IT 995; φυλάττου, ὅ. μὴ εἰς τοὐναντίον ἔλθῃς X. Mem. 3.6.16 : rarely with pres., οὐ φοβεῖ ὅ. μὴ ἀνόσιον πρᾶγμα τυγχάνῃς πράττων Pl. Euthphr. 4e : sts. the preceding Verb is omitted, with aor. subj., ὅκως μή τι ὑμῖν πανώλεθρον κακὸν ἐς τὴν χώρην ἐσβάλωσι Hdt. 6.85 : with pres. subj., ὅπως μὴ . . ᾖ τοῦτο Pl. Cra. 430d.

data.quote: τὴν θεὸν δʼ ὅ. λάθω δέδοικα
φυλάττου, ὅ. μὴ εἰς τοὐναντίον ἔλθῃς
οὐ φοβεῖ ὅ. μὴ ἀνόσιον πρᾶγμα τυγχάνῃς πράττων
ὅκως μή τι ὑμῖν πανώλεθρον κακὸν ἐς τὴν χώρην ἐσβάλωσι

children.label: c
children.definition: subj. after a historical tense, X. Mem. 2.9.3.

ὅρα ὅκως μή σευ ἀποστήσονται Πέρσαι Hdt. 3.36 ; ἄθρει . . ὅπως μὴ ἐκδύσεται Ar. V. 141; τηρώμεσθʼ ὅπως μὴ . . αἰσθήσεται ib. 372 : but this came to be omitted, and ὅπως or ὅπως μή with fut. ind. or aor. subj. are exactly = the imper., ἔμβα χὤπως ἀρεῖς Id. Ra. 378 (lyr.) : most freq. with fut. ind., ὅκως λόγον δώσεις τῶν μετεχείρισας χρημάτων, = δίδου λόγον, Hdt. 3.142 ; ὅπως παρέσει μοι, = πάρισθι, Ar. Av. 131 ; ὅπως πετήσει Id. Pax 77, cf. X. An. 1.7.3, Lys. 1.21, 12.50, Pl. Grg. 489a, etc.: rarely with I pers., ὁποῖα κισσὸς δρυός, ὅπως τῆσδʼ ἕξομαι E. Hec. 398, cf. Ar. Ec. 297 (lyr.): very rarely with aor. subj., ὅπως μή τι ἡμᾶς σφήλῃ Pl. Euthd. 296a codd.; ὅπως μὴ . . ἐξαπατήσῃ Id. Prt. 313c ; ὅπως μὴ ποιήσητε D. 4.20 codd.—The codd. freq. vary, as between διδάξεις and -ξῃς Ar. Nu. 824 ; τιμωρήσονται and -ωνται Th. 1.56; πράξομεν and -ωμεν ib. 82 ; θορυβήσει and -σῃ D. 13.14, etc.—Since the fut. is frequently, and the aor. (whether 1 or 2) rarely guaranteed by metre or form, the aor. 1 forms shd. prob. be rejected, both in signf. 7 and 8, in cases where codd. vary.

data.quote: ὅρα ὅκως μή σευ ἀποστήσονται Πέρσαι

data.ref: 372 : but this came to be omitted, and
Pl. Grg. 489a, etc.: rarely with I pers.,

data.quote: ὁποῖα κισσὸς δρυός, ὅπως τῆσδʼ ἕξομαι

children.definition: πῶς; in dialogue, A καὶ πῶς; B ὅπως; [do you ask] how? Ar. Eq. 128; A πῶς με χρὴ καλεῖν; B ὅπως; Id. Nu. 677, cf. Pl. 139.
οὐκ οἶδα παιδείας ὅπως ἔχει καὶ δικαιοσύνης in the matter of . . , Pl. Grg. 470e, cf. R. 389c.

data.quote: οὐκ οἶδα παιδείας ὅπως ἔχει καὶ δικαιοσύνης

children.label: IV
children.definition: direct questions, how? ἔπραξας ὅπως; Jul. Ep. 82p.106B.-C.; cf. ὅστις.

children.label: V
children.definition: anyhow, τὸ οὐδʼ ὅ. the expression ‘not at all’, Pl. Tht. 183b (v.l. οὐδʼ οὕτως).

children.label: B
children.definition: that, in order that, the original notion of modality being merged in that of purpose or design, cf. ἵνα, with which it is sts. interchanged, Antipho 1.23 and 24, And. 3.14, Lycurg. 119 sq.:—in early Att. Inscrr. only ὅπως ἄν is used, IG 1(2).39.19, al. ; ὅπως without ἄν only once in cent. iv B. C., ib. 2(2).226.42 (343 B.C.), after which it becomes gradually prevalent:
subj.,

children.label: a
children.definition: subj. or imper., τὸν δὲ μνηστῆρες . . λοχῶσιν, ὅπως ἀπὸ φῦλον ὄληται Od. 14.181, cf. A. Ch. 873, S. Ph. 238, El. 457, X. Mem. 2.10.2, etc.

data.quote: τὸν δὲ μνηστῆρες . . λοχῶσιν, ὅπως ἀπὸ φῦλον ὄληται

children.label: b
children.definition: ἵνα B. I.1b), when there is no pf. form, or when the aor. represents the pf., ξυνελέγημεν ἐνθάδε, ὅ. προμελετήσωμεν we were convened, i. e. we have met in assembly, Ar. Ec. 117 ; παρήλθομεν . . , ὅπως μὴ χεῖρον βουλεύσησθε Th. 1.73 ; also when the occurrence purposed is regarded from the point of view of the person purposing, ἦλθον πρεσβευσόμενοι, ὅπως μὴ σφίσι . . τὸ αὐτῶν [ναυτικὸν] ἐμπόδιον γένηται ib. 31, cf. 57, 65, etc.: sts. the opt. and subj. appear in consecutive clauses, φρυκτοὺς παρεσκευασμένους ἐς αὐτὸ τοῦτο, ὅπως ἀσαφῆ τὰ σημεῖα . . ᾖ καὶ μὴ βοηθοῖεν Id. 3.22, cf. 6.96, 7.17.

data.quote: φρυκτοὺς παρεσκευασμένους ἐς αὐτὸ τοῦτο, ὅπως ἀσαφῆ τὰ σημεῖα . . ᾖ καὶ μὴ βοηθοῖεν

children.definition: πὰρ δέ οἱ αὐτὸς ἔστη, ὅπως . . κῆρας ἀλάλκοι Il. 21.548 ; more freq. in Od., as 13.319, 14.312, 18.160, 22.472; so in S. OT 1005, OC 1305, X. Cyr. 1.4.25, Pl. Ti. 77e, etc.: after historical pres., πέμπει τούσδʼ ὅπως κτείνοιεν A. Pers. 450 ; ἡγεμόνα πέμπει ὅπως ἄγοι X. An. 4.7.19 : after opt., ἔλθοι . . ὅ. γένοιτο A. Eu. 297, cf. S. Aj. 1221 (lyr.).

data.quote: πὰρ δέ οἱ αὐτὸς ἔστη, ὅπως . . κῆρας ἀλάλκοι

children.label: a
children.definition: εἴθʼ εἶχε φωνὴν ἔμφρονʼ ἀγγέλου δίκην, ὅ. δίφροντις οὖσα μὴ ʼκινυσσόμην A. Ch. 196, cf. S. El. 1134: rare in Prose, ἐδεξάμην ἃν . . φράσαι πρὸς ὑμᾶς . . , ὅ . . . προῄδετε And. 2.21 ; τίς οὐκ ἂν . . ταῦτα ἐδήλωσεν, ὅ . . . ταῦτα ἠλέγχθη; D. 36.20; οὐκοῦν ἐχρῆν σε Πηγάσου ζεῦξαι πτερόν, ὅ. ἐφαίνου τοῖς θεοῖς τραγικώτερος Ar. Pax 135; τί . . οὐκ ἔρριψʼ ἐμαυτὴν . . ὅ. ἀπηλλάγην; A. Pr. 749.

data.quote: εἴθʼ εἶχε φωνὴν ἔμφρονʼ ἀγγέλου δίκην, ὅ. δίφροντις οὖσα μὴ ʼκινυσσόμην
ἐδεξάμην ἃν . . φράσαι πρὸς ὑμᾶς . . , ὅ . . . προῄδετε
οὐκοῦν ἐχρῆν σε Πηγάσου ζεῦξαι πτερόν, ὅ. ἐφαίνου τοῖς θεοῖς τραγικώτερος

children.label: b
children.definition: fut., θέλγει, ὅ. Ἰθάκης ἐπιλήσεται (= φραζομένη ὅπως ἐ.) Od. 1.57, cf. Il. 1.136 ; [χρὴ] ἀναβιβάζειν ἐπὶ τὸν τροχὸν τοὺς ἀπογραφέντας, ὅ. μὴ πρότερον νὺξ ἔσται And. 1.43 ; ἐμισθώσατο τοῦτον . . , ὅ. συνερεῖ D. 19.316 : sts. fut. ind. and aor. subj. are conjoined, σιγᾶθʼ, ὅ. μὴ πεύσεταί τις, ὦ τέκνα, γλώσσης χάριν δὲ πάντʼ ἀπαγγείλῃ τάδε A. Ch. 265.

data.quote: [χρὴ] ἀναβιβάζειν ἐπὶ τὸν τροχὸν τοὺς ἀπογραφέντας, ὅ. μὴ πρότερον νὺξ ἔσται
σιγᾶθʼ, ὅ. μὴ πεύσεταί τις, ὦ τέκνα, γλώσσης χάριν δὲ πάντʼ ἀπαγγείλῃ τάδε

children.label: II
children.definition: ὅπως c. subj. is sts. used after Verbs of will and endeavour, instead of the inf., λίσσεσθαι . . ὅ. νημερτέα εἴπῃ Od. 3.19 ; αἰτεῖσθαι ὅ. μὴ καταψηφίσησθε Antipho 1.12 ; δεήσεται . . , ὅ. δίκην μὴ δῷ ib. 23 ; ὅ. μὴ ἀποθάνῃ ἠντεβόλει Lys. 1.29 ; παρακελεύεσθε ὑμῖν αὐτοῖς ὅ . . . ἐξίητε Lycurg. 127 ( ἔξιτε Rehdantz): with ἄν, δεῖταί μου σφόδρα ὅπως ἂν οἰκουρῇ Ar. Ach. 1060, cf. Hdt. 2.126, 3.44 ; διεκελεύετο ὅπως ἂν . . ἐγγράφωσί με Is. 7.27; so δεῖ σʼ ὅ. δείξεις (for δεῖξαι), S. Aj. 556, may be expld. as ellipsis for δεῖ σʼ ὁρᾶν (σκοπεῖν) ὅπως, cf. Id. Ph. 55 ; δεῖ σʼ ὅπως . . μηδὲν διοίσεις . . Cratin. 108.

data.quote: ἄν, δεῖταί μου σφόδρα ὅπως ἂν οἰκουρῇ

data.ref: S. Aj. 556, may be expld. as ellipsis for

children.label: II
children.definition: Pl. Hipparch. 232b ; so ὅπως δήποτε D. 3.7, 18.261 ; φύσει ἢ ὅ. Arist. EN 1114b14:— also ὁπωσδηποτοῦν, Dsc. Ther. 3, Eustr. in EN 23.3.

in any way whatever, ever so little, Th. 1.77, 7.60, Isoc. 2.5, etc.; οὐδʼ ὁπωσοῦν in no way whatever, Th. 7.49, Isoc. 12.2, etc.:—so ὁπωστιοῦν, Th. 8.71, Pl. Phdr. 258c ; οὐδʼ ὁπωστιοῦν Id. R. 579e, Phd. 61c, al. ; μηδὲ ὁ. Id. Tht. 179b.
of a boundary: ὁραία τεκτονική, = gruma, Gloss.; cf. ὁριαῖος.

that which is seen, visible object, sight, Arist. de An. 428a16, EN 1173b18, al. ; sight, spectacle, X. Cyr. 3.3.66 ; vision during sleep, dream, LXX Ge. 15.1, al., PGoodsp.Cair. 3.5 (iii B. C.), UPZ 78.37 (ii B. C.), SIG 1128 ( Delos, ii/i B. C.), Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(1).249; ἐν τοῖς ὁράμασι τοῦ θεοῦ Aristid. Or. 42(6).8 codd. ( ἰάμασι cj. Keil).

children.label: II
children.definition: device, plan, τὸ ὅ. Θάλεω (Camer. εὕρημα) Arist. Pol. 1259a31, cf. D. Prooem. 55.1.
vision, νυκτός Aq. Jb. 4.13 (pl.).
visionary, Sm. Is. 56.10.

definition: ὄραμνος, ὁ, later form of ὀρόδαμνος, Nic. Al. 154, AP 5.291.1 ( Agath.).

children.definition: = Lat. orarium, kerchief, scarf, Sammelb. 7033.42 (v A. D.).

seeing, the act of sight, Demad. 3, Arist. EN 1174a14, Men. 123, etc. ; distd. as the ἐνέργεια or act from ὄψις (the sense or faculty), Arist. de An. 426a13, cf. 428a7; but, power of sight, SIG 1141 ( Thrace).
eyes, τὰς ὁ. ἐκκόπτειν D.S. 2.6, cf. D.H. 8.45, Plu. Util. 2.88d : metaph., as title of the daughter-goddess of the Sun, ὅρασιν αὑτοῦ (sc. τοῦ Ἡλίου) OGI 56.56 ( Canopus, iii B. C.).

data.ref: Plu. Util. 2.88d : metaph., as title of the daughter-goddess of the Sun,

children.label: II
children.definition: a vision, LXX Jl. 2.28, Act.Ap. 2.17 (pl.).

children.label: III
children.definition: appearance, ὅμοιος ὁράσει λίθῳ ἰάσπιδι Apoc. 4.3; ὁ μεταμορφούμενος ἐν ταῖς ὁράσεσιν PLeid.W. 13.36.
one must see, Theol.Ar. 38.
= sq., Hsch. s.v. ὀπτήρ.
beholder, LXX Jb. 34.21, Plu. Nic. 19.
keep in view, aim at, οἰκείου σκοποῦ Sever. Clyst. p.13 D.

able to see, τὰ ὄμματα ὁ. τῶν πόρρωθεν Arist. GA 781a1 ; of persons, Ph. 1.336, al.; -κὴ διάνοια Id. 2.19 : abs., ὁρατικὸν τὸ ὁρᾶν, καὶ ὁρατὸν τὸ δυνατὸν ὁρᾶσθαι Arist. Metaph. 1049b15; τὸ ὁρατικόν the power of sight, Id. GA 716a30 ; ἡ ὁ. δύναμις Plu. Def.orac. 2.433d; -κῶν πόνοι pains in the eyes, Vett.Val. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(1).168, cf. Nech. ap. Vett.Val. 279.33. Adv. -κῶς S.E. M. 7.355.

data.quote: ὁρατικὸν τὸ ὁρᾶν, καὶ ὁρατὸν τὸ δυνατὸν ὁρᾶσθαι

children.label: II
children.definition: of or for the sight, θεραπεύματα D.L. 8.89.
to be seen, visible, Hp. Praec. 14 : joined with ἁπτός, Pl. Ti. 28b, al.; opp. νοητός, Id. R. 509d, 524c, etc.; cf. ὁρατικός. Adv. -τῶς Aen.Tact. 23.4, Plu. An.procr. 2.1029e.

definition: Ὀράτριος, epith. of Zeus in Crete, GDI 5039.11 (ii B. C.), al.

children.definition: inspect closely, Aesar. ap. Stob. 1.49.27.

definition: ὁράω, contr. ὁρῶ even in Il. 3.234, Ep. ὁρόω 5.244, etc.; Aeol. ὄρημι (q. v.); Ion. ὁρέω Hdt. 1.80, etc., 2 sg. ὁρῇς Herod. 2.67, al., 3 sg. ὁρῇ Hp. Carn. 17, Vid.Ac. I; inf. ὁρῆν Democr. 11, Hp. Carn. 2 (but 2 sg. ὁρᾷς Archil. 87, 3 sg. ὁρᾷ Semon. 7.80, cf. κατορᾷ Hdt. 2.38; 1 pl. ὁρῶμεν Id. 5.40; 3 pl. ὁρῶσι ( ἐπ-) Id. 1.124; inf. ὁρᾶν ib. 33, 2.64): the forms ὁρῇς, ὁρῇ, ὁρῆν (exc. when found in Dor., as IG 42(1).122.2, 15,47 ( Epid., iv B. C.); impf. 3 sg. ἑώρη ib. 28,70) seem to imply ὁρή-ω (cf. ὄρημι), but ὁρᾷ, ὁρῶμεν, ὁρῶσι, etc. imply ὁρᾰ-ω: Att. impf. ἑώρων Th. 1.51, Ar. Pl. 713, Nu. 354, ( ἐ-) SIG 344.110 ( Teos, iv B. C.); Ion. 3 sg. ὥρα Hdt. 1.11, 3.72, 1 pl. ὡρῶμεν (v.l. ὁρῶμεν) Id. 2.131, 2 pl. ὡρᾶτε Id. 7.8.β. 3 pl. ὥρων Id. 4.3, etc.; Ep. 3 sg. ὅρα Il. 16.646, cf. ὄρημι: pf. ἑόρᾱκα, a form required by the metre in many passages, as Ar. Th. 32, 33, Av. 1573, Pl. 98, 1045, Eup. 181.3, Alex. 272.1, Men. Epit. 166, Pk. 270, Bato 5.11, etc., whereas the metre never requires ἑώρακα; whence ἑόρακα, -άκη ought always to be restored in early Att. writers, though ἑώρακα was used in later Gr., PPetr. 2p.55 (iii B. C.), SIG 685.74 (ii B. C.), UPZ 119.43 (ii B. C.), cf. Theognost. Can. 150 ( ἑώρακε<ν> is prob. in Men. 5 D.): ἑωρ- in the impf. prob. comes from ἠ- ϝορ- (with a long form of the augment, cf. ἠειδ- ( ᾐδ-) in impf. of οἶδα, while ἑορ- in the pf. comes from ϝε-ϝορ-, v. infr.: Ion. pf. ὁρώρηκα Herod. 4.77, al., also ὥρηκα ib. 40 ; Dor. pf. part. ὡρακυῖα IG 42(1).122.6 ( Epid., iv B. C.); 1 sg. ὥρακα Baillet Inscr. des tombeaux des rois 1210: an aor. 1 ἐσορήσαις only f.l. in Orph. Fr. 247.16:— Med. ὁράομαι, contr. ὁρῶμαι even in Il. 13.99 ; Ep. 2 sg. ὅρηαι Od. 14.343 (v. ὄρημι): impf. ἑωρώμην, also ὡρώμην ( προ-) Act.Ap. 2.25, Ep. 3 sg. ὁρᾶτο Il. 1.56:— Pass., pf. ἑώραμαι Isoc. 15.110, D. 54.16 : aor. ἑωράθην only in late Prose, D.S. 20.6 ; inf. ὁρᾱθῆναι Arist. MA 699b19, Pl. Def. 411b, Luc. Jud.Voc. 6, etc.: fut. ὁραθήσομαι Gal. UP 10.12 : verb. Adj. ὁρᾱτός, ὁρᾱτέον (qq. v.).— Hom. uses contr. forms, as ὁρῶ, ὁρᾷς, ὁρᾷ, ὅρα, ὁρᾶν, ὁρῶν, ὁρῶμαι, ὁρᾶται, ὁρᾶσθαι, ὁρώμενος, as well as lengthd. Ep. ὁρόω, ὁράᾳς, ὁράασθαι, ὁρόων, 2 pl. opt. ὁρόῳτε Il. 4.347, etc. ; besides these forms from ὁρα- ( ὁρη-) we have

children.label: II
children.definition: ὀπ- (v. ὄψ) the only fut. in use, ὄψομαι, always in act. sense, Il. 24.704, and Att., Ep. 2 sg. ὄψεαι 8.471, Od. 24.511: a rare aor. 1 ἐπ-όψατο in Pi. Fr. 88.6 (for ἐπιώψατο, v. ἐπιόψομαι); subj. ὄψησθε Ev.Luc. 13.28 (where the v.l. ὄψεσθε may be right): pf. ὄπωπα Il. 6.124, Od. 21.94, Emp. 109, Hdt. 3.37, 63, Hp. Art. 1, Carn. 17; Trag. and Com., as A. Eu. 57, S. Ant. 6, al., Ar. Lys. 1157, 1225, never in Att. Prose: plpf. 3 sg. ὀπώπει Od. 21.123, ὀπώπεε Hdt. 5.92.ζʹ; ὀπώπεσαν Id. 7.125 :— Pass., aor. 1 ὤφθην S. Ant. 709, E. Hec. 970, Th. 4.73, etc. ; opt. ( Ion.) ὀφθείησαν Hdt. 8.7 ; part. ὀφθείς, inf. ὀφθῆναι, Id. 1.9, 10 (for ἐπι-οφθέντας, v. ἐπιόψομαι): fut. ὀφθήσομαι S. Tr. 452, E. HF 1155, And. 2.10, Lys. 3.34 : pf. ὦμμαι Is. Fr. 165, ὦψαι D. 18.263, ὦπται A. Pr. 998, D. 24.66; cf. ὀπτέον.

children.label: III
children.definition: ϝιδ- are formed aor. Act. εἶδον, inf. ἰδεῖν : aor. Med. εἰδόμην, inf. ἰδέσθαι : pf. with pres. sense οἶδα I know, inf. εἰδέναι : verb. Adj. ἰστέος (for these tenses, v. οἶδα). ( ὁρ- prob. from ϝορ-, as indicated by the impf. and pf. forms ; cf. βῶροι (i.e. ϝῶροι), Engl. (a)ware.)

children.label: I
children.definition: see, look, freq. in Hom.; εἴς τι or εἴς τινα to or at a thing or person, Il. 24.633, Od. 20.373, al., E. Fr. 607 ; εἰς τὸν πράττοντα Arist. Po. 1460a14 :— Med., Od. 5.439, Hes. Op. 534, Fr. 188 ; but ἔς τινα ὁρᾶν to be of so-and-soʼs party, Philostr. VS 1.18 ; εἰς τὴν Ἀττάλου καθαίρεσιν εἶδεν aimed at . . , Zos. 6.12 ; for κατʼ αὐτοὺς αἰὲν ὅρα Il. 16.646, Τροίην κατὰ πᾶσαν ὁρᾶται 24.291, cf. καθοράω II ; ὁρόων ἐπʼ ἀπείρονα πόντον looking over the sea, 1.350 ; ὁρᾶν πρός τι look towards, ἀκρωτήριον τὸ πρὸς Μέγαρα ὁρῶν Th. 2.93, cf. AP 7.496 ( Simon., cj.) ; πρὸς πλοῦν ὁρᾷ looks to sail (i.e. is ready), E. IA [1624]; ὁ. ἐπὶ τὴν προδοσίαν D.S. 36.3 ; πρὸς σπονδάς Id. 33.1.

have sight, opp. μὴ ὁρᾶν, to be blind, S. Aj. 84 ; ὅσʼ ἂν λέγωμεν, πάνθʼ ὁρῶντα λέξομεν [though I am blind,] my words shall have eyes, i.e. shall be to the purpose, Id. OC 74 ; ἐν σκότῳ . . οὓς μὲν οὐκ ἔδει ὀψοίαθʼ, i.e. should be blind, Id. OT 1274; ἀμβλύτερον ὁ., opp. ὀξύτερον βλέπειν, Pl. R. 596a ; ἐπὶ σμικρὸν ὁ. to be short- sighted, Id. Tht. 174e; ὁ. βραχύ τι Id. R. 488b.

see to, look to, i.e. take or give heed, Il. 10.239 ; ὁ. εἰς γλῶσσαν . . ἀνδρός look to, pay heed to, Sol. 11.7, cf. A. Supp. 104 (lyr.): freq. in imper., like βλέπε, folld. by a dependent clause, ὅρα ὅπως . . Ar. Ec. 300, cf. Th. 5.27; ὅρα εἰ . . see whether . . , A. Pr. 997, Pl. Phd. 118a, etc.; also ὅρα μὴ . . S. Ph. 30, 519, etc.; ὅρα τί ποιεῖς ib. 589 ; πῶς . . ὑπερδικεῖς, ὅρα A. Eu. 652.

data.ref: A. Supp. 104 (lyr.): freq. in imper., like βλέπε, folld. by a dependent clause,

children.definition: ὁρᾷς; ὁρᾶτε; seeʼst thou? dʼye see? parenthetically, esp. in explanations, Ar. Nu. 355, Th. 490, etc.; ὡς ὁρᾷς S. El. 1114, Tr. 365 ; also ὁρᾷς; at the beginning of a sentence, Id. El. 628, E. Andr. 87 ; ἀλλʼ—ὁρᾷς; but, do you see . . ?, Pl. Prt. 336b; ὁρᾷς οὖν . . ὅτι Id. Grg. 475e ; οὐχ ὁρᾷς; ironically, D. 18.232.
look so and so, δεινὸν ὁρῶν ὄσσοισι Hes. Sc. 426 ; ὁρᾶν ἀλκάν Pi. O. 9.111 ; ἔαρ ὁρόωσα Νύχεια Theoc. 13.45 ; also ἡδέως ὁρᾶν look pleasant, E. IA 1122: c. acc., κακῶς ὁρᾶν τινα Philostr. VA 7.42.

children.label: II
children.definition: see an object, behold, perceive, observe, c. acc., freq. in Hom., etc.: pf. ὄπωπα exclusively in this sense, Il. 2.799, Od. 21.94, etc. ; ὀφθαλμοῖσιν or ἐν ὀφθαλμοῖσιν ὁρᾶν to see with or before the eyes, Il. 24.392, Od. 8.459, etc. ; αἰεὶ τέρμʼ ὁρόων always keeping it in sight, keeping his eye on it, Il. 23.323 ; φίλως χʼ ὁρόῳτε καὶ εἰ δέκα πύργοι Ἀχαιῶν . . μαχοίατο, i.e. δέκα πύργους, εἰ μαχοίατο, 4.347 ; ὁ. τινά look to (for aid), D. 45.64 : in signfs. I and II combined, οὐχ ὁρᾷς ὁρῶν τάδε; A. Ag. 1623, cf. D. 25.89.

data.ref: D. 45.64 : in signfs. I and II combined,

children.label: b
children.definition: ζώει καὶ ὁρᾷ φάος ἠελίοιο, poet. for ζῆν, like βλέπειν, Il. 18.61, Od. 4.833, etc.; so φῶς ὁρᾶν S. OT 375, E. Or. 1523, Alc. 691:— in Med., φέγγος ὁρᾶσθαι Id. Andr. 113 (eleg.); so ὁρᾶν alone, τὰ γὰρ φθιτῶν τοῖς ὁρῶσι κόσμος Id. Supp. 78 (lyr.).

data.quote: τὰ γὰρ φθιτῶν τοῖς ὁρῶσι κόσμος

children.label: c
children.definition: οὐχ ὁράᾳς οἷος . . ; Il. 21.108 ; ὁρᾷς ἡμᾶς, ὅσοι ἐσμέν; Pl. R. 327c ; οὐχ ὁρᾷς ὅτι ἥμαρτες; A. Pr. 261, cf. 325, 951 ; Διὸς . . οὐχ ὁρῶ μῆτιν ὅπᾳ φύγοιμʼ ἄν ib. 906 (lyr.); ἴδεσθέ μʼ οἷα . . πάσχω ib. 92.

children.label: d
children.definition: part., καπνὸν . . ὁρῶμεν ἀπὸ χθονὸς ἀΐσσοντα we see it rising, Od. 10.99; ὁρῶν ἐμαυτὸν ὧδε προυσελούμενον seeing myself thus insulted, A. Pr. 438, cf. 70, 384, al.; ὁρῶ σε κρύπτοντα . . see you hiding . . , E. Hec. 342 ; so ὁρῶ μʼ ἔργον ἐξειργασμένην I see that I have done, S. Tr. 706 ; cf. infr. 4b ; rarely in reference to the subject, ὁρῶ μὲν ἐξαμαρτάνων (= ὅτι ἐξαμαρτάνω) E. Med. 350:—so in Med., ἄνδρα διωκόμενον . . ὁρῶμαι Il. 22.169, cf. A. Pr. 896 (lyr.): also c. inf., ἑώρων οὐκέτι οἷόν τε εἶναι . . Th. 8.60.

data.ref: S. Tr. 706 ; cf. infr. 4b ; rarely in reference to the subject,

children.label: e
children.definition: οὐδεὶς Σωκράτους οὐδὲν ἀσεβὲς . . οὔτε πράττοντος εἶδεν οὔτε λέγοντος ἤκουσεν (where the Constr. is suggested by the use of ἤκουσεν) X. Mem. 1.1.11 ; μέχρι βορῆος ἀπαστράψαντος ἴδηαι Arat. 430.
see to, ἴδε πῶμα Od. 8.443 ; look out for, provide, τινί τι S. Aj. 1165 (anap.), Theoc. 15.2 ; πρόβατον εἰς ὁλοκάρπωσιν LXX Ge. 22.8.

inf. is used after an Adj., δεινὸς ἰδεῖν Sol. 13.6 ; εὐφεγγὴς ἰδεῖν A. Pers. 387, cf. 398, Ch. 174, 176, al. (cf. ὁράω εἶδον A.I.1 a) ; ἐχθίστου . . ὁρᾶν most hateful to behold, S. Aj. 818 ; ὦ πάτερ δύσμοιρʼ ὁρᾶν Id. OC 327 ; ὁρᾶν στυγνὸς ἦν X. An. 2.6.9:— Med. or Pass., αἰσχρὸς ὁρᾶσθαι Id. Cyn. 3.3 : with an Adv., μὴ διχορρόπως ἰδεῖν A. Ag. 349 : with a Subst., ἄνδρα τευχηστὴν ἰδεῖν Id. Th. 644 : with a Verb, πρέπουσι . . ἰδεῖν Id. Supp. 720, cf. S. OT 792.

Med. is used by Poets like Act., Il. 13.99, A. Pers. 179, Ch. 407 (lyr.), S. Ant. 594 (lyr.), Tr. 306, Cratin. 138, etc., v. supr. II.1 b, c: but in Prose Med. occurs only in compds., as προ-ορῶμαι: for the imper. ἰδοῦ, ἰδού, v. ἰδοῦ.

children.label: b
children.definition: Pass. is used by Hom.; in Att. the Pass. has the sense to be seen, A. Pr. 998, Eu. 411, etc.: c. part., ὤφθημεν ὄντες ἄθλιοι was seen in my wretchedness, E. IT 933 ; ὀφθήσεται διώκων he will prove to be . . , Pl. Phdr. 239c, cf. Smp. 178e; τὰ ὁρώμενα all that is seen, things visible, like τὰ ὁρατά, Id. Prm. 130a.

children.label: III
children.definition: discern, perceive, S. El. 945, etc.; so blind Oedipus says, φωνῇ γὰρ ὁρῶ, τὸ φατιζόμενον I see by sound, as the saying is, Id. OC 138 (anap.); ἂν οἴνου . . ὀσμὴν ἴδωσιν Alex. 222.4 ; cf. supr. I.4, δέρκομαι I.2.

data.ref: S. El. 945, etc.; so blind Oedipus says,

children.label: IV
children.definition: see visions, ὁ ἀληθινῶς ὁρῶν LXX Nu. 24.3, 15 :— Pass., appear in a vision, ὤφθη ἄγγελος πρὸς τὴν γυναῖκα ib. Jd. 13.3.

children.label: V
children.definition: interview, ἐμνήσθης μοι ἰδεῖν τὸν κεραμέα περὶ τῶν κεραμίων you told me to see the potter about the jars, PCair.Zen. 264 (iii B.C.).
malum orbiculatum, Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 3.80f, Dsc. 1.115.4.
make a preparation of vetch, PBouriant 13.3 (i A.D.).
vetch-sellerʼs shop, POxy. 1323 (vi A.D.).
vetch-seller, POxy. 1432.6 (iii A.D.), 1037.4 (v A.D.), etc.
the right to sell vetch, PBouriant 13.2 (i A.D.).
POxy. 1323 (vi A.D.), PKlein.Form. 31 (vi/vii A.D.).

soften, knead, temper, A. Fr. 451 F ; πηλὸν ὀργάζειν χεροῖν S. Fr. 482, cf. 510, 787 ; πηλὸν . . ὄργασον Ar. Av. 839, cf. Eup. 248 ; κλωστῆρσι χειρῶν ὀργάσας κατήνυσε σειραῖα δεσμά S. Fr. 25 ; ὀ. λίπεϊ . . θρόνα Nic. Al. 155 ; of the action of fire, τὰ ἐντὸς καθάπερ ὀ. Arist. Pr. 869b27:— Med., φύλλα ξηρὰ . . ἐλαίῳ ὀργάσασθαι Hp. Mul. 2.206, cf. Archil. ap. Phot. p.64 R., Nic. Th. 652 ; dub. cj. in Alciphr. 3.7 :— Pass., ὅταν ὁ κηρὸς μετρίως ὠργασμένος ᾖ has been well kneaded, Pl. Tht. 194c (restored from Tim. Lex. and Suid. for εἰργ-). Cf. ὀργάω.

data.quote: κλωστῆρσι χειρῶν ὀργάσας κατήνυσε σειραῖα δεσμά

children.definition: make angry, enrage, καὶ γὰρ ἂν πέτρου φύσιν σύ γʼ ὀργάνειας S. OT 335.

data.quote: καὶ γὰρ ἂν πέτρου φύσιν σύ γʼ ὀργάνειας

children.label: II
children.definition: grow or be angry, Id. Tr. 552 ; τινι with one, E. Alc. 1106 ; cf. ὁρμαίνω II.2.
fistularius, Gloss.

serving as organs or instruments, instrumental, esp. of the several parts of the body, Arist. PA 646b26: distd. from τὰ κινητικά, Id. GA 742b10 ; τὰ ὀ. μέρη Id. EN 1110a16, cf. PA 661b29, GA 739b14, al. ; αἱ ὀ. [ἀρεταί], of a slave, Id. Pol. 1259b23 ; ὀ. καὶ μηχανικαὶ κατασκευαί Plu. QConv. 2.718f; esp. of war-engines, ἡ ὀ. βία D.S. 17.43 ; ὀ. κατασκευαί Onos. 42.3 : metaph., ὁ ὀ. εἰς πλήθη λόγος speech which is brought to bear on the mob, Plu. Cat.Mi. 4 ; of musicians, practical, opp. λογικοί (theoretical), Id. QConv. 2.657e ; ἐποιεῖτο ἀκροάσεις λογικάς τε καὶ ὀ. Supp.Epigr. 2.184.6 ( Tanagra, ii B.C.) ; so of surgeons, τῶν ὀ. οἱ διασημότεροι PMed.Lond. 155.2.13 ; ἡ ὀ. (sc. τέχνη) Plu. Marc. 14 ; but ὀργανικός, = λογικός, logical, Elias in Porph. 115.17. Adv. -κῶς by way of instruments, Arist. EN 1099b28; -κώτερον making more use of instruments, Simp. in Cael. 504.33 ; τὸ κινοῦν ὀ. Arist. de An. 433b21.

data.quote: ἐποιεῖτο ἀκροάσεις λογικάς τε καὶ ὀ.

definition: ὀργάνιον, τό, Dim. of ὄργανον, AP 5.190 ( Mel.), M.Ant. 10.38.

children.definition: waterworks-engineer, PLond. 3.1177.72,80 (pl., ii A.D.).
musician, instrumentalist, Olymp. in Alc. p.202 C.
engineer, PLond. 1.125.20 (iv A.D.), PLips. 97 vii 13 (iv A. D.),
drawing up of tables, κανονικαὶ -θεσίαι Vett.Val. 150.23.
tabulate, [ζῴδια] Vett.Val. 295.24 ( Pass.).

instrument, implement, tool, for making or doing a thing, S. Tr. 905, cf. ἀθηρόβρωτος; λογχοποιῶν ὄργανα E. Ba. 1208, cf. Ion 1030 ; πολεμικὰ ὅπλα τε καὶ ὄργανα Pl. R. 374d, cf. Lg. 956a ; ὄ. without any Adj., engine of war, Ctes. Fr. 81 ; τὰ ναυτικὰ ὄ. tackle, Pl. Plt. 298d ; ὄ. ὅσα περὶ γεωργίαν Id. R. 370d ; ὄνομα ἄρα διδασκαλικόν τί ἐστιν ὄ. Id. Cra. 388b ; ὄργανα χρόνων or χρόνου, of the stars, Id. Ti. 41e, 42d ; ὄ. κυβευτικά Aeschin. 1.59; of a person, ἁπάντων ἀεὶ κακῶν ὄ. S. Aj. 380 (lyr.).

data.quote: ὄνομα ἄρα διδασκαλικόν τί ἐστιν ὄ.

children.definition: organ of sense or apprehension, τὰ περὶ τὰς αἰσθήσεις ὄ. Pl. R. 508b ; τὸ ὄ. ᾧ καταμανθάνει ἕκαστος ib. 518c, cf. Tht. 185c, al.; διʼ ἀμυδρῶν ὀ. θεᾶσθαί τι Id. Phdr. 250b, cf. Ti. 45b, Epicur. Nat. 11.6, 7.

children.label: b
children.definition: Arist. PA 642a11, 645b14, GA 716a24, Phld. Mus. pp. 71,96 K., Gal. 10.47 ; the hand is called ὄργανον ὀργάνων or ὄ. πρὸ ὀργάνων, Arist. de An. 432a2, PA 687a21 ; τὰ πορευτικὰ ὄ. the organs of locomotion, Id. GA 732b28; ὄ. πρὸς ἐργασίαν τῆς τροφῆς the digestive organs, ib. 788b24 ; τὸ ὄ. τὸ περὶ τὴν ἀναπνοήν the respiratory organ, Id. PA 664a29 ; τὰ ὄ. τὰ χρήσιμα πρὸς τὴν ὀχείαν Id. HA 500a15 ; of plants, Id. de An. 412b1, PA 656a2.

data.quote: τὰ ὄ. τὰ χρήσιμα πρὸς τὴν ὀχείαν

children.definition: musical instrument, Simon. 31, f.l. in A. Fr. 57.1 ; ὁ μὲν διʼ ὀργάνων ἐκήλει ἀνθρώπους, of Marsyas, Pl. Smp. 215c ; ἄνευ ὀργάνων ψιλοῖς λόγοις ibid., cf. Plt. 268b ; ὄ. πολύχορδα Id. R. 399c, al.; μετʼ ᾠδῆς καί τινων ὀργάνων Phld. Mus. p.98K.; of the pipe, Melanipp. 2, Telest. 1.2.
surgical instrument, Hp. Off. 2, X. Cyr. 5.3.47, Pl. Plt. 298c.

children.label: II
children.definition: work or product, μελίσσης κηρόπλαστον ὄ. S. Fr. 398.5 ; λαϊνέοισιν Ἀμφίονος ὀ., of the walls of Thebes, E. Ph. 115 (lyr.).

children.label: III
children.definition: instrument of philosophy, ἡ λογικὴ πραγματεία ὀργάνου χώραν ἔχει ἐν φιλοσοφίᾳ Alex.Aphr. in Top. 74.29, cf. Phlp. in APr. 6.23 ; πᾶσα τεχνικὴ διδασκαλία ὑπὸ τὸ λογικὸν ὄ. ἀνάγεται Sch.D.T. p.161 H.; but τὸ ὄ. as title of Aristotleʼs collected logical writings lacks authority.

data.quote: ἡ λογικὴ πραγματεία ὀργάνου χώραν ἔχει ἐν φιλοσοφίᾳ

children.label: IV
children.definition: instrument or table of calculations, εἰσῆλθον εἰς τὸ προκείμενον ὄργανον Vett.Val. 20.12.

children.label: V
children.definition: ὄ. χλούνιον, = ἠρύγγιον, Ps.- Dsc. 3.21.
furnish with organs, c. acc., Syrian. in Metaph. 186.10.
instrument-making, Ti.Locr. 101e, Ph. 1.29, 2.94, al.; apparatus, Heliod. ap. Orib. 44.23.43, 49.20.8, 49.22.15 ; anatomical structure, Porph. Gaur. 13.4.
manufacture of war-engines, Ph. Bel. 49.6.
maker of instruments or engines, D.S. 17.43, IG 14.1717 ( Rome), Ptol. Tetr. 180.
working, forming, ὀργάνη χείρ E. Andr. 1014 (s.v.l.): Ὀργάνη as epith. of Athena, BCH 52.52 ( Thasos, v B.C.), IG 2.1329, Hsch., Phot. ; cf. ἐργάνη.
to be organized, πρὸς τὴν τῆς ἀληθείας γνῶσιν S.E. M. 7.126, cf. Porph. Abst. 3.8.
organization, arrangement, Porph. Abst. 3.7.

any well-watered, fertile spot of land, meadow-land, partially wooded, with or without cultivated fields, IG 1(2).325.18, E. Ba. 340, 445, El. 1162 (lyr.), X. Cyn. 9.2, AP 6.41 ( Agath.); ὑπʼ ὀργάδα τὰν Ἀχέροντος Hymn.Is. in Not.Arch. 4.212.

rich tract of land sacred to the gods: such a tract between Athens and Megara, sacred to Demeter and Persephone, was specially called ἡ ὀ. or ἱερὰ ὀ., D. 13.32, Call. Fr. 35 P., Plu. Per. 30, Paus. 3.4.2, cf. IG 2(2).204.8,16 ; similarly perh. ὀργή in Herod. 4.46 (s.v.l.).
orgasm, Sch. Hp. Hum. 3.
a place of ὄργια, Nic. Al. 8.

definition: ὀργάω, mostly in pres.: pf. part. ὀργηκότες (v.l. ὡρμ-) occurs in J. AJ 17.9.2 : plpf. Pass. ὤργητο in Hsch., v. II fin.

children.label: I
children.definition: to be getting ready to bear, growing ripe for something, of soil, Thphr. CP 3.2.6 ; of trees, συμβαίνει . . τὰ . . δένδρα ὀργᾶν πρὸς τὴν βλάστησιν ib. 1.6.2 ; ὀργᾷ [ἡ σμῖλαξ] πρὸς τὴν ἄνθησιν Plu. QConv. 2.647f; and of fruit, swell as it ripens, ὁ καρπὸς πεπαίνεται καὶ ὀργᾷ Hdt. 4.199 : so c. inf., ὀργᾷ ἀμᾶσθαι grows ripe for cutting, ibid., cf. X. Oec. 19.19 ; of a wound, ὀργᾶν φαίνεται appears turgid, Hp. Fract. 28, cf. Aph. 1.22.

children.label: II
children.definition: swell with lust, wax wanton, be rampant, Ar. Lys. 1113, Av. 462 (where the Sch. explains it ἐπιθυμητικῶς ἔχω) ; ὁ ἐπʼ ἀφροδισίοις μαινόμενος . . ὀργῶν Poll. 6.188 ; of human beings and animals, to be in heat, desire sexual intercourse, ὀργᾶν πρὸς τὴν ὁμιλίαν, ὀχείαν, Arist. HA 542a32, 560b13 ; ὀ. ὀχεύεσθαι ib. 500b11 ; πρὸς τὸ γεννᾶν Plu. QConv. 2.651c.

to be eager or ready, to be excited, Λακεδαιμονίων ὀργώντων ἔμελλον πειράσεσθαι Th. 4.108 ; ὀργῶντες κρίνειν judge under the influence of passion, Id. 8.2 : c. inf., ὄργα μαθεῖν A. Ch. 454 (lyr.); ὀργᾶν τεκεῖν Arist. HA 613b28 ; ἀκοῦσαι ὀργῶ Cratin. 21 D.; of a thing, to be urgent, ὤργα τὸ πρᾶγμα A. Fr. 54A; ὀ. πρός τι Plu. Alex. 6, D.Chr. 36.26, Marcellin. Vit.Thuc. 54 ; ἐπὶ ἐκφύλους συνόδους Ph. 2.21 ; ὀργᾷς ὃς ἱππίαν ἐς ὁδόν dub. cj. in Pi. P. 6.50 : plpf. Pass. in act. sense, ὧν ἀκροᾶσθαι . . ὤργητο (restd. from Hsch. and some Mss. for ὥρμητο) Th. 2.21.

children.label: III
children.definition: ὀργήσας is f.l. for ὀργάσας in Hdt. 4.64.

definition: ὀργεών, ῶνος (nom. pl. once ὀργεῶναι IG 2(2).2361.18 (iii A. D.)), ὁ,

children.definition: member of a religious association, Is. 2.14, 16, al., Philoch. 94, IG 2(2).1252 (iv B. C.), etc.: poet., generally, for ἱερεύς, priest, A. Fr. 144 :—a poet. form ὀργειών (in codd. sts. ὀργιών), ῶνος, ὁ, is used by Antim. Eleg.Fr. 2, Hermesian. 7.19 : in acc. with ο for ω, ὀργίονας h.Ap. 389 codd. :—a gen. pl. ὀργέων Lys. Fr. 112 S. is prob. f.l. for ὀργεώνων :—a fem. pl. ὀργεῶναι, = ἱέρειαι, in Hsch. (The Att. stem ὀργεών- may come from ὀργηόν- of which acc. pl. ὀργηόνας (or its corruption ὀργειόνας) may be read in h.Ap. l.c.: prob. cogn. with ὄργια.)
of or for the ὀργεῶνες, δεῖπνον ὀ. a feast of the ὀργεῶνες, Ath. 5.186a ; ὀ. σύνοδος IG 2(2).2361.14 (iii A. D.) ; τὸ γραμματεῖον τὸ ὀργειωνικόν ib. 12(8).19 ( Lemnos) ; θύματα ὀ. AB 240, Phot.

natural impulse or propensity (v. ὀργάω II): hence, temperament, disposition, mood, κηφήνεσσι κοθούροις εἴκελος ὀργήν Hes. Op. 304, cf. Thgn. 98, 214, 964, etc. ; ὀργὴν ἄλλοτʼ ἀλλοίην ἔχει Semon. 7.11 ; so μείλιχος, γλυκεῖα ὀργά, Pi. P. 9.43, I. 2.35 ; εὐανθεῖ ἐν ὀργᾷ παρμένων Id. P. 1.89 ; ὀργῆς τραχύτης A. Pr. 80 ; ὠμή, ἀτέραμνος ὀργή, Id. Supp. 187, Pr. 192, etc. ; ὀργῆς νοσούσης εἰσὶν ἰατροὶ λόγοι of ‘a mind diseased’, ib. 380: so in pl., h.Cer. 205, Pi. I. 5(4).34 ; ὀργαῖς ἀλωπέκων ἴκελοι Id. P. 2.77 ; κνωδάλων ἔχοντες ὀργάς A. Supp. 763 ; ἀστυνόμοι ὀργαί social dispositions, S. Ant. 356 (lyr., cf. σύντροφος 3); ὀργαὶ ἤπιοι E. Tr. 53 : also in Prose, διεπειρᾶτο αὐτῶν τῆς τε ἀνδραγαθίης καὶ τῆς ὀργῆς Hdt. 6.128 ; οὐ τῇ αὐτῇ ὀ. ἀναπειθομένους τε πολεμεῖν καὶ ἐν τῷ ἔργῳ πράσσοντας Th. 1.140 ; τῇ ὀ. . . . χαλεπῇ ἐχρῆτο ib. 130 ; ἐπιφέρειν ὀργάς τινι suit oneʼs moods to another, Id. 8.83, cf. Cratin. 230 ; ὁ πόλεμος πρὸς τὰ παρόντα τὰς ὀ. τῶν πολλῶν ὁμοιοῖ Th. 3.82 ; τὴν τῶν πολλῶν . . συνιόντων ὀ. . . . σοφίαν ἡγούμενος Pl. R. 493d.

data.quote: διεπειρᾶτο αὐτῶν τῆς τε ἀνδραγαθίης καὶ τῆς ὀργῆς
οὐ τῇ αὐτῇ ὀ. ἀναπειθομένους τε πολεμεῖν καὶ ἐν τῷ ἔργῳ πράσσοντας
ὁ πόλεμος πρὸς τὰ παρόντα τὰς ὀ. τῶν πολλῶν ὁμοιοῖ
τὴν τῶν πολλῶν . . συνιόντων ὀ. . . . σοφίαν ἡγούμενος

children.label: II
children.definition: anger, wrath, ὀργῇ χρῆσθαι to be in a passion, Hdt. 6.85, S. OT 1241; ὀργὴν ποιήσασθαι Hdt. 3.25 ; ὀργὴν ποιεῖσθαι εἰ . . Th. 4.122 ; ὀργῇ χάριν δοῦναι S. OC 855 ; ὀργῇ εἶξαι, χαρίζεσθαι, E. Hel. 80, Fr. 31 ; ὀργὴν ἔχειν τινί Ar. Pax 659 (but ὀ. ἔχει involves anger, D. 10.44); διʼ ὀργῆς ἔχειν τινά Th. 5.46 ; ἐν ὀργῇ ἔχειν, ποιεῖσθαί τινα, Id. 2.65, D. 1.16 ; οὐ τίθεται ταῦτα παρʼ ὑμῖν εἰς . . ἣν προσῆκεν ὀ. Id. 18.138 ; εἰς ὀργὴν πεσεῖν E. Or. 696, etc. ; ὀργῇ περιπεπτωκέναι D. Ep. 2.14; ἀνιέναι τῆς ὀργῆς, ὀργὴν χαλᾶν, remit oneʼs anger, be pacified, Ar. Ra. 700, V. 727; ὀ. κατέχειν Philem. 185 ; ὀργῆς κρατεῖν Men. 574 ; ὀ. ἐμποιεῖν τινι make one angry, Pl. Lg. 793e ; ὀργῆς τυγχάνειν to be visited with anger, D. 21.175, etc.; ὀργὴν ἄκρος quick to anger, passionate, Hdt. 1.73: in pl., ὀργὰς ἀφιέναι A. Pr. 317; φαίνειν Id. Ch. 326 (lyr.), al.

data.quote: οὐ τίθεται ταῦτα παρʼ ὑμῖν εἰς . . ἣν προσῆκεν ὀ.

children.definition: ὀργῇ in anger. in a passion, Hdt. 1.61, 114, S. OT 405, etc. ; ὀργᾷ περιόργῳ A. Ag. 216 (lyr.); διʼ ὀργῆς S. OT 807, Th. 2.11 ; διʼ ὀργάν A. Eu. 981 (lyr.) ; ἐξ ὀργῆς S. Ant. 766 ; κατʼ ὀργήν Id. Tr. 933, etc.; μετʼ ὀργῆς Isoc. 2.23, Pl. Ap. 34d ; μετὰ τῆς ὀ. D. 21.76 ; πρὸς ὀργήν S. El. 369, Ar. Ra. 844, Th. 2.65 ; ὀργῆς χάριν, ὀ. ὕπο, E. Andr. 688, IA 335.
Πανὸς ὀργαί visitations of Panʼs wrath, Id. Med. 1172 ; but

children.label: b
children.definition: ὀργή τινος anger at or because of a thing, S. Ph. 1309 (cj.), Lys. 12.20 ; ὀ. τῆς προδοσίας εἶχε τοὺς Ἀθηναίους Plu. Them. 9 ; ἀπύρων ἱερῶν ὀργάς A. Ag. 71 (anap.).

data.quote: ὀ. τῆς προδοσίας εἶχε τοὺς Ἀθηναίους

children.definition: Hom., who uses θυμός instead ; once in Hes.; freq. in Eleg. and Lyr. and in Ion. and Att. Prose.
S. Aj. 913, for ὄρυγμα.
Hsch.

secret rites, secret worship, practised by the initiated, a post- Hom. word ; used of the worship of Demeter at Eleusis, h.Cer. 273, 476. Ar. Ra. 386, Th. 948 ; of the rites of the Cabeiri and Demeter Achaia, Hdt. 2.51, 5.61; of Orpheus, Id. 2.81; of Eumolpus, App.Anth. 1.318 ; of Cybele, E. Ba. 78 (lyr.): most freq. of the rites of Dionysus, Hdt. 2.81, E. Ba. 34, al., Theoc. 26.13.

data.ref: E. Ba. 78 (lyr.): most freq. of the

children.label: II
children.definition: rites, sacrifices, SIG 57.4 ( Milet., v B. C.), A. Th. 179 (lyr.), S. Tr. 765, Ant. 1013 ; ὄργια Μουσῶν Ar. Ra. 356.

mysteries, without reference to religion, ἐπιστήμης Hp. Lex 5 ; τοῖς τῆς Ἀφροδίτης ὀ. εἰλημμένον Ar. Lys. 832, cf. Ach.Tat. 4.1; τὰ Ἐπικούρου θεόφαντα ὄ. Metrod. 38.—The sg. ὄργιον is rare, Jahresh. 13 Beibl. 29 No.3 ( Erythrae, iv B. C.), Luc. Syr.D. 16, Orph. H. 52.5. (Prob. cogn. with ἔρδω, ῥέζω, cf. ἔργον, ὀργεών.)

celebrate ὄργια, E. Ba. 415 (lyr.), etc.: c. acc., ὀ. τελετήν Pl. Phdr. 250c; ἱερά Id. Lg. 910c; θυσίας, πομπάς, χορείας Plu. Num. 8: c. dat., pay ritual service to a god or goddess, ταύτῃ Str. 10.3.12:—so in Med., ὀργιάζεσθαι δαίμοσι, and in Pass., of the sacred places, have service done in them, both in Pl. Lg. 717b.

children.label: II
children.definition: honour or worship with ὄργια, ταύτην v.l. in Str. l.c. ; τοὺς μεγάλους θεούς D.H. 1.69, cf. Plu. Cic. 19.
ὀ. τινά initiate into ὄργια, Ph. 2.158, Luc. Trag. 112.

definition: ὀργιάς, άδος, ἡ, pecul. fem. Adj.,

children.definition: ecstatic and mystic, Man. 4.63.
celebrating of ὄργια, Str. 10.3.11, Plu. Superst. 2.169d ; οἱ περὶ τὸν Διόνυσον ὀ. Id. Alex. 2.

one who celebrates ὄργια, μυστηρίων ὀργιασταί Plu. Def.orac. 2.417a ; τῆς Ἴσιδος App. BC 4.47 ; τῆς Ἀκαδημείας ὀ. an enthusiastic adherent of the Academy, Plu. QConv. 2.717d :—fem. ὀργι-αστίς, ίδος, IG 2.1413,1414.
of or for ὄργια, exciting, οὐκ ἔστιν ὁ αὐλὸς ἠθικόν, ἀλλὰ . . ὀργιαστικόν Arist. Pol. 1341a22 ; ὀ. καὶ παθητικά ib. 1342b3.

data.quote: οὐκ ἔστιν ὁ αὐλὸς ἠθικόν, ἀλλὰ . . ὀργιαστικόν

definition: ὀργιάω, poet. for ὀργιάζω, Man. 4.229, for ὀργάω, Id. 1.260, in the Ep. form ὀργιόωντες.

children.definition: to be fierce, of lions, LXX Is. 5.29 ( ὁρμῶσιν cod. A).

definition: ὀργίζω, X. Eq. 9.2 : aor. ὤργισα Ar. and Pl. (v. infr.): ( ὀργή II):—

children.definition: make angry, provoke to anger, irritate, τινα Ar. V. 223, 404, Pl. Phdr. 267c ; opp. εὔνουν ποιῆσαι, Arist. Rh. 1415a35.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., Pl. Phdr. 267d, etc. : fut. Med. (in pass. sense) ὀργιοῦμαι X. An. 6.1.30, Lys. 15.9, Isoc. 18.4, etc. ; but ὀργισθήσομαι Lys. 21.20, D. 59.111 : aor. ὠργίσθην Lys. 22.2, Pl. Prt. 346b, etc.: pf. ὤργισμαι E. Hipp. 1413, Ar. V. 431, etc.: grow angry, be wroth, S. OT 364, etc.: c. part., τίς γὰρ . . οὐκ ἂν ὀργίζοιτʼ . . κλύων; ib. 339, etc. ; τινι with a person or thing, E. Hel. 1646, Th. 4.128, Pl. Ap. 23c, al. ; ὑπέρ τινος Th. 1.143, Isoc. 9.60 ; ἐπί τινι And. 1.30, Lys. 28.2, etc. ; ἐπί τινος D. 21.183 ; διά τι X. An. 1.2.26: abs., in part., ἄνθρωπος -όμενος in a passion, Antipho 5.72 ; τὸ -όμενον τῆς γνώμης their angry feelings, Th. 2.59. Cf. ὀργαίνω.

inclined to anger, irascible, Hp. Epid. 1.19, X. Eq. 9.7, D. 6.33, Arist. EN 1108a7: Comp. -ώτερος Id. Cat. 10a7, Phld. Ir. p.74 W., J. AJ 15.7.4 (v.l. -αίτερος). Adv. -λως, ἔχειν to be angry, D. 21.215 ; τινι with one, Id. 45.67 ; ἐπί τινι Paus. 8.25.6 ; διατίθεσθαι Phld. Ir. p.42 W.: neut. as Adv., ὀργίλον βλέπειν Jul. Or. 3.103b, Lib. Or. 62.24 : Comp. -ώτερον J. BJ 3.2.3.
irascibility, Arist. EN 1108a7, Plu. Virt.mor. 2.443d.
priest, one who initiates others into orgies, AP 9.688, Orph. H. 6.11.
one must be angry, D. 21.123, Arist. EN 1109b16, M.Ant. 5.22.
fit to cause anger, τῶν ἐπιθυμητῶν καὶ τῶν -τῶν Plot. 4.3.28.

definition: ὀργογοργονίστρια, ἡ, epith. of Ἐρινύς, PMag.Par. 1.1419.
ὄργυια, Att. ὄργυᾰ, ᾶς, IG 2(2).1672.9 ; Ion. ὄργυιᾰ, ῆς, ἡ (v. infr.): ( ὀρέγω):—

children.definition: the length of the outstretched arms, about 6 feet or 1 fathom, ἕστηκε ξύλον . . ὅσον τʼ ὄργυιʼ ὑπὲρ αἴης Il. 23.327 ; τοῦ μὲν ὅσον τʼ ὄργυιαν ἐγὼν ἀπέκοψα Od. 9.325, cf. 10.167, X. Mem. 2.3.19.

data.quote: ἕστηκε ξύλον . . ὅσον τʼ ὄργυιʼ ὑπὲρ αἴης
τοῦ μὲν ὅσον τʼ ὄργυιαν ἐγὼν ἀπέκοψα

children.definition: αἱ ἑκατὸν ὀργυιαὶ δίκαιαί εἰσι στάδιον ἑξάπλεθρον, ἑξαπέδου τῆς ὀργυιῆς μετρεομένης καὶ τετραπήχεος Hdt. 2.149, cf. 4.41, 86, PHal. 1.98 (iii B. C.), POxy. 669.39 (iii A. D.).

data.quote: αἱ ἑκατὸν ὀργυιαὶ δίκαιαί εἰσι στάδιον ἑξάπλεθρον, ἑξαπέδου τῆς ὀργυιῆς μετρεομένης καὶ τετραπήχεος

children.definition: rod for measuring land, = 9 1/4 σπιθαμαὶ βασιλικαί, Hero *Geom. 4.11 :—poet. also ὀρόγυια (q.v.): in compds. -ωρυγ-, v. δεκ-ώρυγος. (Proparox. in nom. and acc. sg., Hom. ll.cc. ; oxyt. or perispom. in other cases, cf. Hdn.Gr. 2.613, al. ; in Ion. the nom. and acc. sg. end in -ᾰ, -ᾰν, as in Att., Hom. ll.cc., the gen. and dat. sg. in -ῆς, -ῇ (acc. ὀργυιήν before consonant in Arat. 69, 196, is corrected to ὄργυιαν by Voss); ὀργυιά, -άν in late Gr., Hero l.c., etc.)
an ὄργυια long or wide, κέρας AP 6.114 ( Simm.).

definition: ὀργυιόεις, εσσα, εν, poet. for foreg., Nic. Th. 216.

children.definition: to have the arms extended, πέδαις . . ὠργυιωμένη bound with outstretched arms, Lyc. 1077 ; φώσσωνες ὠ. outspread sails, Id. 26.
hartwort, Tordylium officinale, Nic. Th. 841 (sed leg. τόρδειλον).

definition: ὄρδημα ἡ τολύπη τῶν ἐρίων, Hsch. ὄρδικον· τὸν χιτωνίσκον (Parian word), Id. ὀρδῠλεύω,

children.definition: Id. s.v. ὠρδυλευσάμην.
men, in the mystic language of the Pythia, Plu. Pyth. 2.406e ( Hsch. ὀρείονες· ἄνδρες).
by reaching out, Sch. Il. 2.543, Hsch. s.v. ὀρεκτῇσι μελίῃσι.
subo, Gloss.

stretching out, τὰ χερὸς ὀ. A. Ch. 426 (lyr.); προτείνει δὲ χεὶρ ἐκ χερὸς ὀρέγματα (as Herm. from Sch. for ὀρεγόμενα of cod. M) A. Ag. 1111 (lyr.); βημάτων ὄρεγμα Id. Ch. 799 (lyr., but the passage is corrupt); ὄ. ποδός APl. 16.189 ( Nic.): abs., διὰ τὸ μέγεθος τοῦ ὀ. of their reach or stride, of camels, Arist. HA 632a31 ; v. ἁμιλλάομαι II.
holding out, offering, παρηΐδων E. Ph. 307 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: σχοῖνος, Tab.Heracl. 2.33, al.
eructation, Aret. SD 1.5 (v.l. ὀρυγ-).
part., χεῖρας ὀρεγνύς Il. 1.351, 22.37 ; χεῖρας ὀρεγνύμενος AP 7.506.6 ( Leon.), cf. Mosch. 2.112.

definition: ὀρέγω, Od. 17.366, E. Ph. 1710 (lyr.), etc.; Ion. and later Prose, Hdt. 2.2, Arist. HA 497b27, etc.: impf. ὤρεγον Pi. P. 4.240, App. BC 4.126 : fut. ὀρέξω Il. 13.327, E. Med. 902 : aor. ὤρεξα Il. 23.406, Trag. ( S. OC 846, etc.), and sts. in Prose, Pl. Phd. 117b, X. An. 7.3.29:— Med. and Pass., Il. 24.506, Th. 2.65, etc.: fut. ὀρέξομαι E. Hel. 353, Pl. R. 486a ( ἐπ-): aor. ὠρεξάμην Il. 23.99, E. HF 16, etc.: rare in Prose, X. Mem. 1.2.15 ; also ὠρέχθην ib. 16, Ages. 1.4, Smp. 8.35, Hp. Ep. 17, Epicur. Sent. 7, Fr. 187, as well as in E. ( Hel. 1238) (not in Hom.): pf. ὤρεγμαι Hp. Oss. 18 ; redupl. 3 pl. ὀρωρέχαται, plpf. -έχατο, Il. 16.834, 11.26.—Cf. ὀρέγνυμι, ὀριγνάομαι :—

children.definition: reach, stretch, stretch out, χεῖρʼ ὀρέγων Od. 17.366 ; εἰς οὐρανόν Il. 15.371, Od. 9.527 ; χεῖρας ἐμοὶ ὀρέγοντας, in entreaty, 12.257, cf. Plu. Cam. 36 ; μοι . . λεχέων ἐκ χεῖρας ὄρεξας Il. 24.743 ; πρός τινα Pi. P. 4.240, cf. S. OC 846, etc. ; Ὅμηρον . . , ἐφʼ ὃν πᾶσαι χεῖρʼ ὀρέγουσι πόλεις, to claim him, APl. 16.294.

reach out, hold out, hand, give, κοτύλην καὶ πύρνον Od. 15.312 ; δέπας Il. 24.102 ; ὁπποτέροισι πατὴρ Ζεὺς κῦδος ὀρέξῃ 5.33, cf. 17.453, Hes. Th. 433 ; ἠέ τῳ εὖχος ὀρέξομεν, ἦέ τις ἡμῖν Il. 12.328, cf. S. Ph. 1203 (lyr.); ὀ. πλοῦτόν τινι Pi. P. 3.110 ; τέλος ἔμπεδον Id. N. 7.58 ; ὤρεξε τὴν κύλικα τῷ Σωκράτει Pl. Phd. 117b ; later βοήθειαν ὀρέξαι τοῖς ἀδικουμένοις extend help, POxy. 902.11 (v A.D.).

data.quote: ἠέ τῳ εὖχος ὀρέξομεν, ἦέ τις ἡμῖν

children.label: II
children.definition: Med. and Pass.,

stretch oneself out, stretch forth oneʼs hand, Od. 21.53 ; ἀνδρὸς . . ποτὶ στόμα χεῖρʼ ὀρέγεσθαι Il. 24.506 (but χεῖρας ὀρεξαμένου having lent a helping hand, Epigr.Gr. 448.4 ( Syria)); ὀρεξαμένη ἀπὸ δίφρου Hes. Sc. 456; ὠρέξατο χερσὶ φίλῃσι, χειρὶ σκαιῇ, Il. 23.99, Hes. Th. 178 ; ἔγχει ὀρεξάσθω let him lunge with the spear (from the chariot), Il. 4.307 ; πρόσθεν Ἄρης ὠρέξαθʼ ὑπὲρ ζυγὸν . . ἔγχεϊ χαλκείῳ 5.851 ; ποσσὶν ὀρωρέχαται πολεμίζειν, of horses, they galloped to the fight, 16.834; ὀρέξατʼ ἰών he stretched himself as he went, i.e. made a stride, 13.20 ; ὀρωρέχατο προτὶ δειρήν were stretched out towards the neck, 11.26 ; of fish, rise at the bait, καί τις τῶν τραφερῶν ὠρέξατο Theoc. 21.44 ; for A. Ag. 1111, v. ὄρεγμα I.1.

data.quote: πρόσθεν Ἄρης ὠρέξαθʼ ὑπὲρ ζυγὸν . . ἔγχεϊ χαλκείῳ

children.definition: reach at or to a thing, grasp at, οὗ παιδὸς ὀρέξατο he reached out to his child, Il. 6.466, cf. Od. 11.392 ; in a hostile sense, aim at, assail, hit, τοῦ δʼ ἀντίθεος Θρασυμήδης ἔφθη ὀρεξάμενος . . ὦμον hit him first on the shoulder, Il. 16.322 ; ib. 314, a gen. pers. must be supplied, ἔφθη ὀρεξάμενος πρυμνὸν σκέλος; so in 23.805 ὁππότερός κε φθῇσιν ὀρεξάμενος χρόα καλόν; δηΐων ὀρέγοιτʼ ἐγγύθεν ἱστάμενος Tyrt. 12.12 ; also of a suppliant, τί χρῆμα θηρῶσʼ ἱκέτις ὠρέχθης ἐμοῦ; E. Hel. 1238.

data.ref: 314, a gen. pers. must be supplied,

children.label: b
children.definition: reach after, grasp at, yearn for, γάμων Id. Ion 842 ; τῶν μεγίστων Id. Fr. 240; ἀπεόντων Democr. 202; ζωῆς Id. 205 : freq. in Att. Prose, Antipho 2.2.12, Th. 3.42, Pl. R. 439b, 485d, etc.; ὀ. τοῦ πρῶτος ἕκαστος γίγνεσθαι Th. 2.65 : so c. inf., πόλιν ὠρέξατʼ οἰκεῖν E. HF 16 ; ὀ. τοιοῦτος γενέσθαι Pl. Prt. 326a ; οὐδέποτε ὠρέχθην τοῖς πολλοῖς ἀρέσκειν Epicur. Fr. 187 : also, abs., yearn, desire, πάσῃσιν ὀρέξαιτο πραπίδεσσιν Emp. 129.4 ; θυμὸς ὀρέξατο γηθοσύνῃσιν A.R. 2.878 ; ὀρεγόμεθα κατὰ τὴν βούλευσιν Arist. EN 1113a12 ; cf. ὀρεκτός, ὄρεξις.
σῖτόν τʼ ὄρεξαι take food, E. Or. 303 (v.l. σίτων); αἰώρημα διὰ δέρης ὀρέξομαι I will put the noose on my neck, Id. Hel. 353 (lyr.).
wandering on the mountains, condemned by Thom.Mag. p.267R.
mountain-king, i.e. Pan, AP 6.34 ( Rhian.).

definition: ὀρειάς, άδος, ἡ, ( ὄρος) pecul. fem. of ὄρειος,

children.definition: of or belonging to mountains, πέτρα ὀ. mountain crag, AP 6.219.5 ( Antip.), cf. Arch.Pap. 1.219 ( Ptol.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Oread, mountain-nymph, Bion 1.19, Nonn. D. 6.259, 19.331.
inhabiting the mountains, Opp. C. 3.18, H. 4.309.
wandering on mountains, in pl., Str. 10.3.23, Ael. NA 3.2, Max.Tyr. 34.1.
a festival in which persons traversed the mountains in procession, Str. 12.4.3.
traverse mountains, c. acc., D.S. 5.39.

children.label: II
children.definition: roam the mountains, AP 10.11 ( Satyr.), Plu. Fab. 7 ; of horses, Str. 3.4.15.
mountain-ranging, θήρ S. Ph. 955 ; Κύκλωψ E. Tr. 436; αἶγες, πιθήκη, Ael. NA 14.16, 6.26 ; ὄρνις Ar. Av. 276 codd. ( ὀριβ- Brunck) ; v. οὐριβάτας, ὀρειοβάτης.
roaring in the mountains, Suid., Eust. 460.27, cf. An.Ox. 2.398.
mountain-born, Nic. Th. 874.

children.label: II
children.definition: MoschioTrag. 6.5.
running on the hills, AP 7.413 ( Antip.).
running on the hills, Pi. Pae. 7.6 ( ὀριδρ- Pap.), E. Ba. 985 (lyr.), IA [1593], Nonn. D. 5.229, 25.194 (v.l. ὀριδρ-).
blooming on the hills, Lyc. 1423.
dwelling in the mountains, σῦς Pi. Fr. 313.
couching on the hills, λέοντες Emp. 127.1.
frenzied haunter of the heights, Διόνυσος Tryph. 370 ; μητρὸς ὀ. cj. in Orph. H. 31.5 ( ὀρειομανοῦς codd.).
graze or live on the hills, Suid.

feeding on the hills, δέλφακες Anaxil. 12 (codd. Ath., but ὀρειονόμους is prob. cj.); αἴξ Thphr. HP 9.18.3 ; mountam-ranging, Κενταύρων γέννα E. HF 364 (lyr.) ; ὀ. πλάνη a roaming oʼer the hills, AP 6.107 ( Phil.).
mountainous, hilly, χώρη Hdt. 1.110, cf. 2.34 ; opp. πεδινός, X. Cyr. 1.6.43 ; opp. πεδιάς, J. BJ 3.3.4 ; ὀρεινὴν οὖσαν [τὴν Ἀρκαδίαν] Arist. Mete. 351a3 ; ἡ ὀρεινή hill-country, Id. HA 556a4, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: of or from the mountains, dwelling on the mountains, οἱ ὀ. Θρᾶκες Th. 2.96, X. An. 7.4.11 ; of birds, Arist. HA 592b19 ; of plants, Thphr. HP 6.8.3 ; τὸ ἄγριον καὶ τὸ ὀ. his wild and mountain nature, Pl. Cra. 394e : metaph., ὀ. ἱμάτιον, = ἄκναπτον, Com.Adesp. 328.

children.label: III
children.definition: belonging to the edge of the desert, esp. as epith. of canals, PTeb. 61 (b). 160, al. (ii B. C.).
S. OC 1054 :—written ὀρηο-, Sammelb. 286.2 ( Ptol.); ὀρεο-, ib. 294 ( Ptol.).
mountain-dwelling, Sch. E. Or. 1621, Ph. 683.
mareʼs tail, Hippuris vulgaris, Plin. HN 27.115. ὀρείονες, v. ὀρεᾶνες.
AP 6.14 ( Antip. Sid.), 240 ( Phil.); prob. cj. in Anaxil. 12 ; cf. ὀρεινόμος.

definition: ὄρειος, α, ον, also ος, ον Plu. Sollert. 2.965c, Luc. Demon. 2, Dear.Iud. [DDeor. 20.]3 ; Ep. οὔρειος:—

children.definition: of or from the mountains, mountain-haunting, νύμφην οὐρείην h.Merc. 244, cf. Hes. Fr. 198, Phoronis 2 ; this Ep. form is also used by Trag. and Com. in lyr., S. Ant. 352, E. IT 127, 1126, Ph. 806, Ar. Av. 1098, etc.; but ὄρειος (which is not only Att. but Ion., v. infr.) in trim., as in A. Ag. 497, S. Ph. 937 ; Μήτηρ ὀρεία, of Rhea, Ar. Av. 746 (lyr.); Ion. gen., Μητρὸς Ὀρέης IG 12(7).75 ( Amorgos); Ion. acc. pl., πέτρας ὀρείας Hippon. 35.5 : in Prose, ὄρειοί τινες . . νομῆς Pl. Lg. 677b, cf. Criti. 109d ; opp. ἄγροικος, of animals, Arist. HA 488b2 ; so ὀρειότερος Opp. C. 2.22.
delighting in the hills, APl. 16.256.
vulture or eagle, the same as περκνόπτερος, Arist. HA 618b34.
mountain-roaming, Νύμφαι Ar. Th. 326 (lyr.), cf. Opp. C. 3.224, Nonn. D. 21.189. ( ὀριπλ- freq. in codd.)

definition: ὀρειπλανής, ές, Nonn. D. 9.291 (in form ὀριπλ-); and ὀρεί-πλᾰνος, ον, ib. 16.184 ( ὀριπλ-, v.l. ὀρειπλ-); = ὀρείπλαγκτος.

children.definition: Suid.
wych-elm, Ulmus montana, Thphr. HP 3.14.1.

definition: ὀρείτης, ου, ὁ, ( ὄρος) name of a stone, Orph. L. 362, 457.

children.definition: Ael. NA 2.43.
mountain-bred, mountain-fed, A.R. 2.34 ; ποταμός Tryph. 193 :—also ὀρεί-τροφος, ον, βοτά S. Ichn. 151, cf. Opp. H. 1.12. [Both are freq. written ὀριτρ- in codd., and ὀρίτροφος has ῐ in Babr. 106.3.]
mountain-labour (v. ὀρειτύπος), Hp. Epid. 6.3.9.

working in the mountains: ὀρειτύποι, acc. to Gal. 17(2).49, were wood-cutters and quarry-men, who brought down materials from the mountains :—so ὀρεοτύποι, Thphr. HP 3.3.7, 3.12.4, al. (but ὀρει- CP 5.11.3) ; ὀροιτύποι, Nic. Th. 5, 377, AP 7.445 ( Pers.), Eleg.Alex.Adesp. 1.6 ; cf. also ὀροτύπος.
roam the mountains, Sostr.Eleg. ap. Eust. 1665.49.
mountain-roaming, Phanocl. 3 :—so ὀρείφοιτοι ποιμένες, ὀρείφοιτα θηρία, Babr. 91.2, 95.25 ; ὀρείφοιτοι Βάκχαι Corn. ND 30.
of orichalc, στήλη Pl. Criti. 119c, cf. IG 2(2).1533.24 (iv B. C.).

orichalcum (which by a false etym. was freq. written aurichalcum), mountain-copper, i.e. yellow copper ore, copper or brass made from it, h.Hom. 6.9, Hes. Sc. 122, Stesich. 88, Ibyc. Oxy. 1790.42, B. Fr. 68 Bgk., Pl. Criti. 114e, Arist. APo. 92b22, Mir. 834b25, Philostr. VA 2.7, 20; a mirror of it, Call. Lav.Pall. 19 ; described by Theopomp. Hist. 109 as a mixture of ψευδάργυρος and χαλκός.

data.ref: Theopomp. Hist. 109 as a mixture of

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., = foreg., Suid.
mountainous, Eust. 1246.28.
AP 9.824 ( Eryc.).
to be desired, Stoic. 3.22.
Hsch., Suid.
Hsch.

appetitive, Arist. de An. 433b3, EE 1233a38, al. ; τὸ ὀρεκτικόν the impulsive or conative faculty, Id. EN 1102b30 ; οὐχ ἕτερον τὸ ὀ. καὶ φευκτικόν . . ἀλλήλων Id. de An. 431a13, al. ; ὀ. νοῦς Id. EN 1139b4. Adv. -κῶς Hsch. s.v. θουραίη; πρὸς τὸ ἀγαθὸν -κῶς κινεῖσθαι Arr. Epict. 3.3.2.

data.quote: οὐχ ἕτερον τὸ ὀ. καὶ φευκτικόν . . ἀλλήλων

children.definition: exciting appetite, οἶνος Dsc. 5.6.
stretched out, ὀ. μελίαι pikes to be used for thrusting, Il. 2.543 ; so ὀρεκτὸν δόρυ pike, opp. παλτόν (javelin), Str. 10.1.12.

children.label: II
children.definition: longed for, desired, τὸ ὀ. the object of appetency, Arist. de An. 433a18, cf. EN 1113a10, al. ; τὸ ὀ. κινεῖ οὐ κινούμενον τῷ νοηθῆναι ἢ φαντασθῆναι Id. de An. 433b11 ; opp. ὀρεκτέος, Stoic. 3.22.

data.quote: τὸ ὀ. κινεῖ οὐ κινούμενον τῷ νοηθῆναι ἢ φαντασθῆναι

children.definition: drainers of the mountains, epith. of rivers, Orac.ap Plu. Pyth. 2.406e.

appetency, conation, including ἐπιθυμία, θυμός, βούλησις, Arist. de An. 414b2, cf. 433a13, al., Stoic. 3.40, Epicur. Fr. 202, Metrod. Herc. 831.16, Phld. Mus. p.78 K. ; opp. φυγή, Arist. de An. 431a12 ; opp. ἔκκλισις, Arr. Epict. 1.4.1, M.Ant. 8.7.
longing or yearning after a thing, desire for it, Democr. 219, Pl. Def. 414b, Arist. EN 1119b7, de An. 414b6, al.: more rarely, ὄ. ἐπί τι Plu. Aud. 2.48c ; περί τι Democr. 72.
propension, appetency, ὄ. βουλευτική Arist. EN 1113a11 ; ὄ. διανοητική ib. 1139b5 ; [ἐπιθυμίαι τινὲς] εὐδιάχυτον τὴν ὄ. ἔχουσιν Epicur. Sent. 26.

definition: ὀρεοβαζάγρα, epith. of Hecate or the Moon-goddess, Tab.Defix. Aud. 41 A 6 (i/ii A. D.), cf. 38.28, al.; also ὀρεο-βαρζάγρα and ὀρεο-βαρζάγραμ, Mélanges Beyrouth 15.111.

children.definition: mountain-high, χιόνες Adam. Vent. 40 ( ὡρεο- cod.).
haunt mountains, Luc. Dear.Iud. [DDeor. 20.]7.
haunting mountains, Gloss.
mountain-parsley, Athamanta macedonica, Thphr. HP 7.6.3, Dsc. 3.65, Gal. 12.119, Plin. HN 20.117.
saltuarius, Gloss.; desert-guard, Mim.Oxy. 413.141, Sammelb. 4636.28 (iii A. D.), prob. in OGI 111.16 (ii B. C.).
living on mountains, Opp. C. 3.345 ; ὀρεσίβῐος, Eust.ad D.P. 322.
S. OT 1100; ὀρεσίκοιτος, ον, gloss on ὀρεσκῴοισιν, Hsch.
frequenting of heights, Sch. Il. 8.93.
Hsch. s.v. ὀρεσκῴοισιν.
Hom. always epith. of the lion, Il. 12.299, Od. 6.130, al. ; βούτης Nonn. D. 15.204.
Corn. ND 34.
live on mountains, Nic. Th. 413.

definition: ὀρέσκιος, ον, = sq., of Dionysus, AP 9.524.16.

children.definition: lying on mountains, mountain-bred, wild, of the Centaurs, Φῆρες Il. 1.268 ; Κένταυροι Hes. Fr. 79.5 ; αἶγες Od. 9.155 :—the Trag. form is ὀρεσκόος, ον, A. Th. 532, E. Hipp. 1277 (lyr.), Cyc. 247 ; also in Archil. ap. Lex.Mess. p.409.
APl. 16.233 ( Theaet.), Coluth. 107.
mountain-roaming, Πανὸς ὀρεσσιβάτα ( Dor. gen.) S. OT 1100 (lyr.), cf. Ant. 350 (lyr.).
A. Fr. 168, Ar. Ra. 1344, BMus.Inscr. 902 ( Halic., iii B. C.).
Orph. A. 21.
Hes. Sc. 407, Nonn. D. 28.25.
Nonn. D. 13.137, prob. cj. ib. 14.250.
growing on mountains, ῥίζα Nonn. D. 44.272.
pouring from the mountains, Nonn. D. 20.337.
the tale of Orestes, a poem by Stesichorus, Frr. 34 sqq. Bgk. ; the collective name of Aeschylus’ Agamemnon, Choephoroe, and Eumenides, Ar. Ra. 1124; cf. Λυκούργεια.
of Orestes, κακά S. El. 1117.

ὀρεινός, epith. of a snake, Il. 22.93 ; of wolves and lions, Od. 10.212 ; ὀρεστέρα παμβῶτι γᾶ S. Ph. 391 (lyr.); παρθένος E. Tr. 551 (lyr.); ἀγρευτῆρες Opp. H. 4.586. (Posit. Adj. formed from ὄρος (τό) , opp. ἀγρότερος from ἀγρός.)
Phot. : elsewh. only as pr. n. Ὀρέστης, voc. Ὀρέστα, S. El. 6, 15, etc.
of the mountains, νύμφαι ὀρεστιάδες, = Ὀρειάδες, Il. 6.420, h.Hom. 19.19.

children.label: II
children.definition: ὀρεστίας, ου, ὁ, mountain-wind, Arist. ap. Ach.Tat. Intr.Arat. 33, Call. Fr. 39.

definition: ὄρεσφι, ὄρεσφιν, Ep. gen. and dat. sg. and pl. of ὄρος.

children.definition: Harp. s.v. ὀσχοφόροι; = τὸ σὺν τοῖς βότρυσιν ἀφαιρεθὲν κλῆμα, Hsch.

definition: ὀρεύς, Ion. οὐρεύς, έως, ὁ (even ὁ θῆλυς ὀ. Arist. HA 577b22, though τῆς θηλείας follows τοῖς θήλεσιν ib. 573a16),

children.definition: mule, in Il., as a beast of draught and burden, always in Ion. form, synon. with ἡμίονος, cf. 23.115 with 121, and 24.702 with 716 ; also in Ar. Ra. 290, etc. ; νικᾶν τοῖς ὀρεῦσι win the mule-race, Arist. Rh. 1405b25.—In Att. ἡμίονος is the usual word, though the Adj. ὀρικός is preferred to ἡμιονικός by Moer. p.273P.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj. for ὀρεινός, Lyc. 1111.

Ep. Verb, once in Hom., βόες . . ὀρέχθεον ἀμφὶ σιδήρῳ σφαζόμενοι Il. 23.30: expld. by most Gramm. of the death- rattle in the throat (as though cogn. with ῥοχθέω) ( κατὰ μίμησιν ἤχου τραχέος . . , ἀντὶ τοῦ ἔστενον ἀναιρούμενοι Sch.Tad loc., cf. Eust. 1285.60 sq., Apollon. Lex., Hsch., etc.); but also as cogn. with ὀρέγομαι, ἀναιρούμενοι ὠρέγοντο ἤτοι ἐξετείνοντο Eust. l.c. (cf. Sch. T, Zonar., etc.), i.e. they were stretching themselves, struggling, in the throes of death.—In later Poets it seems freq. to mean swell up, esp. of the heart when stirred by emotion, like ὀρίνομαι, τῶς οἴεσθέ μου τὴν καρδίαν ὀρεχθεῖν; Ar. Nu. 1368 ; νεάτη δʼ ὑπὸ κύστις ὀρεχθεῖ the bladder swells, Nic. Al. 340 ; σφακέλῳ δέ οἱ ἔνδον ὀρεχθεῖ μαινομένη κραδίη, of a dying whale, Opp. H. 2.583 ; τῇ δὲ . . δέδεται κέαρ ἔνδοθεν ἄτῃ, οὐδʼ ἔχει ἐκφλύξαι τόσσον γόον, ὅσσον ὀρεχθεῖ A.R. 1.275 ; καί οἱ ὀρέχθει θυμὸς ἐελδομένῳ στηθέων ἐξ αἷμα κεδάσσαι Id. 2.49: in Aristias 6, μύκαισι ( μυκαῖσι Schneidewin) δʼ ὠρέχθει τὸ λάϊνον πέδον, it must have the sense of ῥοχθέω if μυκαῖσι is accepted ; θάλασσαν ἔα ποτὶ χερσὸν ὀρεχθεῖν let the sea roar landwards, Theoc. 11.43 (cf. βοάω I.2, ἐρεύγομαι (B)).

data.quote: τῇ δὲ . . δέδεται κέαρ ἔνδοθεν ἄτῃ, οὐδʼ ἔχει ἐκφλύξαι τόσσον γόον, ὅσσον ὀρεχθεῖ
καί οἱ ὀρέχθει θυμὸς ἐελδομένῳ στηθέων ἐξ αἷμα κεδάσσαι

children.definition: Poll. 7.183 (written ὀρεο-).

muleteer, Ar. Th. 491, Fr. 633, IG 2(2).10 B4 (v/iv B. C.), 1673.18 (iv B. C.), Pl. Ly. 208b, X. HG 5.4.42, Hyp. Lyc. 5.—In codd. freq. misspelt ὀρεοκόμος, as in Pl. l.c., Poll. 7.183, Hsch. ; the latter also cites a form ὀρειοκόμος, which may be an Ep. spelling of *ὀρη(ϝ)οκόμος, the older form implied by ὀρεωκόμος.
tend mules, and ὀρεω-πώλης, ου, ὁ, mule-dealer, Suid.

Aeol. for ὁράω, Sapph. 2.11 ; 3 sg. ὄρη Theoc. 30.22, cf. Aeol. ἐπόρημι; part. ὄρεις Pittac. ap. D.L. 1.81 ; to this athematic stem ὁρη- (not from ὁρα-) prob. belong 2 sg. Med. ὅρηαι Od. 14.343 and 2 sg. Act. ποθόρησθα Theoc. 6.8 :—but many Dor. forms have η by contr. from ᾰε, as Lacon. inf. ὁρῆν Ar. Lys. 1077, Syrac. imper. ὅρη Epich. 170.12, etc. ; v. ὁράω.

definition: ὁρητός, ή, όν, Ion. for ὁρατός, Man. 2.31, 130.

children.definition: announce rightly and truly, Phryn. PS p.92 B.

definition: ὀρθαγόρας, ου, ὁ, pun on a pr. n., with an obsc. allusion, Ar. Ec. 916.

children.definition: sucking-pig, Lacon. word, Ath. 4.139b, 140b, Hsch. ; cf. ὀρθραγορίσκος.
Apion ap. Plin. HN 32.19.
with straight thorns, Thphr. HP 3.18.11.
a vine growing without props, Plin. HN 14.40.
chelidonium, Gloss.

Pl.Com. 174.12, IG 12(8).52 ( Imbros, ii B. C.), Str. 13.1.12, cf. Phot. s.v.: written with -νν- in IG l.c. and codd. of Pl.Com. and Str., cf. Hdn.Gr. 1.70, with -ν- in Phot. ; Ὀρηθάνης in Hsch. ; Ὀρθαγένης v.l. in Str. l.c. ; Ὀρθάγης Lyc. 538 (cf. Sch. ad loc.).
a woollen cloth for wiping the shrines of temples, Din. ap. Poll. 7.69.

definition: ϝορθασία, ἁ, epith. of Artemis, IG 5(2).429 (v B. C.), 5(1).1572 ; v. sq.

senses.definition: X. Lac. 2.9, Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.239c :—written ϝορθεία, IG 5(1).252 ( Sparta, vi B. C.); ϝωρθεία, ib. 255.1 (ibid., iv B. C.) ; Βωρθεία, ib. 303.9 (ii A. D.) ; Βορθέα, ib. 343.4, al. ; Ὀρθεία, ib. 2(2).1623.76 (name of a ship), 5(1).602.6 (of the goddess) ; Ὀρθία, codd. X., Plu. ll. cc.:—also ϝορθασία, Ὀρθωσία (qq. v.).

definition: ὀρθέσιον ὄρθιον, μακρόν, ὀξύ, μέγα, Hsch.

children.definition: impf. ὤρθευεν E. Or. 405.
tall, straight, κυμβία IG ΙΙ(2).145.49 ( Delos, iv/iii B. C.), cf. 154 B 29,161 B 37, al., Str. 12.7.3:—so ὀρθηρός, BGU 781 i 15, al. (i A. D.).
uphill, X. Lac. 2.3.
speak in a high tone, speak loud, ὀ. γόοις shriek with loud wailings, A. Pers. 687, cf. Phld. Ir. p.60 W.

children.label: II
children.definition: set upright, APl. 16.261.2 ( Leon.).
ὀρθιάζοντα, gloss on ἐξηνδρωμένον, Hsch., cf. Paul.Aeg. 6.70.
the lower part of a mast, Epich. 106 :— also ὀρθίας· ἱστὸς νεώς, Hsch. ; also, sens. obsc., Id.
a setting upright, erection, Aret. SA 2.12, Sch. E. Ph. 1284.
a high pitch of voice: in pl., loud commanding tones, Ar. Ach. 1042.
Gloss., Sch. Lyc. 538.
rowing upright, Hsch.

definition: ὄρθιος, α, ον, Att. also ος, ον Th. 5.58: ( ὀρθός) :—

children.definition: straight up, steep, uphill, οἶμος Hes. Op. 290 ; πάγοι S. Fr. 89 ; πρόσβασις E. El. 489 ; ὁδός X. An. 1.2.21, etc. ; ὄρθιον ἑτέραν (sc. ὁδὸν) ἐπορεύοντο Th. l.c. ; ὄρθιον or πρὸς ὄρθιον ἰέναι march uphill, X. An. 4.6.12, HG 2.4.15 ; ἡ ἀρετὴ πρὸς ὄρθιον ἄγουσα leading by a steep path, Id. Cyr. 2.2.24 ; πρὸς ὀρθίῳ on rising ground, opp. ἐν ἐπιπέδῳ, Id. HG 6.4.14 ; κατὰ τοῦ ὀ. by a steep descent, Arr. An. 1.1.8; τὰ ὄ. the country from the coast upwards, τὰ ἐς μεσόγαιαν φέροντα, Hdt. 4.101.

upright, standing, ὄ. ἦν τὰ γέρρα Id. 9.102 ; πύργοι E. Andr. 10 ; esp. of hair, ὀ. στῆσαι τρίχας S. OC 1624; τριχὸς ὀρθίας πλόκαμος ἵσταται A. Th. 564 (lyr.), cf. E. Hel. 632 (lyr.) ; also ὄ. ἐφιστὰς τὸ οὖς pricking up the ear, Luc. Tim. 23 ; of animals, rampant, Pi. P. 10.36.

children.label: II
children.definition: high-pitched, shrill, κελεύματα A. Ch. 751 ; κωκύματα S. Ant. 1206 ; κηρύγματα Id. El. 683, Ichn. 40 ; ὀρθία σάλπιγγος ἠχώ E. Tr. 1266: more freq. the neut. as Adv., ἤϋσε . . ὄρθια she cried aloud, Il. 11.11 (not found elsewh. in Hom.) ; ἰάχησε δʼ ἄρʼ ὄρθια φωνῇ h.Cer. 20, cf. 432 ; so ὄρθιον ὤρυσαι, φωνεῖν, Pi. O. 9.109, N. 10.76 ; ὄρθιον ἀντηλάλαξε . . ἠχώ A. Pers. 389 ; ἐσήμηνʼ ὄρθιον σάλπιγγι E. Heracl. 830.

νόμος ὄ. a traditional melody of very high pitch (cf. Arist. Pr. 920b20), Hdt. 1.24, Ar. Eq. 1279, etc.: pl., ὀρθίοις ἐν νόμοις A. Ag. 1153 (lyr.); also ὁ ὄρθιος alone, Ar. Ach. 16, etc., cf. Sapph. 44.32 L.-P.; μελῳδία ὄ. Plu. Mus. 2.1140f.

children.label: b
children.definition: ὄρθιος, ὁ, metrical foot having an arsis of four morae and a thesis of eight morae, Aristid.Quint. 1.16, 2.15, Plu. Mus. 2.1140f (but differently defined at Bacch. Harm. 101); of a melody, written in such a rhythm, τῆς ὀρθίου μελῳδίας ibid. [edited from Supp.]

children.label: III
children.definition: formed in column, opp. in line or extended front, ὀ. ποιεῖσθαι τοὺς λόχους X. Cyr. 3.2.6, cf. An. 4.8.10 ; προσβάλλειν ὀ. τοῖς λόχοις ib. 4.2.11 ; ἄγειν τοὺς λόχους ὀ. bring them up in column, ib. 4.3.17 ; προῆγεν [αὐτοὺς] ὀ. ἐπὶ τοὺς πολεμίους Plb. 11.23.2, cf. Polyaen. 5.16.1.

children.label: b
children.definition: engaged lengthwise in the wall, i.e. with only the short sides showing, headers (opp. stretchers) τιθέντας τοὺς λίθους ὀρθίους ἐν γύψῳ Ph. Bel. 80.21.

data.quote: τιθέντας τοὺς λίθους ὀρθίους ἐν γύψῳ

children.label: IV
children.definition: straight, opp. crooked, φλέψ Hp. Aph. 5.68, Gal. 11.218 ; ἴχνος X. Cyn. 6.14, 15 ; τάφροι Thphr. CP 3.6.3 ; opp. πλάγιος, κάλαμοι Aen.Tact. 32.2 : metaph., ἤθη ὄ. straight-forwardness, Plu. Sull. 1 ; ὄ. καὶ αὐθέκαστος Id. Cat.Ma. 6.

children.label: V
children.definition: ὀρθία (sc. γωνία) a right angle, Id. Isid. 2.373f.
-ία, ἡ, latus rectum of a conic, Apollon.Perg. 1.11, al.
ὀ. διάμετρος conjugate diameter of a two-branched curve, Id. 1 Def. 1, al.

children.label: VI
children.definition: Ὄρθιος, epith. of Asclepius, IG 42(1).459 (Epid.).
walk straight, ἀτραπόν (of a blind man) AP 9.11 ( Phil. or Isid.).
shoot straight, metaph., Phld. Rh. 2.71, 98 S.
thrown straight, Hsch. s.v. ἰθυπτίωνα ( -βουλον cod.).
right counsel, Adam. 1.11.
right-counselling, wise, μῆτις, μαχαναί, Pi. P. 4.262, 8.75 ; of persons, A. Pr. 18.
think or judge rightly, Ph. 1.547.
thinking or judging rightly, ψυχή Hp. Ep. 17 ; ὀ. ἐπιμονή, transl. of ‘Rebekah’, Ph. 1.549.
make an elevation (cf. sq. [ὀρθογραφία] II), ὡς ὀρθογραφεῖται as is shown in the accompanying plan, Apollod. Poliorc. 193.1.
orthography, A.D. Adv. 165.15, S.E. M. 1.92 ; name of works by Herodian, Orus, and other Gramm.

data.ref: S.E. M. 1.92 ; name of works by Herodian, Orus, and other Gramm.

children.label: II
children.definition: the elevation of a building, opp. the ground-plan, Vitr. 1.2.2.
orthographer, Suid. s.v. ἀνώγεων.

rectangle, Arist. de An. 413a17 ; ὀρθογών-ιος, ον, rectangular, Archyt. ap. Simp. in Cat. 392.8 ; τρίγωνον Ti.Locr. 98a, D.L. 8.12 ; κῶνος Archim. Sph. Cyl. 1 Prooem.; ἐξ ὀρθογωνίου by rectangular measurement, PSI 4.320.12 (i A. D.), POxy. 2134.15 (ii A. D.).
knowing rightly how to do a thing, c. inf., A. Ag. 1022 (lyr.).
by which justice is upheld, γᾶς ὀμφαλός Pi. P. 11.9:—so ὀρθό-δῐκος, ον, Στύξ B. 10.9, cf. 13.23, and ὀρθο-δίκαιος, A. Eu. 994 (lyr.).
according to right opinion, βίος Procl. in Alc. p.76 C., cf. Id. in Prm. p.721 S., etc. Adv. -κῶς Ascl. in Metaph. 273.7.
have a right opinion, περί τι Arist. EN 1151a19, Posidon. ap. Gal. 5.469, Alex.Aphr. in Top. 265.13.
right opinion, Poll. 4.7, Hierocl. in CA 10p.435M., Olymp. in Phd. p.113 N.
orthodox in religion, Cod.Just. 1.5.21, al., MAMA 1.290 ( Phrygia).
giver of a right judgement, Orph. H. 76.5 (pl.).
run straight forward, X. Eq. 7.14, Poll. 1.205.
the length from the wrist to the finger-ends, = σπιθαμή, Hsch., cf. Poll. 2.157.

children.label: II
children.definition: = membrum erectum, PLond. 1821.166.
Orph. H. 19.8.
correctness of diction, Democr. 20a, Pl. Phdr. 267c, Phld. Rh. 1.191 S., D.H. Dem. 26, Quint. 1.6.20.
speak or pronounce correctly, Phld. Rh. 1.186 S., D.H. 1.90.
with hair upstanding or making the hair stand on end, φόβος A. Ch. 32 (lyr.); φόβαι D.H. 7.72.
sitting upright, cj. in Paul.Aeg. 6.99, for -ευδον.

definition: ὀρθοκαθεύδω, in neut. part. -κάθευδον σχῆμα, dub. in Paul.Aeg. 6.99 (v. foreg.).

children.definition: sit upright, Paul.Aeg. 6.60.
upright stalk, interpol. in Dsc. 4.2.
v.l. in Orph. H. 19.8.
straight-stalked, Thphr. HP 7.8.2, 8.3.2.
= sq., Apollon. Lex. and Hsch. s.v. ὀρθοκραιράων.

straight-horned, βοῦς A. Fr. 74.2 ; upright-horned, ἔλαφος Epic. in Arch.Pap. 7p.4 ; ὀ. φρίκη horror which makes the hair stand up like horns, S. Fr. 875 : Poll. 2.31, Hsch., and Phot. explain it by ὀρθόθριξ.
with head erect, Apollon. Lex. s.v. ὀρθοκραιράων.
stonemason, Inscr.Magn. 290.
a very lark, nickname of one with a thin bad voice, Alciphr. 3.48 (Bergler for ὀρθοκόρυζος).
having an upright crest, Hsch.

with straight or upright horns, epith. of horned cattle, Il. 8.231, Od. 12.348 ; also of galleys, of which the two ends turned up so as to resemble horns, Il. 18.3, 19.344 ; of a mountain range, Πυρήνην -κραιρον AP 14.121.5 ( Metrod.).— Hom. has it only in poet. gen. pl. fem. ὀρθοκραιράων.

data.ref: Od. 12.348 ; also of galleys, of which the two ends turned up so as to resemble horns,

with limbs fixed in extended position, Gal. 18(1).623 ; ἵπποι τὰ γόνατα ἔχοντες σκληρὰ καὶ ὅμοια τοῖς ὀρθοκοίλοις (sic) Hippiatr. 115.

definition: ὀρθολεκτέω, = sq., Ps.- Alex.Aphr. in Metaph. 783.27.

children.definition: speak correctly, Plu. Fat. 2.570e.
correctness of language, Pl. Sph. 239b.

true prophecy, A. Ag. 1215.
a true prophet, opp. ψευδόμαντις, Pi. N. 1.61.
Suid.
with an outstanding boss, πόπανον IG 2(2).1367.13.
making right award, δαίμονες A. Eu. 963 (lyr.).
dozing in an upright position, Pall. in Hp. 2.119 D.
fixed erect, κίδαρις Plu. Alex. fort. 2.340c.
Steep-hill, name of a hill near Thurii, Plu. Sull. 17.
hitting while standing, opp. pummelling while on the ground, CR 43.210 (Fassiller, Asia Minor).
wrestling in an upright posture, opp. κλινοπάλη, Luc. Lex. 5.
walking about erect, Alex.Aphr. in Top. 381.25, Ammon. in Porph. 54.20, Ascl. in Metaph. 345.28, Phlp. in APr. 275.20, al.

definition: ὀρθοπλήξ, ῆγος, ὁ, ἡ, of a horse,

sail prosperously, have a fair voyage: metaph., to be successful, Euryph. ap. Stob. 4.39.27 ( Med.), Clin. ib. 3.1.76.
sailing prosperously: metaph., successful, Hippod. ap. Stob. 4.39.26.
embroidered with feathers, Sammelb. 7033.39 (v A. D.).
breathing only in an upright posture, orthopnoea, a symptom of various diseases, Hp. Prog. 23, Acut. 17.
connected with ὀρθόπνοια, Hp. Coac. 417, 538.

definition: ὀρθόπνοος, ον, contr. ὀρθό-πνους, ουν, = foreg., Hp. Mul. 2.126.

children.definition: walk straight or uprightly, Ep.Gal. 2.14.
ἐλέφας Nonn. D. 26.335, 28.72.
upholding the city, Pi. O. 2.7, BCH 23.302 ( Termessus).
in a straight course, Orac. ap. Porph. Plot. 22.

definition: ὀρθόπους, ὁ, ἡ, πουν, τό, gen. ποδος,

children.definition: upright on their feet, ὀ. βαίνοντες ἄνις . . τιθήνης Nic. Al. 419.

act uprightly, Democr. 181, Arist. Pol. 1260a26, Phld. Herc. 1251.13.
right conduct, Teles p.22 H., prob. in Phld. Herc. 1251.12.
